column2: Proposals before Congress to raise taxes on income from foreign investments and certain export earnings are provoking a battle in which the chief antagonists are the national labor unions and the multinational corporations.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 Argentines are not usually considered among the most fervently religious Latin Americans. But last week a column of faithful stretching for 12 blocks waited to enter the Church of San Cayetano and pray to the saint who is the guardian of workers's jobs.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. Aug. 12 (AP) A violent lightning storm passed over the rocket pad today and for three hours held up technicians who were replaying a faulty valve that postponed the launching of the Viking probe to Mars.
Two Department of Public Works employes who were found repairing their foreman's automobile while on duty were suspended along with the foreman yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) Walter J. Scott, reportedly a key witness in the investigation of the Patricia Hearst case, is in protective custody because he fears for his life, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

Charles F. Mansfield, president of Marine Midland Bank-New York, was named chief executive officer yesterday following the resignation for personal reasons of John S. Lawson as chairman of the board. Mr. Mansfield is 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 The Nixon Administration planned a covert campaign to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile in 1970 through military and diplomatic channels separate from operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, authoritative Government sources said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 12 Secretary General Waldheim, in a report on the work of the United Nations, urged the world organization today to commit itself more strongly to international disarmament.

COPENHAGEN Right now, to use fowl language, the United States is playing chicken with Turkey. Our most urgent foreign policy problem is the need to compose relations with Ankara and Athens while encouraging a modus vivendi for the disputed island republic of Cyprus.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 Governor Carey today signed a bill restructuring the State Commission of Correction and nominated Herman Schwartz, a law professor and longtime advocate of prisoners' rights, as the commission's first full-time chairman.

The kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d were reported to be demanding a $4.5-million ransom and to have "buried" the 21-year-old son of the head of the billion-dollar Seagram Company, Ltd., with a 10-day supply of air and water, according to law-enforcement officials.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP) Striking Birmingham city workers accepted a 5 per cent wage increase and some benefits tonight, ending a 4-week-old strike by nearly one-third of the city's work force. The workers will return to their jobs tomorrow morning.

TRENTON, Aug. 12 (AP) Closing Fort Dix, or even a major cutback of the Army post, "would inflict major damage on the Burlington County economy" and affect the entire state, according to a State Labor and Industry Department report.

EL CAJON, Calif., Aug. 12 Construction will begin her tomorrow on the first largescale recycling plant designer to demonstrate that municipalities can profitably convert their trash and garbage into fue oil to help meet the nation energy needs.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 12 (AP) John Walker of New Zealand shattered the world record in the mile run with a time of 3 minutes 49.4 seconds today. He became the first man to run the distance in under 3:50.

New York State yesterday introduced its major public project to commemorate the American Revolution: a red, white and blue barge that will sail the state's waterways next spring and summer. It will stop in 32 ports, bringing with it the story of the common man in New York during the Revolutionary War.

The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose 0.6 per cent last week, paced by a 5-cents-a-pound rise in the average price of pork chops to $2.18 and a 4-cent increase in the price of bottom round roast to $2, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 12 The Bronfmans are newcomers here, but the seclusion they were seeking even before the kidnaping of Samuel Bronfman 2d is as old as this northern Westchester community.

The kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d were reported to be demanding a $4.5-million ransom and to have "buried" the 21-year-old son of the head of the billion-dollar Seagram Company, Ltd., with a 10-day supply of air and water, according to law-enforcement officials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 A group of medical students at George Washington University Medical School has filed suit against the university because of proposed increases in tuition.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 12 After nearly 10 years of stalemate, the black and white leaders of Rhodesia announced today that they had agreed to meet within two weeks to discuss a new constitution for the racially divided country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will gather in Cleveland tomorrow to plan stepped-up enforcement of school desegregation in Northern districts.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 New Jersey's Commuter Operating Agency today proposed railfare increases of up to 70 per cent and bus-fare increases of up to 100 per cent on state-subsidized intrastate lines.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges here yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation as an outgrowth of the 1974 sale of its major appliance division.
BONN, Aug 12 The elders of Oberammergau have decreed that the next version of the town's famous Passion Play will not use a sharply criticized text that blames the Jews for the death of Jesus.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 Federal officials have begun notifying long-time friends and acquaintances of James R. Hoffa that they will be among witnesses called before a grand jury soon to tell under oath what they may know about the disappearance 13 days ago of the former president of the Interntional Brotherhood of Teamsters.

LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 12 (UPI) The Portuguese national airline accelerated the airlift of white refugees from the southern town of Nova Lisboa today and authorities said that they planned to evacuate 250,000 to 300,000 persons to Portugal by Oct. 31.
LISBON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) A political party in Portuguese Timor that says it has staged a successful coup demanded immediate independence today, according to the office of the Portuguese President.

Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut accused the Federal Government yesterday of turning its back on the city's transit problems and then recommended a regional approach in finding new revenue to help stabilize the fare in the future.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 Governor Carey today signed a bill restructuring the State Commission of Correction and nominated Herman Schwartz, a law professor and longtime advocate of prisoners' rights, as the commission's first full-time chairman.

The Baltimore Orioles, who had won 22 of 29 games since the All-Star break in mid-July, lost to Kansas City last night, but it took the Royals 10 innings to accomplish the feat. The final score at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium was 4-2.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) Nine persons were injured, one seriously, as several hundred youths attacked motorists passing through Boston's Mission Hill and Orchard Park housing projects today, the police said.

It is difficult to know the precise level at which a company calling itself U.S. Terpsichore should be evaluated. This troup of some 34 dancers opened a week's season at the small yet attractive Marymount Manhattan Theater, a seemingly useful modern facility at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 East 71st Street.

When an agency establishes a reputation for expertise in one field, it often finds difficulty in breaking out of that niche. Venet Advertising which spent more than 15 years specializing in retail accounts is no exception.
Henri Pierre Blanc, director of Hilton International's Career Development Institute at Montreal, died there yesterday. He was 43 years old and lived in Montreal.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Massachusetts House voted overwhelmingly today to cut welfare spending and drop thousands of recipients from the state welfare roles.
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 12 (Reuters) A major Protestant Parade here today ended in three hours of fighting between British soldiers and rockthrowing Roman Catholic youths.

LISBON, Aug. 12 Military officers today petitioned President Francisco da Costa Gomes to end what the officers view as efforts by Premier Vasco Goncalves to turn Portugal into a Communist state on Eastern European lines.

SHIFTING GEAR With the closing of "Moby Dick Rehearsed" last weekend at the downtown St. John's-in-theVillage, the Theater Q.E.D. unit is introducing mime, which will subsequently alternate with two short plays by Shaw for the rest of the summer.
Savoring the promise of moving within 5 games of first place last night, the Mets found disappointment instead at Shea Stadium and went down to defeat before the San Diego Padres, 8-5.
Prof. A. Chester Hanford, former dean of Harvard College, died Tuesday at the Dunrovan Nursing Home in Creskill, N.J., He was 84 years old.

NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) Marilyn Palmer, a seventh-grade teacher in western Canada, scored a stunning upset with a 5-and-3 victory over the defending champion, Cynthia Hill, today in the second round of the 75th women's United States Amateur golf championship.
Dr. Alvin Novick is batman and shih tzu man.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission says the last year's 400 per cent rise in raw sugar prices resulted from natural market forces, but warned its study was not exhaustive.

Prices declined yesterday in the quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market. An early attempt to extend Tuesday's upturn failed to take hold in the closing hours of trading.

Brotherhood will reach a milestone sometime in the next few days when Jesus Alou gets into the line-up for the New York Mets and gives the three Alou brothers of the Dominican Republic a combined total of 5,000 games in the major leagues.
"Hey, you were terrific in that TV commercial," a visitor called out.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 13 Sundance, a 6-year-old Palomino mare, scored 754 points and won the national final in the American Horse Shows Association large pony competition today.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 13 (UPI) The pound, buoyed by reports of the release tomorrow of optimistic British trade figures for July, rallied slightly on money markets today at the expense of the dollar and other currencies.
As the stock market became increasingly concerned with a renewal of double-digit inflation, prices on the New York Stock Exchange dropped yesterday quite sharply though trading remained light.

Avery Fisher Hall is the kind of place that daunts all but the most impressive chamber-music players. But the Beaux Arts Trio, which was making its debut at-the mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday night, is certainly an impressive aggregation, and the result was a superb (if inevitably somewhat anemicsounding) night of music.

Governor Carey's veto of a bill to stiffen penalties for youths who commit violent crimes has been criticized by some juvenile-justice specialists in light of an increase of nearly 20 per cent in such arrests here in the first six months of 1975.
The talking calculator finished its computation, and answered: "Five six four."
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 13, (Reuters) At least three people were killed here tonight and 26 wounded when a bomb was thrown into a tavern in one of the city's Protestant districts.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13 Attorney General Edward H. Levi disclosed today Justice Department proposals to curtail the Federal, Bureau of Investigation's domestic intelli gence operations. The proposals include a ban against using informers to instigate crimes; a requirement that the Attorney General report "periodically" to Congress on "preventive action plans" that he

Mark B. Slater, newsstand sales manager for Time Inc. publications and, later, for Time magazine, died of cancer Tuesday evening in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived at 11 Normandy Road. Bronxville.

The Court of Appeals decision that President Ford exceeded his authority in imposing a $2-a-barrel fee on imported crude oil moves the nation toward sudden and total decontrol of oil prices. Whether or not the President appeals to the Supreme Court, oil controls will expire Aug. 31 if Mr. Ford makes good his threat to veto Congress's bill extending the Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act, with its authority for continued control.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug 13 Hugh L. Carey brought his traveling Governor's office to the northernmost reaches of the state today at the start of a two-day tour that took in heavy industry and dairy farming, recreation and health care, and the scene that knows no geographic bounds politics.

Stocks of gasoline and distillate products rose in the week ended Aug. 8, giving further indication that shortages of these essential petroleum products now appear unlikely at least until the early months of winter.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 13 The Giants gave up on Jim Del Gaizo as a quarterback today and also declined to take a chance on the physical condition of their latest acquisition, Greg Marx.
MONTREAL, Aug. 13 The American Bar Association registered its opposition today to restrictions on news organizations in sections of the proposed Federal Criminal Code before Congress.

Advertising in the Yellow Pages has long been thought of as a way for local and regional advertisers to reach consumers in a buying mood. But with the entry of a number of the largest ad agencies into this field in recent years national advertising in the classified sections of telephone directories has become a more significant factor.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13 The idea that music is a self-contained system, referring to nothing outside itself, is a seductive one for many composers. Music, in this Spartan view, is about and only about the interplay of sounds. There is something appealingly neat in this way of composing and listening to music that finds a response in our science-oriented society. It is a fair gener

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 13 A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is expected to return many indictments soon as a result of investigations' of allegations of corruption in the awarding of contracts by the Long Island State Park Commission, an official of the commission said today.
The kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, the 21-year-old heir to the Seagram fortune, sent a new communication to his family yesterday in the form of a tape recording.
JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 13 Bill Collins of Brae Burn, the 1956 titleholder, held on to the lead in the annual $25,000 Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship today on a technicality.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 9 The controversy about what role, if any, that Stephen M. Bingham, a fugitive lawyer, played in an alleged prison escape attempt in 1971 by George Jackson intensified during the first week of testimony in the murder trial here of six inmates of San Quentin prison.

When the United States Supreme Court first met in 1790, there were three million people in the United States, and we have 213 million today. As the country grew, government was enlarged to meet new needs. In 1790, there were only thirteen Federaljudges in addition to the six Supreme Court Justices; today, there are over 500 Federal judges and nine Justices.
Fresh peas for Thanksgiving dinner, leaf lettuce in January and carnations to cut in March these are real possibilities with a greenhouse.
ALBANY, Aug. 13 (UPI) The 1975 Legislature and Governor Carey got along remarkably well. The Democratic Governor vetoed ony 18.1 per cent of the 1,059 bills sent to him a record low for the decade.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP) Walter Scott, reportedly a key figure in the hunt for Patricia Hearst, said tonight that his brother Jack had offered to deliver the missing newspaper heiress to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in return for $100,000 and a grant of immunity from prosecution.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the Government of Iran for a 15-month contract for systems planning and engineering for a national telecommunications network for both civil and military use

ANCHORAGE, Aug. 12 There's nothing quite like driving around for half an hour or so looking for a parking space in downtown Anchorage to make a resident or a visitor come abruptly to terms with what has happened in the last few years to this sprawling city on the quiet waters of Cook Inlet.
PARIS, Aug. 13 When Thomas Mann, one of this century's major writers, died near Zurich, Switzerland, in 1955 he left four bulky packages wrapped in brown paper to be opened 20 years after his death.
"Lose 'Em All, Lose 'Em All," a song about the losses of the Brooklyn Dodgers in the early Forties, was the hit of the annual Baseball Writers show.
The thousands of extra dollars that New York State legislators voted to pay themselves on the last day of their session will be held back because of questions raised about their constitutionality.

After generations during which going to college was assumed to be a sure route to the better life, college-educated Americans are losing their economic advantage over those less educated and the value of college as a guarantee of upward social mobility is slipping.
Dr. Frank J. Gardner, international editor of Oil and Gas Journal, a trade publication, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in London, where he had his office. He was 59 years old.
LISBON, Aug. 13 A group of radical but anti-Communist officers today called for the establishment of a political system here based on such organizations as neighborhood and worker associations.

Lee A. Iacocca, president and a director of the Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest auto maker, sold nearly 16 per cent of his stock in the company on July 15, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

Anatoly Karpov, the new world champion, is fortunately not emulating his predecessor, Bobby Fischer, who buried his head in the sand during the three years of his reign. No sooner had the 24year-old Russian been declared the titleholder after Fischer refused to defend his championship, than he entered and won the strong third Vidmar Memorial Tournament in Portoroz-Ljubljana, Yugoslavia.

A meeting to discuss objections by Off Off Broadway producers to a new code for showcase productions, issued Aug. 4 by the Actors Equity Association, broke down yesterday when a committee representing 49 theaters walked out of the offices of Donald Grody, executive secretary of Equity.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 Canada has sold the Soviet Union 750,000 long tons of lowgrade wheat, considerably easing anxiety in the agricultural community over the record accumulation of lowgrade grain because of unfavorable weather conditions.
The kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, the 21-year-old heir to the Seagram fortune, sent a new communication to his family yesterday in the form of a tape recording.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP) -L.E. Judd, former city editor of The Akron Press, now defunct, died Monday of emphysema and a heart condition. He was 83 years old and in recent years had lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., as well as here.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 The United States auto industry reported 131,218 new-car sales in the Aug. 1-10 period, off 28.9 per cent from a year ago and a sharper decline than had been expected by analysts.

Golf purists claim that most hackers cheat at some time during the majority of their rounds. This may be a rather harsh judgment since most golfers may only be guilty of not knowing the rules. After all, if officials who referee tournament matches do not know the exact letter of the golf law, it is difficult to accuse average players of cheating.

"I can't teach them how to play the game they know how to do that," said Greg Jackson, a guard for the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association. "But maybe I can tell them about some other things like school and hygiene they'll need to know."

NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 13 A plan to save more than $100,000 in annual fire-fighting costs by staffing one of the city's outlying firehouses with l6 Rutgers students was announced here today by Mayor Richard Mulligan.

LISBON, Aug. 13 The Roman Catholic Church, initially intimidated and embarrassed by a revolution that it neither promoted nor foresaw, has 15 months later taken the offensive against it in terms suggesting almost a crusade.
LISBON, Aug. 13 A group of radical but anti-Communist officers today called for the establishment of a political system here based on such organizations as neighborhood and worker associations.

The 50-cent subway and bus fare that will take effect here next month is a necessary evil, dictated by the city's fiscal plight, the soaring deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the failure of public officials to develop adequate policies for the support of mass transportation.

"There's the most extraordinary, unheard of poetry buried in America, but none of the conventional means known to culture can even begin to extract it ... the agony is too deep, the disorder too big for art enterprises undertaken in the old way ...

HONG KONG, Thursday, Aug. 14 Cambodia announced the appointment yesterday of two Communist figures with reported links to Hanoi as Deputy Premiers. The announcement was followed by a disclosure from Peking last night that a high-level delegation of Cambodian leaders would visit China tomorrow.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 (Reuters) The itinerary in the United States of Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako was announced by the Japanese Government today.
ATHENS, Aug. 13?Greek authorities are investigating the case of a Greek seaman, a Jew, who disappeared in the Iraqi port of Basra more than two weeks ago.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug 13 Nigeria's new head of state, Brig. Muritala Rufai Mohammed, threw his full support behind the previous government's $45billion five-year development plan today, urging officials and citizens to carry out the program "with courage and industry."
FATIMA, Portugal, Aug. 13 some half-million Roman Catholic pilgrims gathered here today to pray for the freedom of Portugal and for the troubled African territory of Angola.

Prices of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds plummeted yesterday by $15 to $25 for each $1,000 face value, primarily reflecting the disappointing pace in presale interest for $275-million of new bonds.

HONG KONG, Aug. 13 The new South Vietnamese authorities appear to be still having difficulty deciding whether to allow about 2,000 Vietnamese refugees abroad to return to Saigon, knowledgeable diplomats say.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 13 Orange County's welfare crisis remained unresolved today and County Executive Louis V. Mills said he would renew efforts for Congressional legislation for special Federal revenue-sharing funds for welfare.

The Ladies' Home Journal announced yesterday a reduction in its guaranteed circulation, page rate and cost per thousand, effective with the January, 1976, issue. "We're returning to the era of the reader," said Louis E. Porterfield, publisher, adding that 56 per cent of the magazine's revenue is now derived from circulation.

GALLUP, N.M., Aug. 12 Quintessentially speaking, as a young man here was the other day, the Midwest has corn and baton-twirling contests, the Northwest has trees and returnable bottles, the Far West has freeways and surfboards, and the Southwest has turquoise and retirees.
NEW BERN, N.C., Aug. 13 (AP) Abbott Laboratories has pleaded no contest to charges that it conspired to introduce adulterated and misbranded intravenous solutions into interstate commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The White House is considering asking a Federal court to clarify whether it has the power to release documents from former President Richard M. Nixon's papers under subpoenas issued by the Senate Select Committee, on Intelligence, Ford Administration sources said today.
Raymond K. Mason, chairman of the Charter Company, said yesterday that two of Charter's subsidiaries, the Bartell Media Company and Downe Communications, Inc., would
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 13 (UPI) About 10 policemen battled a crowd this morning in a night club parking lot. Two officers were injured. and a bystander was wounded

The Municipal Assistance Corporation, disappointed that $125-million of its $275-million August bond issue remains unsold, yesterday deferred until tomorrow the closing of the offering to give salesmen more time to scour the country for customers.
"There are no heroes here," said a longtime aide of Mayor Beame as he discussed the political ramifications of the worst fiscal crisis in the city's history, a crisis that has forced.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is preparing to mount a legal challenge to the pending wage freeze but is still holding out the possibility that it can reach agreement with the city before the freeze takes effect.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 13 Mesmerized as usual by their former teammate, who helped pitch them to three world championships, the Oakland A's lost to Jim (Catfish) Hunter and the New York Yankees tonight by a 3-1 score.

CRUZEIRO'DO SUL, Brazil This is the end of the road, the last deadend stretch of highway in this nation's mad, heroic attempt to explore and conquer the vast world of equatorial jungle and river called Amazonia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 13 Secretary General Waldheim announced today that he would ask the forthcoming General Assembly to approve a $737-million budget for the next two years, 21.6 per cent above the two-year $606-million budget for 1974 and 1975.
PARIS, Aug. 13 When Thomas Mann, one of this century's major writers, died near Zurich, Switzerland, in 1955 he left four bulky packages wrapped in brown paper to be opened 20 years after his death.

Dance nowadays seems to be an inexhaustible New York resource. No sooner has American Ballet Theater vacated the New York State Theater than the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater comes in. In fact, Ballet Theater vacated last Satur
DEERFIELD, Aug. 13 The nation's oldest agricultural society gave some city slickers an education today with a farm tour of Cumberland County.

Faced with the prospect of continued inflation in the cost of materials and services purchased by the city, Beame administration officials concede that further reductions in the municipal work force will be needed to prevent exceeding the promised 2 per cent limit on budget increases.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Aug. 13 The launching of a Viking craft toward Mars, already postponed three days by a malfunction in the booster rocket's steering mechanism, was delayed today for about 10 more days by an electricity-supply problem aboard the Viking itself.

Ubiquity would be a useful property for some bridge players. The truth of this statement is illustrated by the sad story of Bill Sides of Van Nuys, Calif., who was trying to be in Miami Beach, Fla., and New York City simultaneously last Monday and could not quite manage it.

"He's free to do whatever he wants to do," said Tim Temerario, Washington's personnel director, in making the announcement yesterday that Duane Thomas, the moody and controversial running back, had been dropped by the Washington Redskins.

NEWARK, Aug. 13 In a somewhat milder stance than heretofore, Attorney General William F. Hyland and Virginia Long Annich, director fo the Department of Consumer Affairs, urged 3,100 pharmacists throughout the state to end their "boycott" of Medicaid presccriptions and honor their professional commitments under the law.

Several major airlines are seeking the agreement of the Ford Administration for a deal whereby the airlines would reduce their fuel consumption and thus their scheduled service by 9 per cent over the next year and would in return receive sympathetic consideration for higher passenger fares.

HANOVER, West Germany, Aug. 13 (Reuters) More than 10,000 men, many already exhausted, continued for the sixth day today to fight a spreading series of woodland fires in northern Germany. No rain was forecast.
Dora McCann, a radio personality, died yesterday at New York University Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Yonkers.

T-shirts emblazoned with a brand label, trademark or other commercial advertisng are appearing all over the country. The midsummer madness is not only a breathing form of pop art but a classic example of unplanned, unchecked free enterprise.

The Prospect Park boathouse, a Brooklyn landmark restored after years of neglect at a cost to taxpayers of more than $1-million and reopened last year amid, great fanfare, once again lies in a state of disusethe victim of delays in a minor construction project.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 A report issued today by the United States Commission on Civil Rights says that little has been done by local, state and Federal officials in the last 10 years to ameliorate racial hostility in the southern Illinois town of Cairo. The three governments were cited for gross negligence concerning the town's problems.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) Heavy fighting involving the three rival liberation movements in Angola has broken out in the port of Lobito, a Lisbon radio station said tonight.

James R. Dumpson, the city's Human Resources Administrator, called on the Federal Government yesterday to set up special job and education programs for Vietnam refugees rather than have them rely on existing programs and voluntary efforts on their behalf.
LONDON, Aug. 13 Margaret Thatcher's biggest single frustration is that she cannot order up a national election tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam The fury of the battle is over, though the guns are not yet completely silent. For some the adjustment is painful; for others if has been unbelievably smooth. For all a different life is dawning in Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) A juror in the Kent State shootings trial was dismissed today after allegedly calling the plaintiffs "Commies."
LEE, Mass., Aug 13 Tenacity has to be the first requirement of anyone trying to establish a new dance company.

After generations during which going to college was assumed to be a sure route to the better life, college-educated Americans are losing their economic advantage over those less educated and the value of college as a guarantee of upward social mobility is slipping.

An investor filed a suit yesterday in Federal District Court here accusing top city officials, banks and brokers of defrauding the purchasers of the city's securities by a concerted effort to conceal "the true financial position of the city."
Elizabeth Armstrong Hawes died yesterday at her summer home in Little Compton, R.I. She was 68 nears old.

Kidnapping in the United States appears to have risen dramatically in the last decade, but sentences for convicted kidnappers seem relatively light in contrast to possible penalties of up to life in prison, Federal Bureau of Investigation records show.

Articles in two scientific journals have questioned widely publicized predictions that, in coming decades, the world climate will deteriorate severely affecting food production and, perhaps, initiating a new ice age.
"I think I was honest," said Betty Ford when asked yesterday if she had regrets about saying she "wouldn't be surprised" if her 18-yearold daughter, Susan, told her she was having an affair.

For nine years Charles Bauerlein of Allendale, N.J., toiled in vain, trying to get a passion flower vine to yield one blossom. Under the best of conditions, it is a singular event, for the flower opens for less than 24 hours and then falls off. "So, it's an occasion that you take movies of," Mr. Bauerlein said the other day.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 13 Premier Yitzhak Rabin and his negotiating team today studied Egypt's reply to Israel's latest proposal for an interim Sinai agreement and found that it left something to be desired. However the Israelis acknowledged that it had "narrowed the issues to a degree." No details were disclosed.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 13 Alice Peters and her three sons moved into their new home in this quiet Westchester County community on Monday night, but a mysterious fire attack there early today has forced them to seek refuge with relatives.

For at least six hours yesterday officials at Rikers Island prison did not know that four inmates had escaped, apparently by swimming half a mile in a remote section of La Guardia Airport, where their wet clothes aroused the suspicions of Port Authority notice.
Movielab Inc., said yesterday it had settled out of court its antitrust suit against Technicolor, United Press International reports.

The increase in the city's real-estate tax will cost the average electricity customer who uses 250 kilowatt hours a month 34 cents, not 20 cents as originally reported, Consolidated Edison disclosed yesterday. The company is passing the realty-tax increase along to its customers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) Mario DeStefano, reputed loan racketeer whose two brothers were victims of gangland-style slayings, died yesterday of a heart ailment at PresbyterianSt. Luke's Hospital. He was 60 years old.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 31 per cent in second-quarter net income and 17 per cent in the first half, reflecting lower results for its insurance, Grinnel and Rayonier operations as well as European automotive and consumer products.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) The newest major energy agency outlined today a threepart strategy to have the sun meet one-fourth of the nation's enemy needs in 45 Years.
BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Seventeen persons were injured today, including six policemen, and two persons were arrested in sporadic stone throwing as racial violence erupted again.

Claude F. Houlbreque, who had been a senior officer and film director in the public-information division of the United Nations from 1946 until his retirement in 1973, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived in East Marion, L.I.
Dr. Horace E. Wood 2d, who retired as a Rutgers University biology professor in 1959, died yesterday at a Swainton, N.J., nursing home. He was 74 years old and lived in Cape May Court House. N.J.

Traffic on West 125th Street was disrupted for almost four hours yesterday when more than 2,000 youngsters employed in summer programs across the city, many of whom had not been paid for more than four weeks, tried to force their way into a Youth Services Agency pay office to get their checks.
Irene Bengochea was a 17year-old Bronx high school senior who could read only 180 English words a minute but that was five weeks ago.
The Papercraft Corporation, the largest manufacturer of gift-wrap items, is small in a nation of billion-dollar corporations.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Aug. 13 (UPI) A spokesman for Senator Carl Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, said today an illegal $5,000 contribution to his 1972 campaign committee would be returned to Ashland Oil, Inc.

Governor Carey's veto of a bill to stiffen penalties for youths who commit violent crimes has been criticized by some juvenile-justice specialists in light of an increase of nearly 20 per cent in such arrests here in the first six months of 1975.

Some of the wildest wildlife this side of the Everglades is within two hours' ride from the city, in New Jersey at a couple of national wildlife refuges. If your children have reached the stage where they whisper in the presence of wild animals partly out of fear of scaring them away and partly out of reverence the refuges are naturals for a summertime outing.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 A week before his mysterious disappearance, James R. Hoffa told a longtime friend that "something big is going to happen soon."

Portugal's friends and allies will watch the denouement in Lisbon with anxiety but also with higher hopes for the survival of freedom than could have been justified even a few days ago.

"This town here is a real old-fashioned town," said Pat Racana, a resident of College Point, Queens, as he watched 75 youngsters from the Neighborhood Youth Corps working yesterday with rakes, shovels and axes to clean up the College Point Sports Complex, a 24-acre field.

As music director of the New York Philharmonic, Pierre Boulez has followed it out into the city parks more faithfully than anyone else. Tuesday night he led the orchestra in Central Park for the fourth time in as many summers. In turn, he had the faithful with him.

Louis Goldburt, a certified public accountant and a senior partner of the firm of Siegel Goldburt, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in this city and Westhampton, L.I.

Chicago wheat prices rose 12 to 17 cents a bushel yesterday as the major export houses covered actual and expected overseas orders. Corn gained 3 to 5 cents, but soybean prices fell 6 to 9 cents in lackluster trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

With the Bicentennial only months away, one of the country's most historic sites is ironically threatened with conversion into a cemetery bordered by housing developments and a hotel-office-shopping center plaza.

Near Yalta yesterday, Leonid I. Brezhnev gave 18 visiting United States Congressmen a tour of a summer palace of the 19th-century Czar Alexander III. For 20 years, Yusef Lateef has nurtured a jazz image consistently his own a slightly exotic use of reed and woodwind instruments that is just far enough removed from the jazz form to be distinctive, but not so far as to seem a labored attempt to be different. The balance wheel is his strong, forthright, swinging attack, which invariably comes charging into view before he can become too precious.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 Lynn Epstein of Miami, the second-seeded star, was eliminated today in the United States girls 18-and-under grass court tennis championship after being at match point three times. A 50-cent increase in airport bus fares from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The increase will take effect on Sunday.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 United States automobile production is expected to decline 7 per cent this week from last week as more plants are closed for model changeovers, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

Bruce Alva Gimbel, the 62year-old chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced his retirement yesterday. His departure, effective Aug. 31, from the department store chain his great grandfather founded 133 years ago ends another family dynasty in American retailing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Ford Administration will appeal to the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court's decision that President Ford's tariff on imported oil is illegal. Solicitor General Robert H. Bork announced today.
MANILA, Aug. 14 The Philippine Government announced tonight that rebels in southern Mindanao who fought under the banner of the Moro Liberation Front had accepted a cease-fire.

LISBON, Aug. 14 President Francisco da Costa Gomes sought today a 45-day delay in replacing his Communistbacked. Premier, Gen. Vasco Goncalves, but Socialists and other political opponents applied pressure to make the Premier step down now.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 A state judge today ordered a re-examination of the ballistics evidence used to convict Sirhan. B. Sirhan of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 At a time of mounting crisis in Portugal, Secretary of State Kissinger today gave the strongest United States support to date to the forces who oppose the Communists in that country.

The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday it had increased its posted lead price to 20 cent, a pound from 19 cents, f.o.b. Herculaneum, Mo.

To ease the fears of 200 newly arrived Vietnamese refugees and help them adapt life in the metropolitan area, an orientation session was held last night at the American Red Cross of Greater New York, 150 Amsterdam Avenue.

The invisible man is one of the more compelling modern power fantasies. The idea of moving unseen in and out of other lives, as voyeur or fabricator of destinies, has a godlike appeal. The invisible man is there but not there; he alters things, for good or ill, to suit his whims, free of the burden of self, impervious to normal human consequences.

The first two major merchandising chains to report results for their most recent quarters, showed a mixed trend. Montgomery Ward increased earnings by 15.6 per cent in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31. Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had a 28.1 per cent decline for its third fiscal quarter ended June 30.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved an expenditure of $22-million to modernize and improve the main concourses and loading platforms of the midtown bus terminal on Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) The launching of the trouble-plagued Viking spacecraft was rescheduled today for Aug. 20, giving the mission another chance to land on Mars on July 4, 1976, space agency officials said.
William F. Beane, the Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in charge of the Bronfman case, is no stranger to kidnapping inquiries.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 It was getting close to midnight. The police Tactical Patrol Force swarmed down the hill and onto the intersection by the Bromley-Heath housing project in a blur of blue jumpsuits, helmets and nightsticks, and the rock-throwing bands of black youths disappeared into the warren of drab brick buildings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UPI) The City of Chicago has issued tickets for deceptive practices against Borden, Inc., and four retail stores, charging that the manufacturer and stores were selling outdated Cracker Jacks.

These are happy but confusing days for shareholders of the Apco Oil Corporation. Apco's stock was languishing in the low teens back in early July when the Alaska Interstate Company of Houston bid $17.50 a share for 1.5 million of Apco's shares approximately 51 per cent of the outstanding stock.

Justice Morris Pashman of the New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday temporarily canceled a 25-cent surcharge that the state had recently ordered Medicaid patients to pay on prescriptions, and he restored a 25-cent cut in dispensing fees that had caused some druggists to stop filling Medicaid prescriptions.
William M. Ellinghaus, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, was among eight business, financial and labor leaders named yesterday by Mayor Beame to his new management advisory board.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 14 (Reuters) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tonight warned Rhodesians not to put too much faith in the new attempts to resolve the country's constitutional problem.

Thomas C. Graham, 48, who had been president and chief operating officer of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation since Jan. 1, 1974, will become chief executive officer of the company on Sept. 1, succeeding Roscoe G. Haynie, 65, who will retire on that date.

HARTFORD, Aug. 14 The City of Hartford has filed suit in Federal District Court here against the Department of Housing and Urban Development to prevent the department from granting more than $4million in Federal funds to seven relatively affluent Hartford suburbs, it was announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 14 The Acting Orange County Attorney, James Tamsen, in a report to County Executive Louis V. Mills, has determined that the county has a legal obligation to pay welfare costs, and that failure to do so could result in court action.
LONDON, Aug. 14 Citizens here are being urged to "buy British," but to the dismay of the Government and industry, they're "buying Japanese" instead.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 Words and music. Like man and woman, they need each other, but their relationship is fluid and often uneasy. Any composer who uses words knows the problem: They are essentially meaningless in a strictly musical sense and yet they can provide him with a strong framework on which to hang ideas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) California, Washington State and Hawaii have been billed a total of slightly more than $1million for losses due to their administration of the Federal food stamp program, the Agriculture Department said today.
Support continued to grow yesterday for a special tax in the 12-county region served by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to stabilize bus, subway and commuter train fares.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 (AP) Argentina's army commander and nine other top generals met for seven hours today and declared that the army would not intervene in the nation's political affairs.
LUANDA, Angola, Friday, Aug. 15 Portugal resumed administrative control of embattled Angola last night in a move that effectively sealed the collapse of the transitional government here.

HIGHLANDS, Aug. 14 Gertrude Ederle, the first woman to swim the English Channel, dedicated a park adjacent to the Highlands Bridge in her own name today as part of a series of celebrations honoring this borough's 75th anniversary.

KINGSTON, N.Y. Looking at the piles of lumber and painted tires, the half-finished platforms and upright posts, there was no way to tell what was being built.
Samuel A. Dachowitz, the personal accountant for Bernard Bergman, pleaded guilty to Federal fraud charges yesterday and disclosed that he was cooperating with the prosecution in the Bergman case.

BONDURANT, Iowa, Aug 14 A former grain inspector who has pleaded guilty to a bribery indictment described at a Senate field hearing today allegedly corrupt practices in the grading and handling of grain to be exported from the Port of New Orleans by two large grain corporations.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 14 Bill Collins of Brae Burn captured the $25,000 Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today over the par-72, 7,101-yard Meadow Brook Club course with a two-over-par 218. Collins, who won the Buick open on the P.G.A. tour in 1962, had a 75 today after rounds of 70 and 73.

In a 1975 comic book, "Power Man," the black villain, Big Ben, is beating up the black hero, Luke Cage. Cage is face down on the ground and Big Ben kicks him in the side. "OOMMPH!" says Cage. Then Big Ben stomps on Cage's head with "six inches of iron filled . . . HEEL.!"
MIAMI, Aug. 14 The Federal Bureau of Investigation reopened today its inquiry into the background of a CubanAmerican who was appointed last week director of the Cuban refugee program.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (UPI) Detroit's 700 sanitation truck drivers made good their strike threat tonight, walking off the job and leaving city residents to face a pileup of garbage.

Four major banks have joined with four city-employe pension funds to buy $65-million in bonds and notes issued by a state-created agency that finances construction of middle-in come housing here, city officials reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Israel has agreed, as part of an accord with Egypt now in the final stage of negotiation, to return the oilfield at Abu Rudeis to the Egyptians.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (UPI) Britain reported today that its over-all balance-of-payments deficit more than quadrupled in July.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (UPI) Gov. Milton J. Shapp, a possible contender for the 1976 Presidential nomination, has been asked to appear before a Federal grand jury here, presumably to answer questions concerning an alleged unreported $20,000 campaign contribution.
One hundred thousand safety brochures were placed on Long Island Rail Road passenger seats yesterday to tell commuters how to stop a train if a passenger gets caught in a car's doors.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 The State Department of Agriculture and Markets has suspended the milk dealer's license of Beverly Farms, Inc., of Mount Vernon, a small independent milk dealer, for technical violations of its regulations.
William E. Boyland, president of the City Tax Commission and head of the Real Property Assessment Department from 1949 to 1966, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx.

The financial statements that are required of state officials who earn more than $30,000 a year, or who are in policy making positions, must detail all assets and sources and amounts of income, but only the sources will be open to public scrutiny, the chairman of the Board of Public Disclosure said yesterday.

The LTV Corporation said yesterday that the exercise price of its common stock purchase warrants expiring Jan. 15 1978, had been reduced to $56.98 a share from $57.46. As a result, the number of shares that can be purchased on exercise of each warrant has been increased to 2.0183 shares from 2.0014.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 14 After almost two years of huge petrodollar inflows accompanied, by massive internal development programs and expensive external investments, Iran is borrowing money also on a grand scale.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 14 Like an echo of the opening day of last week's Professional Golfers' Association championship, which they were calling the "Who's He? Open," a club pro shot 64 today and a tour freshman added a 65 to dominate the first round of the $200,000 Greater Hartford open.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 A major battle is brewing between Congress and President Ford over the long-standing Presidential practice of making executive agreements with other nations that are not subject to Congressional approval, but that must be transmitted to Congress.

PEKING, Aug. 14 (Agence France-Presse) Northern China's autumn harvest is being threatened by drought while crops in central and southern China have been endangered by flooding, according to a report today in the Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 14 Two policemen and three residents of a Mexican-American neighborhood in this Southern California city were shot in a bitter exchange of gunfire before dawn today.

War, the basically black septet that is the headline act in a show at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, has been around for a long time. The core of the group goes back to 1962, but the present configuration came together as the back-up band for Eric Hurdon in 1969 and 1970.

The New York Sets have lost only nine of their 42 World Team Tennis matches this season. But with two remaining on the schedule they are still in danger of finishing second in the Eastern Division behind the Pittsburgh Triangles.

BONN, Aug. 14 Lieut. Col. Jerzy Pawlowski, the Polish fencing champion, has been in jail in Warsaw for more than two and a half months, apparently under suspicion of espionage, according to reports reaching here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 At a time of mounting crisis in Portugal, Secretary of State Kissinger today gave the strongest United States support to date to the forces who oppose the Communists in that country.

Barnaby Bye is a Long Island group by way of Canada (where it records) that has made occasional appearances in Manhattan without achieving much of a breakthrough. Paul Gaynor, board chairman and president of Gaynor Co., inc., a diversified communications concern whose companies include Gaynor Ducas, an advertising agency, and PR Associates, Inc., an public-relations company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. BANGKOK, Thailand Thailand has reached an agreement with three international relief organizations under which they are taking over most of the responsibility for the Indochinese refugees who continue to enter this country. The move is apparently dessigned to ease some of the tensions the refugees have created between Thailand and her Communist neighbors.

Dr. Camp led a University of California expedition in 1947-48 to study fossil remains of "manapes" found at Sterkfontein, near Johannesburg, South Africa, by Dr. Robert Broom, who decided the bones belonged to a new genus that he called Pleisanthropus.
Nancy Bryan Cassiday and Henry Luce 3d, vice president and director of corporate planning of Time Inc., were married in the chapel at the Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary yesterday afternoon.

TORONTO, Aug. 15 (AP) Ilie Nastase of Rumania outplayed sixth-seeded John Alexander of Australia 6-3, 6-7, 6-2 today to advance to the semifinals of the Canadian open tennis championships.

LONDON, Aug. 15 Six members of the Provisional I.R.A. were sentenced to life imprisonment today for mounting bomb attacks that took 21 lives and injured more than 180 persons in Birmingham last November.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 15 The New York Giants will play their second preseason football game tomorrow night against the San Diego Chargers.
Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation voted yesterday to cut the quarterly dividend to 25 cents from 50 cents. It is payable Sept. 22 to stockholders of record Aug. 26.

New York City's recently enacted bond transfer tax went into effect yesterday and investment officials said it added one more element of uncertainty to Wall Street houses already worried by rising interest rates and falling stock-market volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) Two competing routes for bringing Alaskan natural gas to the "lower 48" states offer the nation about the same economic benefit, the Interior Department said today.

Yet another (and unlikely) pop music location opened up Thursday evening the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Peter Allen, the singer and pianist, was the performer and the audience was requested to arrive "semiformal." Setting the tone for the evening, Mr. Allen observed from the stage that "today it means jeans without holes."

New York Stock Exchange members voted here yesterday to add four new directors to the exchange's 20man board, all from Big Board firms. The exchange's board of directors, which has 10 members representing Wall Street and 10 representing the public, would thus have the balance of power in the hands of stockbrokers.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Inflation in Britain reached a record annual rate of 26.3 per cent in July. But the rate of increase is slowing down, according to Government figures issued today.

The Ethyl Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing the domestic price of all standard mixes of antiknock compounds by one-half of 1 cent a pound, effective with shipments on Sept. 19. Ethyl said the increases were the result of higher lead metal costs.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Aug. 15 The General Accounting Office, charging that the Grumman Aerospace Corporation exhibited "serious weaknesses" in the management of spare parts for its controversial F-14 fighter plane program, says that there is a, $28-million discrepancy in the defense contractor's books.

The theory that Government has an obligation to limit campaign contributions and campaign spending in the interest of honest elections got an important judicial lift yesterday when the United States Court of Appeals upheld the 1974 campaign finance law.

Representative Thomas J. Downey, who has been investigating the military's drug experiments with humans, said yesterday that there appeared to have been a deliberate effort to cover up the death of a patient in an Army-sponsored experiment at the New York State Psychiatric Institute 22 years ago.

COPENHAGEN Very few people including the Danes are aware that the largest overseas empire remaining in the world is Denmark's, thanks to the fact that this country controls not only the Faeroes archipelago but also the greatest island on earth, Greenland, which comprises 839,781 square miles.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 15 Hubert Green, who has been in a costly slump since winning four events last year, "felt like" Jack Nicklaus and Johnny Miller today in shooting a 65, to tie Don Bies for the lead in the second round of the Greater Hartford open golf tournament.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 15 (AP) Forty-four professors, students and employes of Chile's largest university have been arrested for "Marxist activities" the military Government announced today.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP) Ken Anderson tossed two touchdown passes and a rookie, Gary Sheide, threw one as the Cincinnati Bengals defeated the Buffalo Bills, 38-28, tonight in a National Football League exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld today all major provisions of the Federal election law that the Watergate scandals propelled through Congress last year.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 Martin H. Gerry, acting director of the Office of Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, conceded today that his office "has been taking too much time" in processing complaints of segregation against Northern school districts.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 15 Abraham Weissman, District Attorney of Orange County, died this morning in Methodist Hospital, Houston. He was 64 years old.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 Since he took up conducting as a steady occupation, Pierre Boulez has not composed much music that anyone knows about. But Mr. Boulez still must he regarded as one of the composing craft's best-equipped living members, and the music world is justifiably aroused by the prospect of any new works by the 50year-old Frenchman.

When the exterior wood siding around the outside of a house starts to split or rot out in sections, repairs should be made promptly to keep moisture and insects from entering, and to keep the condition from getting worse (defects such as this allow water to enter and cause paint to peel from surrounding boards, as well as possibly hastening the swelling and eventual rotting of other sections).

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 19 President Ford warned today that he would be compelled to accelerate the nuclear-arms race if the Soviet Union did not agree to a curb on strategic weapons this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The automobile industry declined today to take a position on whether it is being injured by foreign cars allegedly sold in this country at "dumping" prices.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 21 (UPI) The Government announced today that Indian news organizations need no longer submit their articles to precensorship. which they had been required to do since a national emergency was declared on June 26.

ATHENS, Aug. 21-The principle defense counsel asked for leniency today as arguments ended in the trial of 20 former Greek officers accused of high treason and insurrection for plotting the 1967 coup.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 21 China made her debut in international rowing competition today, in the opening rounds of the world championships. The Chinese team, which consists of six men and six women, finished last in three of the four races in which it competed.
Prices finished down sharply on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in another day of moderate trading. In the overthe-counter market, prices closed mixed as volume fell.

Cooper, Assistant Secretary for International Affairs, told newsmen in Washington yesterday after meeting with representatives of 16 American concerns that deal in gold. Mayor Beame and members of the Board of Estimate met for almost two hours yesterday in their first joint meeting since the board met without the Mayor last Tuesday to discuss what one member described at the time as the Mayor's "drift" during the city's fiscal crisis.

Governor Carey and Mayor Beame were told by the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday that some form of state supervision of the city's borrowing and management functions must be established if the city is to avert a default.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 United Nations officials announced today that Portugal had asked increased support from the world body for the evacuation of refugees from Angola.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 A sharp deterioration of Mexico's balance-of-payments situation has provoked an unusual open debate over the pros and cons of devaluing the Mexican peso against the dollar.

PRAGUE, Aug. 10 The Jews of Prague believe that Judaism, which for seven centuries was a powerful factor in the intellectual, artistic and architectural flowering of this city, will be dead in Czechoslovakia within 20 years. But it will leave an almost indelible legacy behind.

In a statement issued early yesterday, members of the Minnesota Vikings demanded the resignation of Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association. Ed White, the Vikings' player representative, made the announcement.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 The Kremlin, in its first substantial reaction to last week's coup in Bangladesh, hinted today that it was concerned that the overthrow of Sheik Mujibur Rahman might swing her away from the Soviet Union and toward China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Eugene J. McCarthy's Presidential campaign chairman pro tested today the Federal Election Commission's reported plan to audit his campaign financial records, arguing that an audit was not proper snce Mr. McCarthy is an independent and ineligible for Federal election funds.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 22 Recent laboratory experi- ments have lent support to the theory that global epidemics of influenza occur after an entirely new flu virus is created by the natural recombining of fragments of virus strains from human beings, other mammals and birds.

CLARKSBORO, Aug. 22 After several delays, Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, Bergen County Democrat, is scheduled to go on trial next Wednesday in the former schoolhouse of this rural community on charges of trespassing on the Rosario Sorbello Sons farm.
Marian Storm, an author, journalist and naturalist, died Wednesday in the Mexican American Hospital in Guadalajara, Mexico, where she lived. Her age was 83.

Betty Sanders, a guitarist and folk singer who gave many performances here, died of cancer Thursday evening in the Moffitt Hospital of the University of California Medical School in San Francisco. She was 53 years old.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Aug. 22 (AP) The University of Alabama filed a lawsuit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association today, challenging the legality of rules recently adopted that limit the size of football squads.
In an effort to lift Switzerland out of its recession, the Swiss National Bank announced yesterday a cut of one-half of one percentage point in the country's key lending rate.

Four days before the shareholders of the Copper Range Company were to meet to consider a merger with Amax, Inc., the Department of Justice informed the companies yesterday that it opposed the merger.

The New York Stock Exchange has reported that short interest decreased to 22,801,887 shares on Aug. 15 from 25,385,181 shares on July 15. It was the lowest since January 15, when short interest was 20,813,260 shares.

If this useful commodity is lacking, plan for a unique garden feature that combines sound, movement, reflection and sculpture all in one. From birdbath to pond, water is a relatively low-maintenance addition worth investigating.

Among those I asked to speculate about the condition of this region twenty years hence were Premier Yitzhak Rabin, Defense Minister Shimort heres and 'General Ariel Sharon, who commanded the African invasion and encirclement of the Egyptian army that wound up the stalemated Mideast war of October, 1973.

HACKENSACK After a highly successful summer season of free outdoor concerts, the North Jersey Cultural Council is preparing a busy autumn program. All told, four pop and folk groups and the Eric Bass Puppet Theater gave a total of 57 performances in 13 Bergen and Passaic County communities this summer.

WASHINGTON About a year and a half ago, Congress established the National Center on Child Abuse and Neglect. This month the center finally got its first director, a New York City lawyer who is a specialist in the problems of children.

"Jaws" fever is turning into an epidemic. In its first two months of release in the United States and Canada, "Jaws" has already grossed $90-million, surpassing the box-office records of "The Sting" and "The Exorcist," and by the end of the year it could best "The Godfather" as the top-grossing film in movie history.

"What kind of writing do you do?" the editor asked curiously.

HILLSDALE Garage sales have created a new class of specialists: people who will price items for homeowners, advise them on the best selling techniques to use and even conduct the sales for them.

EAST HAMPTON When the amateur gardener drops zucchini seeds into the soil, he usually gets more than he bargains for Zucchini tend to grow faster than they can be harvested and left unpicked can double in size almost overnight. After several weeks, they grow to the size of baseball bats, too big for even the neighbors to accept.

The 75 freshmen Democrats in the House of Representatives began the year with high hopes that, with their help, Congress would seize the initiative from the President. Eight months later, when Congress went into its August recess, many of them left feeling deeply frustrated. Neither feeling was totally warranted. Both grew out of perhaps unrealistic expectations about the ability of Congress to govern on its own.

Benita Eisler is a woman, who gave up a meditative, scholarly career for a public, demanding and energetic life without losing anything of herself in the bargain. Although the Swing Era which made Benny Goodman famous ended in the early forties, Benny Goodman still goes on. He gave up leading a band in the early fifties. A year before the Presidential election campaign goes into high gear, the political outlook is exceptionally obscure. Having acquired office by unprecedented means, President Ford has done well to lift the shadows of scandal from the Republican party and reorient an Administration so overwhelmingly re-elected only three years ago, then so grievously stricken. But his hold upon his party is more tenuous than would normally be true of an incumbent President.

In landscape planting, I like to think small! Small, modest-sized plots can easily be transformed into unique, most attractive, displays by using the dwarf, slow-growing evergreens. Coquillette performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Powell of Cambridge, Mass., brother-in-law and sister of the bride.

Ann Miller's three-room apartment has wide oak floorboards, a 12-foothigh beamed ceiling and a view of woods from every side. The wind, the rain and racoons in the garbage account for most of the noise she hears. There isn't another apartment for miles. Inside and out, the flavor of the place seems more that of New Hampshire or Vermont than that of Connecticut.

On opposite sides of the nation last week, two of America's greatest cities were in crisis. BOGOTA, Aug. 25 (UPI) A municipal newspaper-collection program, started in Ridgewood two years ago, has spread to 23 other New Jersey communities, officials said today. It is underway in such communities as Bergenfield, Bloomfield, Clifton, Englewood, Hackensack, Hopewell, Union City and West Orange.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) United States total reserve assets fell $158-million in July to $16.08-billion, the Treasury Department reported today.

The association said that cumulative production for the year rose to 78,593,000 tons as of Aug. 23. In a move designed to encourage economic growth and attract jobs to the state, Governor Carey announced the appointment of a 24-member Economic Development Board and the creation of the post of Industrial Coordinator to help industry in its dealings with the state.
Mobil, third largest among American oil companies, has demonstrated a commendable sense of public responsibility in its letter opposing President Ford's plan to decontrol all domestic oil prices.
CHICAGO, Aug, 25 (UPI) Bargainers for National Football League players and club owners agreed on short notice, to resume negotiations tonight as a result of a meeting of player representatives.

NEWARK, Aug. 25 (UPI) A Rutgers university student and two friends were arraigned today on charges of making a crude pipe-bomb and mailing it to the student's grandmother, allegedly to inherit her life insurance policy.

KIAMESHA LAKE. N.Y., Aug. 25--Triumphs by Vic Seixas and Hugh Stewart today enabled the United States to eliminate Canada, 2-0, and advance to the semifinals of the annual Stevens Cup international team Tennis tournament at the Concord Hotel.

Mayor Beame failed to complete yesterday the three-year budget plan that he hopes will convince investors that they should lend more money to New York City, irritating state and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials who waited all day to receive the Mayor's proposal.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 25 Kenneth W. Kahler, a 25-yearold unemployed sporting-goods salesman from Seaford, surrendered to the Nassau County police today after a three-month investigation of acid attacks on seven teen-age girls.

Mayor Beame failed to complete yesterday the three-year budget plan that he hopes will convince investors that they should lend more money to New York City, irritating state and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials who waited all day to receive the Mayor's proposal.
The Mobil Oil Corporation's call for gradual decontrol of domestic oil prices was dismissed yesterday by other major petroleum producers as unrealistic at this time.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 25 (AP) Belgian intelligence officials are checking persistent reports that the Soviet Union has sent political funds to Portugal through a shipping concern it runs in Antwerp.

Dr. Rupert B. Vance, a former president of the American Sociological Society and the Population Association of America and emeritus holder of the Kenan Professorship at the University of North Carolina, died yesterday in the North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, where he lived. He was 76 years old.

Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York asked the State Insurance Department yesterday for permission to raise premiums for about four million of its hospitalization subscribers by an average of 23 per cent on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) The Soviet Union, bowing to pressure from American maritime unions, is prepared to pay higher freight rates and give preference to American vessels in shipping grain to Russia, informed Administration sources said today.

The bankroll battle for the services of 27-year-old Bobby Orr continued yesterday in Toronto, where the star defenseman met with officials of the Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association. Orr's contract with the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, believed to be for $225,000 a year, runs out after next season and his skills may then go to the highest bidder.
LEIRIA, Portugal, Aug. 25 Almost any public gathering in Portugal today a country fair, a political rally, a religious parade risks turning into a brutal anti-Communist demonstration.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) Vitas Gerulaitis broke Tom Okker's service three times in men's singles and carried the Pittsburgh Triangles to a 21-14 victory over the San Francisco Golden Gaters tonight in the third and deciding match of the World Team Tennis championship playoffs.

Governor Lucey of Wisconsin has directed his Attorney General, Bronson La Follette, to bring a suit of unusual political importance against the Democratic National Committee. Since 1902 Wisconsin has had "open" primaries in which Democrats have been free to cross over and help choose nominees of the Republican party; Republicans have been just as free to return the compliment. No declaration or formal party affiliation of any sort is required.

The Largest amount of a single day's trading in a commodity in the 103-year-old history of the New York Mercantile Exchange was achieved yesterday when 9,068 contracts in Maine potatoes changed hands. The previous record was 8,803 contracts, also in potatoes, which was reached April 23, 1968.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 25 The "quiet man" of auto racing was buried today and Mark Donohue's funeral, fittingly, was simple.

Governor Carey has reportedly told Albert Shanker, presdent of the teachers' union, that "when the crunch comes," the state may be able to come up with additional money to meet some of the teachers' contract demands.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

The bridge writer or teacher who cites a rule of thumb embodying the words "always", or "never" can usually be assumed to mean "almost always" or "hardly ever." Nevertheless there are some such rules that come close to 100 per cent.
Ladislav J. Skaloud, chief of protocol of Pan American World Airways, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 62 years old.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 25 Foreign ministers and other officials from nearly 80 nonaligned nations opened a five-day conference today with several Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization pressing for a formal decision to seek Israel's expulsion from the United Nations.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the Over-theCounter market rose yesterday in light trading. "Bargain-buying" continued to be the chief reason for the advances.
ATHENS, Aug. 25 The Greek Cabinet decided unanimously today to spare the lives of the three men sentenced to death Saturday for their parts in the coup of 1967.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) Seventy-six per cent of the teachers in the Boston public school system voluntarily attended workshops today to acquaint them with conditions in desegregated classes.
WHO DOES the major part of the work in poor countries? Women do. Yet they are probably the most underrated economic resource in "resource-poor" third world countries.

CHICAGO, Aug, 25 President Ford aroused an audience of hardware merchants here today by declaring, that he would "get the Federal Government out of your business, out of your lives, out of your pockets and out of your hair."

A 53-year-old Corsican accused of being the principal figure of an international drug ring was arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court and ordered held in $2.5-million bail yesterday after having been flown here from Africa in the company of Federal drug-enforcement agents.
Aided by continued heavy trading, stockbrokers chalked up a strong second quarter this year, the second in a row, New York Stock Exchange figures showed yesterday.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 25 The ordering of social structures is of far greater importance in combating world hunger than economic development or "the green revolution," a nutrition specialist of the World Health Organization said here today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) The final report of an 8 -year study confirms earlier findings that the aggressive, hard-driving individual is much more likely to have a heart attack than a relaxed person.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 President Ford plans to ask Congress soon for temporary authority to continue through next winter Federal controls over deliveries and prices of propane, the bottled gas widely used to heat rural homes.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25 The American tuna fleet, parading home today in a protest demonstration, threatened a whole sale desertion to foreign flag registry unless the Government protected it from growing "poaching" in a conservation zone of the eastern Pacific.

Halfway into their exhibition season, the Giants finally have found something in common with the Oakland Raiders and Miami Dolphins: all three still are unbeaten, the last among the 26 National Football League teams.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25 The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved two consumer-protection bills to day, ending a year-long struggle over how the new code is to be enforced.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25 (UPI) President Ford said today he regretted that "there has been some misunderstanding" regarding comments by his wife, Betty, on premarital sex and their personal lives.
The Harris Poll said yesterday that President Ford would decisively beat former Gov. Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination if the election were held now.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 A Senate subcommittee has quietly begun an inquiry to determine whether the American banking system is in a position of potential vulnerability because of the recent shift in wealth to the countries that produce and export oil.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 The United States auto industry today, reported new car sales in the Aug. 11-20 period were off 6.2 per cent from last year but said the selling rate was the highest for the model year.

UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 25 The annual Philadelphia Folk Festival, which was held for the 14th time last weekend on the rolling fields of Pool's Farm near Schwenksville, northwest of Philadelphia, made several moves this year in what may be indicative of future directions.

Bach came back to an old accustomed spot at 104.3 on the FM radio dial at 8 P.M. yesterday. WNCN celebrated its resurrection after a rocky nine months under the call letters WQIV, which made its debut last October with the recording "Roll Over Beethoven."

Machine tool orders in the United States fell 19 per cent last month below the June level to $96.2-million and were 61 per cent below the $247.4-million in the similar 1974 period, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.
LISBON, Tuesday, Aug. 26 As a deadline set for his ouster passed, Premier Vasco Goncalves continued to hold onto office and maneuver for support last night.

The F. W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest variety chain, made a sharp upturn in second-quarter profits surging 66.2 per cent on a sales gain of 9.8 per cent over a year ago, the company's report disclosed yesterday. The S. S. Kresge Co., its nearest competitor had a 32 per cent profit gain in its recent report for the l2 weeks to July 30.

The Fifth Avenue Association has appealed to its midtown business members to cooperate in what it termed the "sanitation crisis" by clearing away the litter in front of their establishments when the city failed to do so.
The nation's 200 leading consumer magazines reported a 3 per cent decline in total paid circulation in the first six months of 1975, according to a study released by the Gallagher report yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 25 With an interim accord with Israel apparently in sight, the Government of President Anwar el-Sadat faces the delicate problem of selling it to the Egyptian people and the Arab world.

Steel production for the week ended Aug. 23 rose 2.5 per cent above that of the previous week, according to weekly as steel production statistics released in Washington yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Kaunda of Zambia to force Rhodesian leaders, black and white, to find a new solution to their racial differences. But as the talks adjourned at midnight, it appeared that they might break down.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Philip W. Buchen, council to President Ford, told a Federal court today that he planned to comply with a Senate Intelligence Committee's subpoena for certain documents compiled under the Nixon Administration, unless the court ruled that he could not do so.

Orison S. Marden, a Wall Street corporate lawyer who was a founder of the New York Legal Aid Society and of the International Legal Aid Organization, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 11 Stonehnuse Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 The Argentine Minister of the Economy, Antonio Cafiero, announced tonight a new antirecessionary economic policy aimed at stemming growing unemployment.
