Negotiators for the city and its firemen said yesterday that they planned to make a new effort later this week to resolve contract issues still in dispute and to conclude their long delayed 1974-76 agreement.

The Erick Hawkins Dance Company will give two performances of works on Sept. 11 and Sept. 13 at Carnegie Hall. All four works will be given on each evening.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 25 Virginia Wade needed more than first-aid spray to protect herself against Chris Event today in the final of the Medi-Quik women's tennis classic at the Westchester Country Club.

CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 22 Usually, it's quiet enough in this somnolent little city to-hear a dime drop in a parking meter half a block away. Usually Yesterday, there was a bomb.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 25 (AP) Gen. Faruk Gurler, military chief of staff in the final phase of Turkey's stormy marrtial law years, died Saturday of cancer at an Ankara military hospital. He was 62 years old.

DECATUR, Miss., Aug 25 (UPI) A State Treasury candidate, Doxey Fisher, and a legislative candidate, Danny Keyes, who were to have been in run-off elections tomorrow died last night when their small plane crashed in a thunderstorm.

A special membership meeting of the Actors Equity Association filled with boos, hisses, applause and catcalls during heated debate voted overwhelmingly yesterday against a new actors' code that had come under fire as a threat to the survival of Off Off Broadway as 'a noncommercial development movement.
WASHINGTON, Aug 25 (AP)--Five more women plan to be ordained to the Episcopal priesthood in defiance of their church's hierarchy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 Canada, which last month blocked the Palestine Liberation Organization from attending a United Nations conference scheduled to be held in Toronto, tacitly agreed today to the group's attendance at a meeting to be held in Vancouver next summer.

Isabelle Strong Jones, widow of the Rev. Dr. William H. Jones, a Baptist minister at churches in Hammond, Ind., Oshkosh, Wis., Chicago and Portland, Me., died yesterday at the home of their daughter, Mrs. Gregory M. Chorlian, 188 Wilmot Road, New Rochelle, N.Y.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25--Undeterred by slumping oil revenues, the Iranian Government is pressing ahead with creation of vast naval facilities at Chahbahar, on the southeastern coast, according to Western business and diplomatic informants.

INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 25 Roger Ginsberg of Muttontown eliminated Jimmy Wright, the defending champion today in the opening round of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship. Ginsberg won, 6 and 4, over the 6,680-yard Inwood layout, Wright's home course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The Interstate Commerce Commission put its support today behind the United States Railway Association's plan for Conrail, a new Governmentsponsored system, to take over most of the lines of the Penn Central and five other bankrupt railroads.

Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York asked the State Insurance Department, yesterday for permission to raise premiums for about four million of its hospitalization subscribers by an average of 23 per cent on Jan. 1.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 The commander of the Argentine Army asserted today that the military still supported civilian constitutional government.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) A question raised by jurors during today's deliberations in the Kent State University trial focused on Gov. James A. Rhodes's role in the 1970 shootings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 This city's legislature laid the legal foundation today to alter substantially the City Charter as the political reverberations of last week's three-day police and firemen's strike continued here.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 26 (UPI)--Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger headed an American delegation that opened a two-day meeting here today with South Korean officials. The meeting an annual one, was designed to work out measures to assure security in the post-Indochina war era.

Repealing the Federal Government in all fields except national defense seems to be the platform on which President Ford has decided to run next year. WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The American Postal Workers Union announced today that its membership had ratified a new threeyear contract with the United States Postal Service.

VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Aug. 26 An extraordinary diplomatic effort was made here yesterday by Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to force Rhodesian leaders, black and white, to find a new solution to their racial differences.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 25 (AP) A march by 300 striking coal miners became violent today after the police prevented them from illegally entering a one-way street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a set of proposed regulations aimed at stripping away some of the mystery obscuring who owns or controls American business.

EAST ORANGE, Aug. 25 (AP) The relationship of former State Senator Ralph C. DeRose's law firm with an engineering concern is being terminated, but Governor Byrne declined to comment today on whether he still wanted Mr. DeRose ousted from the WaterFront Commission of New York Harbor.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 25 The Pathet Lao's take-over of Vientiane, extending its rule throughout Laos, followed weeks of elaborate preparations for the formal ceremo nies, according to reports reach ing Bangkok from diplomatic circles.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 25 Refugees from Portuguese (Timor said today that bodies had littered the streets in Dili, the capital.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 25 (AP) More than 150 young women in black and colored robes swirled to a voodoo dance on a moonlit outdoor stage here at the opening of the first World Congress of Sorcery.

The nation's chain-store organizations in July chalked up a gain in sales volume of 7.7 per cent, compared with July ol 1974, according to a survey by Chain Store Age magazine. The increase last month was slightly below a gain of 7.9 per cent in June. It compared with a rise of 8.4 per cent in May and no gain in April.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday announced an increase in fares, effective Monday, averaging 23 per cent on the Long Island Rail Road and 25 per cent on the Penn Central's Hudson and Harlem commuter lines.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25 Hank Webb and Mike Vail, both of whom spent part of the season in the minors with New York's farm club at Tidewater, held center stage tonight as the Mets defeated the San Diego Padres, 4-0, in the opener of a threegame series.

The 106 players in the New York Philharmonic plus members of the management staff are leaving today for an 18-concert tour of Europe. The orchestra will give its first concert at the Edinburgh Festival on Thursday night. Later it will perform in London, Ghent, Brussels, Lucerne, Berlin, Bonn, Frankfurt, Stuttgart, Mannheim, Munich and Paris. The final concert will be given in Chartres Cathedral on Sept. 19.

NEWARK, Aug. 25 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson urged the Legislature tonight to restore $9-million in state mass-transit subsidies needed to avert proposed higher bus and commuter train fares and curtailed bus service in the state.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 27-Two North Korean solders, armed with AK-47 rifles, intruded into southern part of the Demilitarized Zone yesterday and kidnapped a farmer, the United Nations Command announced this morning.
More than one-third of the market value of the Copper Range Company's stock was wiped away yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

With prospects for the Broadway theater the brightest in more than 20 years, the Shubert Organization is seeking to buy more theaters here if it can get permission from the Department of Justice.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)-The police arrested 10 persons today after a series of clashes between blacks and whites that began last night at the Maverick Square Housing project in the East Boston section.

In a move to place its merchandising emphasis on soft lines, the W.T. Grant Company announced yesterday that it would phase out its major appliance product line from all its stores commencing Sept. 15.

HACKENSACK, Aug. 26 Mrs. Jesse Bercher is one of the 12,500 Bergen County commuters who ride the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad to work in Manhattan every day and, like the others, she faces a fare increase of 32 to 52 per cent on Oct. 1.

The Commerce Department reported yesterday that although increased oil imports eroded the nation's foreign trade surplus in July, the account remained in surplus by nearly $1-billion for the month. TOKYO, Aug. 26 A major maker of paper, chemicals and synthetic fibers Kohjin, Ltd. tottered on the brink of collapse today, threatening to become perhaps Japan's biggest postwar business failure.

A half-century after John Thomas Scopes was convicted of the misdemeanor of teaching evolution in a Tennessee high school, two courts in that state have decided at long last that the subject is not realty one for legislators.

DETROIT, Aug. 26-Th grand jury investigation into the disappearance of James R Hoffa will get under way next week with 70 witnesses scheduled to testify. At least four of the witnesses have reportedly been subpoenaed.

BONN, Aug. 26 (Reuters) The West German Government, which is putting the final touches on a $2.3-billion program to stimulate the economy said today it saw no sign of an end to the nation's prolonged recession.

A diversity of worlds assembled yesterday at Temple Emanu-El to pay a last tribute to Charles H. Revson, chairman of the board of Revlon, Inc., who died Sunday of cancer at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 26 Randy Tate, another of the young pitchers the New York Mets have been displaying lately, posted his first victory in a month tonight as he beat the San Diego Padres, 7-2.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 26 Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said today that "remarkable progress" had been made in the last two days toward the conclusion of a new Sinai agreement with Egypt under Secretary of State Kissinger's auspices.
The typical New York City family saved 75 cents 1 per cent on its food bill last week, as food prices, led by the prices of beef and potatoes, dropped substantially in the city's markets.
A security van, reportedly containing $174,000 in cash, was hijacked by two gunmen yesterday as its driver approached an intersection in Elmhurst, Queens.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 26 (UPI) The United States dollar fell today against all European currencies except the lire. The dollar had opened higher after steady increases over the weekend and yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) United Airlines said today it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board later this week to impose a 4.2 per cent surcharge on all passenger fares to offset rising fuel prices caused by deregulation of domestic oil.
NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug., 26 The men's world rowing championships opened today and the biggest surprises occurred in the heats for eights, the most prestigious event of the regatta.

AGUILARES, El Salvador Luis Garcia wandered back from his tiny cornfield to the shack where his wife was preparing a lunch of salted tortillas. Last year's corn crop has been eaten and this year's is still two months away. The money earned cutting cane on the nearby plantations has also been spent and the Garcias are going hungry.
The name of the game in Forest Hills for the last 60 years has been tennis, and the quiet Queens town-in-a-city is putting out its nets today for the 12-day United States Open Championship.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 26 The nonaligned bloc appeared to drift closer to the Communist nations today as its conference of foreign ministers voted to give full membership to North Vietnam and North Korea.

The Commerce Department reported yesterday that although increased oil imports eroded the nation's foreign trade surplus in July, the account remained in surplus by nearly $1-billion for the month. The unexpected surplus the fourth largest ever recorded comes at a time when virtually all of the nation's leading competitors are suffering severe declines in their own trade balances.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 26 Karen Gilder's Happy Days accomplished a rare equestrian feat today by winning the local working hunter championship without the benefit of a blue ribbon at the Catamount Hunt horse show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 When Secretary of State Kissinger addresses the United Nations General Assembly next week, his aides expect him to take a more conciliatory stand toward demands from developing nations for a greater share of the world's wealth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26-New York City appeared today to hold a decisive edge over Los Angeles in a long and close competition for the Democratic party's 1976 convention.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 26 (UPI) The Finance Minister of the Arab Sheikdom of Kuwait predicted today that, as a result of the declining United States dollar value, oil prices, will jump 10 per cent when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets next month.
Cream that has been pasteurized by a new method that extends the cream's shelf life in the store at only slight loss in taste has been introduced in food stores here.

A telegram from Mr. and Mrs. Allen Crosby with 10 Hallelujahs in a row, no spaces and no commas, hangs on a door at the sixth-floor offices of radio station WQIVFM at 2 West 45th Street.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Massachusetts is within days of defaulting on housing notes and bonds because of interim state budget cuts, a state official said today. However, another state official said that the alleged crisis was the result of an apparent oversight.

ANN ARBOR, Mich. With disdain for editorial mortality and other deadlines, the Middle English Dictionary project here has been taking forever to get to Z. But the Mellon Foundation has suddenly given the project $950,000 and a deadline only seven years away.

In the brown appointment book Manager Billy Martin keeps on his desk, the one in which he lists his starting pitcher for each game, the name Hunter appears every fourth day for the rest of the season. The Yankees can thank goodness or Charles O. Finley, who most people will say is anything but goodness for Catfish Hunter.

The music business is hardly known for justice otherwise Steve Goodman would be reaping just rewards for what he is, an acute, witty and truthful observer of the contemporary world, disguised as a folk singer.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 26 Eleven years after high school graduation, 80 per cent of Americans in a survey say they find their jobs rewarding.
SAN FRANCISCO "I thought I was joining the convent for the glory of God," Sister Catherine Pinkerton said of her entrance into the sisterhood 32 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 New York City appeared today to hold a decisive edge over Los Angeles in a long and close competition for the Democratic party's 1976 convention.
John Stossel has been relieved of his duties as consumer reporter for WCBS-TV.

The works of film makers from France, Germany, Britain, Hungary, Senegal, Switzerland and the United States as well as a series of directors' symposiums make up the 13th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, to run from Sept. 26 through Oct. 12.
Rain delays at other tournaments forced major scheduling revisions in the start of the United States Open tennis championships today at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

Darryll Reese of the New York Pioneer Club won the open three-mile run in 14 minutes 48.8 seconds today in the final meet of the Road Runners Club of New York summer program at Queensboro Community College, Bayside, Queens.

LAUDERHILL, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) The Professional Golfers' Association Tournament Player Championship, to be held in conjunction with the Jackie Gleason-Inverrary Classic next year, will offer a total purse of $300,000, officials said today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 26 (UPI) Severe storms that lashed western Michigan over the weekend caused more than $4-million damage to harvestready peach, plum and pear crops, agriculture officials reported today.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 In the first round of diplomatic sparring and posturing after the coup d'etat in Bangladesh, the Soviet Union and India took quite a negative view of the change in leadership. Now, they seem to have moderated their position and so, apparently, have the Pakistanis, who at first could scarcely conceal their satisfaction.

The Suffolk County Executive's ambitious $60-million farmland preservatian program, which was designed to stem suburbanization in this developing region, has bogged down in a political quagmire, with several County Legislators predicting the imminent demise of the project.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Felix Forte, who was the judge at the Brink's robbery trial, died here yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital. He was 80 years old.

INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 26 Jim Albus of LaTourette, Staten Island, a former Metropolitan open titleholder, gained the final round of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship today with Roger Ginsberg of Muttontown.

DEAL, Aug. 26 The wandering Jew has returned home. So have the avocados, yuccas, palms and ferns and all their window boxes, hanging pots and terrariums. This summer, it's the girls in their baggy dresses.

HARTFORD, Aug. 26 (AP) Doctors, including psychiatrists, at four state mental hospitals began cutting back their work week today, refusing to work more than 35 hours and giving priority to medical rather than administrative duties.

Paul O'Dwyer, President of the City Council, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation for $1 round-trip tolls on 12 East River and Harlem River bridges, which he estimated would yield, $125-million a year.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 Bangkok's elite university reopened quietly today after a week's shutdown that followed clashes between students and the police.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP) An organization of private colleges said today that failure by the state to increase subsidies to independent schools had forced students to aattend public colleges and universities.

Todd Rundgren's Utopia group was low-key in appearance (Mr. Rundgren has been known to flaunt green hair at times) at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Monday. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (UPI) A Federal appeals court ruled today that the University of Nebraska acted illegally when it refused to pay male employes according to the same salary schedule developed for female employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has decided to postpone the deadline on its subpoenas for tape recordings and documents from former President Richard M. Nixon's files, a committee spokesman said today.

FLEMINGTON, Aug. 26 It baa's; it moo's; it spins around wildly in circles. It glows in the dark. '"It" is the 118th annual Flemington Agricultural Fair which opened here today and runs through Labor Day.
AUSTIN, Tex. (UPI) People with poor diets have more colds, flu-type viruses and other ailments, according to state health officials.

Adm. Matthias B. Gardner. who retired in 1956 as Deputy Chief of Naval Operations, died Sunday at the Naval Hospital in Pensacola, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Pensacola.

The number of Americans studying or teaching abroad is declining rapidly as rising costs compete with scarce tuition dollars, student priorities change and foreign countries often appear less friendly than before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, contending that imports of men's suits, jackets and slacks have increased rapidly, said today that the union would apply under the 1974 Trade Act for weekly cash payments from the Federal Treasury for 20,000 clothing workers.

Joseph Stresser, who had been president of the Tatarek Penztar Bank in Budapest until he came to this country in 1957 after the uprising in Hungary, died Monday of a kidney ailment in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 26 A science center with the world's only institute devoted entirely to the study of volcanoes and another institute performing the Soviet Union's most extensive marine biology research has been created in Siberia.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 The recent encephalitis outbreak in Mississippi may have spread to Illinois, the state Director of Public Health warned today.
Several new tax-exempt offerings were well received in the credit markets yesterday, where prices and trading activity generally picked up from Monday's levels.

Vincent Tracy, a former alcoholic who achieved a record of nearly 90 per cent success in rehabilitating thousands of drinkers, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital of a kidney ailment and coronary failure. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 71st Street.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 26 Citing what it called "unsafe services" by the Long Island Rail Road, particularly at the Huntington station, the Suffolk County Legislature voted unanimously today to withhold funds due the commuter line and file suit to prevent the line from collecting fares at that station.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 26 Up to five small earthquakes occur every hour of every day in an underwater basin off the northern coast of California, according to new evidence from the University of California at Berkeley.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The, White House, citing "terrible political liabilities" of incumbency, said today that President Ford's extensive crosscountry travels bore no direct relation to his candidacy for a full term as President.

LISBON, Aug. 26-The great green Tagus River appears to be busy as usual with Dutch, German, Norwegian freighters, a Bulgarian oil-and-ore carrier and two Bulgarian fishing boats docked for repairs. But there is only one supertanker in port and the big vessels are increasingly rare.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) President Ford's record on busing and school integration is very clear, his press secretary, Ron. Nessen, said today. Mr. Ford supports "obedience to the law and to the court," Mr. Nessen said.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP) Business pressures led to the suicide of Lockheed Aircraft's treasurer, the victim's brother said today. Norman Waters said a note left by his brother, Robert, would not be released to the public, but said, "The gist of it was that it was business pressures. His last words werfe, 'I'm just too tired to go on,'" Mr. Waters said. "The note was personal and we have decided not to release it."

STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 26 (AP) Dwight Stones of the United States, the world record-holder, scored an easy high jump victory today in an international track and field meet by leaping 7 feet 5 inches to beat Walter Boller of West Germany by a margin of 4 inches. BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) Firemen walked off the job today for higher pay and the Mayor declared a state of emergency in order to get state help.

Kellogg Company, Houston, Tex., a division of Pullman, Inc., announced yesterday that Techmashimport, the company responsible for chemical plant purchases for Soviet industry, has signed contracts for four 1,500-to-a-day fertilizer ammonia plants. Kellogg will provide process design and engineering technology while the Toyo Engineering Corporation of Japan will furnish engineering and supplies. The total erected cost of the project was reported to be $245-million, with completion scheduled in 1979.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 Intense negotiations in the last few days have reduced differences to two or three points in the language of the projected Egyptian-Israeli accord, American officials said today.
DARWIN, Australia, Aug. 27 (Reuters) An effort to stop the widespread carnage in Portuguese Timor gradually took shape today.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 27 The United States assured South Korea today that it would honor its defense treaty with South Korea and would help deter any new attack from the North against the South.
Directors of the proposed Convention Center told members of the Board of Estimate yesterday that they were optimistic that the $230-million project would be completed with private financing.

TRENTON, Aug. 27 A reduction in the number of layoffs in private employment and a better summer job market for young people as a result of Federal programs is prompting some cautious optimism about New Jersey's economy among state labor officials.
For decades, people have gone to American summer music festivals to hear classical music. But now they are just as likely to encounter the Carpenters or Neil Sedaka as Seiji Ozawa or James Levine.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 27 (AP) Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, builder of the trans-Alaska pipeline, has won a temporary restraining order against the teamsters union to stop a walkout that idled 4,200 pipeline workers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (UPI)-A .22-caliber pistol equipped with a homemade silencer was the weapon used to kill Sam Giancana, reputed crime syndicate figure, in his suburban Oak Park home, the police said today.

Nationalization of Venezuela's mammoth oil industry may or may not produce the benefits for the country envisioned by its proponents, but the tide of nationalism sweeping Latin America made it inevitable. Given that fact of hemispheric politics, the Caracas Government was prudent in fashioning legislation that permits a continuing role, by contract, for the foreign (mostly American) oil companies operating in Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Perpetual Corporation, owned by Joe L. Allbritton, publisher of The Washington Star, announced today that it has extended the period for shareholders of Washington Star Communications, Inc., to offer their shares for purchase by Perpetual.

The Metropolitan Opera will raise the price of single tickets for several of the subscription performances that it expects to be in demand this coming season, in an effort to raise as much money as possible through the box office.

While ecologists discuss the politics of allocating the world's food supply and housewives protect food budgets by shopping with pocket calculators, the restaurant industry does business as usual. Diners who prefer smaller portions, for health or ecological or financial reasons, are totally ignored.

Carl A. Vergari, the District Attorney of Westchester County, announced yesterday that the alleged kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d would be prosecuted in State Supreme Court in Harrison and that Federal charges against them would be dismissed.

They remembered Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia wanting to take away their nightsticks, gangsters battling for territory in Prohibition days, and trying to keep peace in the breadlines during the Depression.

Although one year remains on his contract with the New York Rangers, Bobby Rousseau announced his retirement today after 15 seasons in the National Hockey League. The popular forward underwent spinal fusion surgery early last season after appearing in only eight games.

If the glass walls of Buddy's Place are still standing today, it is not because Maynard Ferguson and his orchestra have not been doing their best to blow them down. Playing the downstairs room across West 33d Street from the Statler Hilton, Mr. Ferguson combines a band that works at almost constant fever pitch with a sound system that is built for volume, producing music that is sometimes buried in its own loudness.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 27 (UPI) The dollar seesawed today on European money markets following mixed reaction at a cut in the United States trade surplus for July.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 27 Vice President Rockefeller, who regularly asserts that he is not actively seeking the second spot on next year's Republican ticket, campaigned avidly here and in Alabama today among Southern Republicans, many of whom have never forgiven him for not supporting Barry Goldwater in 1964.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 27 (AP) All 16 black members of Rhodesia's white-dominated Parliament announced today that they consider the African National Council "the true voice of the African people" in the country.

It will cost $600,000 to $1million to refurbish Madison Square Garden for the Democratic National Convention next year, but even as New York City was selected as the site, Garden officials were not sure exactly how the money would be spent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27, (AP) Representative Les Aspin said today that Navy inspection reports showed 22 older ships in "atrocious condition" with defects including a bad hull that kept one submarine from diving.

At least one good thing can be said for the Postal Rate Commission's reported rejection of the recommendations of Seymour Wenner, its administrative law judge. Mr. Wenner would have cut the cost of mailing a firstclass letter from 10 cents to 8 but he would have had senders of parcel post packages, bulk mail and periodicals make up for the loss.

The city's three biggest banks yesterday rejected Governor Carey's proposal for them to help raise the $2-billion needed by the city in the next few months, throwing the fiscal picture back into confusion with few apparent alternatives to a city default.

Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, the American commander for the Apollo-Soyuz mission last month, will leave the astronaut corps Nov. 1 after 13 years. The veteran of four spaceflights will return to active duty with the Air Force as commander of its test-pilot training at Edwards, Air Force Base in California. General Stafford, a Naval Academy graduate, did his test-pilot training at Edwards and later headed its performance branch.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Senate Democratic strategists disclosed today that they would not try immediately to Override a veto of the bill to extend oil price controls for six months beyond midnight next Sunday.

The Democratic party's site committee has concluded that New York City is still a going concern, capable of staging the party's 1976 Presidential convention in comfort and style. The committee's choice of New York over Los Angeles was narrow (before being made unanimous), but that seems not to have been a reflection of the city's fiscal troubles so much as a simple concern over the adequacy of floor space in Madison Square Garden.
What has happened to Stan Smith? Is his season-long tennis slump really the result of a sore arm, as Onny Parun believes? Or is his faltering play a mental collapse that more than time must heal?

Employment in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area declined by 241,000 between June, 1974, and June, 1975, the largest annual job loss on record for the 25-year period for which data are available, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

In case you're wondering how the Oakland A's are faring this summer without Catfish Hunter, the report is; so far, so good. In case you're wondering who took his place on the pitching staff after he auctioned himself off to the Yankees for $3.75-million, the answer is: three guys in the bull pen.

The Amstar Corporation and the National Sugar Refining Company said yesterday that effective immediately they had cut the wholesale prices on bundles holding 12 five-pound bags of sugar to $17.46 from $18.66 and lowered the price on bundles of six 10-pound bags from $18.60 to $17.40.

ALBANY, Aug, 27 The State Health Department levied $23,350 in fines against three nursing homes and cited 31 homes for operational deficiencies in August, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the State Health Commissioner, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The Government's new composite index of leading indicators of the economy rose substantially again in July, marking the fifth consecutive monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported today.

"Ben Vereen...Comin' at Ya" gets a fourth and final summer-showcase presentation tonight at 8 on NBC. Mr. Vereen came into his own TV series through review-catching performances in the stage musicals "Hair," "Jesus Christ, Superstar," and "Pippin." He sings, he dances, he acts, and he literally simmers with energy, providing the human equivalent of what scientists call a monopole, a center of magnetic force.

When the Giants face the Pittsburgh Steelers at Princeton University Saturday they not only will have to contend with an experienced quarterback named Terry Bradshaw, they also will have to deal with an eager neophyte punter whose name also happens to be Terry Bradshaw.

Charles S. Christopher, 29years-old, president and chairman of the board of the Surety Industries Company, a Dallasbased company, and Richard Geyer, 56, of North Palm Beach, Fla., the owner of Tracer Investigative Products, Inc. and the Geyer Detective agency, were indicted yesterday on charges of illegally using electronic equipment to spy on Mr. Christopher's business competitors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) President Ford has been more reluctant to turn over files from the Nixon Administration than files from the Kennedy Administration, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today.

PARIS, Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP) About 300 youths attacked government headquarters in the center of the Corsican city of Bastia early today, killing a policeman and wounding 14 persons, official sources there said.

RICHMOND, Aug. 27 (AP) Stanley Price of Pittsburgh, who couldn't make the var sity golf team at Duke, upset the British Amateur champion, Vinny Gies, on Giles's home course today in the second round of the 75th United States Amateur.

Representative Peter A. Peyser yesterday accused Senator James L. Buckley of "potential conflict of interest" regarding his votes on oil and gas issues, and called on him to make full disclosure of his finances.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 27 (AP) An epidemic alert was issued and mass inoculations continued today to try to stem an outbreak of hepatitis that could affect up to 5,000 patrons of two Portland restaurants. Multnomah County health officials estimate that about 5,000 persons patronized the restaurants from July 10, when the spread of the illness apparently started, until the restaurants closed voluntarily Aug. 22.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The Federal Reserve Board has unanimously opposed a request of the House Banking Committee for the staff projections of the economy that the board and Federal Open Market Committee use in drawing up their targets for the money supply.
From top executive to jostling subway rider, New Yorkers reacted jubilantly yesterday to the news that their city would be host next year to its first Presidential poiitical convention since 1924.

With prices for many steel products used in the automobile and appliance industries scheduled to rise Oct. 1, steel producers report that their major customers are asking them to speed delivery on orders previously scheduled to be filled after the price rise.
DETROIT Under hot floodlights and before a closedcircuit television camera, Bill Peck gently lifted a loose end of the mummy's fragile linen bandage and began to unwrap the preserved corpse.
Futures prices of wheat, corn, red meat, oats and potatoes, which had been down on Tuesday, rebounded yesterday in active trading while soybean futures were off.
Elias Kabil, a textile maufacturer and importer, died of cancer yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived at 150 Elderfield Road, Manhasset, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 President Ford has asked the Office of Management and Budget to review Social Security's federalized welfare program Supplemental Security Income.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The Democcatic party chose New York City over Los Angeles today as the site of its 1976 convention.
MADRID, Aug. 27 A law against terrorism that went into effect today makes it obligatory for judges to sentence to death persons convicted of killing policemen, soldiers or government officials.
Alexis R. Wiren, special assistant to the president of Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I., died Tuesday at his home there. He was 78 years old.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27 Most of Alabama's 6,000 coal miners ignored today a Federal court order to return to work and continued to picket two of the area's largest mines, apparently in sympathy with a wildcat strike that started in West Virginia.

The best performance by a player from the New York area in the recent Summer Nationals in Miami Beach was by Jim Linhart of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., who towers over his rivals from a height of 6 feet 8 inches. He won the first major title, the mixed teams, and then returned to New York to do a week's work.

Haile Selassie, the last emperor in the 3,000-year-old Ethiopian monarchy, who ruled for half a century before he was deposed by military coup last September, died yesterday in a small apartment in his former palace. He was 83 years old.
The Board of Education yesterday offered city teachers a cost-of-living salary adjustment tied to some concessions by the teachers, but the offer was turned down by the United Federation of Teachers.
Earnings of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., for the quarter and nine months ended Aug. 2 shrank dramatically from the high levels of a year ago, according to the results reported yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 27 The arrest by security police of a young exiled South African poet, who allegedly re-entered the country disguised as a Frenchman, has led to a fresh wave of students arrests, the local press reported today.
Vice President Rockefeller has agreed to testify tomorrow before a grand jury investigating the prison uprising at Attica four years ago.

A course-correction maneuver at 2:30 P.M. yesterday placed the Viking I spacecraft on a "precision course" to orbit the planet Mars next June 19, Dr. Edgar M. Cortright, director of the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., announced at a news conference in Pasadena, Calif.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 27-The Indian Government said today that it was continuing to maintain normal diplomatic relations with neighboring Bangladesh.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) After an angry reception by Hudson County mayors when he sought their support for bond issue referendums today, State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner scheduled a meeting to reconsider the county's road-construction proposals.
ROME, Aug. 27 Portions of the originals of three films, including Federico Fellini's "Casanova," have been stolen from the studio where they were being shot, production sources announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The two Christmas stamps issued for use during the 1975 holiday season will portray a madonna and child, and a cherub swinging from a Christmas bell. But, for the first time, they won't have a monetary denomination.

The Norwegian whaling ship Barba Negra set sail in New York harbor yesterday with two mechanical harpoons and a hearty crew of 10 to do what she was not designed to do save whales.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) Total world trade will fall about 12 per cent this year in volume and rise 5-to 6 per cent next year, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today in its Economic Review.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 A Federal jury exonerated today Gov. James A. Rhodes, the former president of Kent State University and 27 Ohio National Guardsmen from any responsibility in the shootings at Kent State in 1970.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Blacks who develop cancer have less hope of long-term survival than whites of the same sex, according to data collected during the last 20 years in a major study by the National Cancer Institute.

Two auxiliary police officers, a man and a woman, were injured the man critically in Central Park last night when an apparently deranged nude man beat them with a nightstick he had taken from them, according to the police.

When the City Opera production of Strauss's "Salome" was played last season, there were many pros and cons. This writer, overseas, missed it. WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today it had ordered new warning labels on a drug linked to six deaths from liver disease.

TRENTON, Aug. 27 (AP) Insurance companies and owners of auto-body repair shops complained today that proposed state regulations to protect consumers were too rigid.

PARIS, Aug. 27 The French Government today announced a plan to improve the lagging economy with heavy spending, especially in public works.

Although they are in elite company with the Miami Dophins and Oakland Raiders as the only winners of all three exhibition games this summer, the Giants still do not know what kind of a team they will have. The Pittsburgh Steelers will help them find out tomorrow in the preseason contest at Princeton's Palmer Stadium.

The Board of Education be gan sending layoff notices yes terday to 1,500 regularly li censed elementary and junior- high teachers because of the schools' financial crisis, and school officials voiced concern that the number of dismissed teachers would eventually be considerably higher.
OTTAWA, Aug. 28--Canada and the Soviet Union have set tled their quarrel over Atlantic fisheries, and Soviet fishing vessels are again to be allowed to use Canadian east coast ports.

Massachusetts State Bank ing Commissioner Carol S. Greenwald has accused Fed eral banking officials of "un dermining" efforts by state officials there to get national banks in Boston to provide her office voluntarily with mortgage placement data that would help the depart ment determine if there has been redlining in Boston.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28-- Four men, all large and a little paunchy, met here to day and let out a jungle scream. Each of them could have said to the other, "Me Tarzan. You Tarzan."

A couple whose home in Rosedale, Queens, was bombed last New Year's Eve because they are black were shot ac cidentally Wednesday night when the husband's pistol went off as a police officer tried to disarm him during a confron tation with neighbors, the po lice said yesterday.

BONN, Aug. 28--The Social Democratic party of West Ger many has supplied several mil lion dollars in aid to the Soci ist party of Portugal during the last year and a half, according to German and American in formants.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28-- little paunchy, met here to- day and let out a jungle scream. Each of them could have said to the other, "Me Tarzan. You Tarzan."
BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP) The American Basketball Association ended months of uncertainty over its bank rupt Memphis Sounds fran chise today when it an nounced that the club would move to Baltimore.
What an official in the City Controller's office described last month as "the worst catastrophe that could befall the city"--default--is now staring New York in the face.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The Federal Trade Commission pro posed today regulations that would prohibit a variety of funeral-industry practices-- from unnecessary embalming to bait-and-switch sales tech niques--that the commission said inflict "economic and emo tional injuries" on the con sumer.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 28--The head of the United Nations Environment Program today told nations participating in the Pacific Science Congress here that unless they took con certed action to preserve the islands of the South Pacific, those territories could soon be come "an oceanic wilderness."

Mayor Beame yesterday ordered 24 assistant admin istrators, deputy commission ers and assistant commission ers to give up their city cars to save the city money. He directed that the vehicles be sold at public auction.

HAWORTH, Aug. 28--The (treasury of the White Beeches Golf and Country Club here is $1,000 lighter because of an Alcoholic Beverage Commission fine on charges of possessing "obscene" printed material, but its president would just as soon leave the issue a closed book.
Paul E. Paddock Jr., who with his brother William wrote "Famine 1975! America's Decision: Who Will Survive?" in 1967, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 67 years old.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Arthur Bell Thompson, a well-known writer of crime fiction under the pen name Francis Clifford, died Monday at the age of 57.
TOKYO, Aug. 29 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger criticized the Japanese today for having been "too much a passive partner" in security and urged them to assume a more active role.
Futures prices of most farm commodities closed lower yesterday in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 Five major exchanges of art exhibitions between the United States and the Soviet Union will take place between now and 1980 under an agreement signed today by Soviet cultural officials and Thomas P.F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

LISBON, Aug, 29 Gen. Vasco Goncalves, opposed for weeks by overwhelming military and political forces for trying to promote Communist rule in Portugal, was dismissed as Premier tonight by President Francisco da Costa Gomes.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29 (Agence France-Presse) The Indonesian Government said today that it wanted to help end the fighting on Portuguese Timor and was seeking Portuguese authorization to hold talks on the island.

WASHINGTON; Aug. 29 In Washington Tuesday it was 112 degrees on the sidewalk and a cool 72 in the marble file cabinets where great men confer, Lunch, nuzzle the telephone and otherwise engage in what is always called here, with no trace of self-mockery, the exercise of power.

TRENTON, Aug. 29-State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner met with Hudson County officials for four hours today to outline state plans for highway and local road projects and he hoped to convince county Democratic leaders to drop their threatened opposition to a proposed $560-million transportation bond issue.
TOKYO, Aug. 29 Officials of the Tokyo metropolitan government disclosed recently that they had projected a previously unexpected $500-million drop in tax revenue in the current fiscal year.

FRANKFORD, Ind., Aug. 29 (AP) Basil (Stuffy) Walters, former executive editor and a director of Knight Newspapers, Inc., and later editor of The Chicago Daily News, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at Clinton County Hospital. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) Manufacturers who produce 94 per cent of all the home appliances sold in the nation have pledged to take part in a voluntary program aimed at conserving energy and helping consumers pick the most effective products.
BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Two Basque nationalist guerrillas were condemned to death today as a wave of protest demonstrations and strikes swept the Basque country.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 208.4 from 207.8 last week.

Governor Carey plans to call a special session of the Legislature next week if an intricate package of financing arrangements can be worked out this weekend to raise the cash the city needs to avert a default in the days ahead.

"If I wish to know what the Irish want," said Eamon de Valera, "I look into my own heart." It was a claim that recalled Charles de Gaulle's self-identification with France; but not even Mr. de Valera's onetime British enemies nor his most implacable foes on Ireland's political battlefronts would seriously challenge its validity.

Federal Judge Charles J. Brieant Jr., has approved settlement of three suits in which stockholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiary, the Hartford Accident Indemnity Company claimed damages for the alleged misuse of inside information. The Associated Press reported yesterday.
The size of the crowd and not so much the outcome of the game will be of interest today when the New York Giants play the Super Bowl champions, the Pittsburgh Steelers, at Princeton's Palmer Stadium.

BONN, Aug. 29 The West German Government, running out of money to stimulate the flagging economy, decided today on what Finance Minister Hans Apel called a "painful" package of budget cuts and tax increases for 1976 and 1977.

In their cars, they load up, drive away, and then suddenly realize they don't know where they're going. They can be cranky, bewildered, giddy, frustrated and sometimes moved to acts of violence.

GUTTENBERG, Aug. 29 Among the proliferating high rises marching along the Palisades in growing ranks is the Galaxy, a 1,200-apartment, multilevel complex here that will include a two-level shopping mall built into the sides of the cliff and is scheduled to open next July.

The present token will remain in use when subway and bus fares rise from 35 to 50 cents at 12:01 A.M. Monday, David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced yesterday.

When they're covering up as parachute jumpers at St. Tropez, the sandy strip where toplessness started, it figures that in the concrete canyons of Gotham they're letting it all hang out. This August's beachheads are the office, the subway and the sidewalks of New York.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 29 Two Federal judges ordered Alabama prison authorities today to stop accepting any new prisoners until the inmate population of the state's penal institutions reached a manageable proportion.

Nobody's opera season is officially open in New York these days until Beverly Sills has appeared, and appear she did on Thursday nightin the New York City Opera's "I Puritani." The production was Tito Capobianco's appropriately dark and puritanical conception, but Miss Sills personally lighted it up every time she came into view as the virginal Elvira, and set fires of enthusiasm every time she opened her throat.

The wife, Louisa, through illness has become an automaton losing power of speech and, apparently, sensibility. Her husband, Charlie, a schoolteacher, slavishly cares for her, trying to enlist the assistance of their preteen-age daughter, who, more realistic and less sympathetic than the father, considers her mother dead.

Governor Carey plans to call a special session of the Legislature next week if an intricate package of financing arrangements can be worked out this weekend to raise the cash they city needs to avert a default in the days ahead.

NEWARK, Aug. 29 (UPI) An auxiliary Newark policewoman walked into Police Headquarters here today with a grenade she said he had taken from her brother after he allegedly had threatened to kill members of her family.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Agriculture Department today cut by five million tons its estimate of the Soviet Union's drought-ravaged grain crop, but officials indicated that they did not expect the Russians to seek more United States grain to make up the shortage.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29 President Carlos Andr s P rez of Venezuela signed into law today a bill ordering the nationalization of the country's petroleum industry, with the Government taking complete control on Jan. 1, ending more than half a century of dominance by foreign oil companies.
A new method for processing polyester end nylon filament into textured yarns at a very high rate of speed promises to give the apparel and home furnishings trades a wide variety of new fabrics.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) A juror in the Kent State damage trial said today that the deciding factor in the case had been film and tape recordings made during the seconds before Ohio National Guardsmen opened fire on antiwar demonstrators on May 4, 1970.

Continuing huge deficits for the second quarter and halfyear ended July 31 were reported yesterday by the W.T. Grant Company, the financially troubled retailer that lost a record $177-million last year.

HOPEWELL, Va., Aug. 29 (UPI) The number of persons in this blue-collar city with traces of the pesticide Kepone in their blood increases as the authorities try to determine the poison's long-term effect on humans.
Rick Wise, who won only three games for the Boston Red Sox last season because of injuries, has made a complete turnaround this year.

The Bell Telephone System and most of the nation's major independent telephone companies are pressing state utility regulators to approve increases in charges to customers for directory assistance and pay-telephone calls.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29 After seven years in power, the leftist military Government that had vowed to carry out a revolutionary transformation of Peruvian society still remains an enigma to both its supporters and critics.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 29 Millions of tourists are invading the Pacific islands, and this last week ethnologists met here to discuss whether the native cultures can survive the invasion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Faulty crop forecasting by the Agriculture Department resuited in wrong policy decisions that cost the Government $1.67-billion in a year, according to the General Accounting Office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Average prices for raw farm products held unchanged in the month ended Aug. 15 as a drop in cattle, potato, and tonato prices offset further increases in other commodities, he Agriculture Department reported today.

WANTAGH, L.I., Aug. 29 (AP) A police sharpshooter killed a 10-foot-long shark at Jones Beach today as thousands of bathers watched from the sand after being ordered out of the water. No one was injured.
ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP) Governor Carey's office says that 5,820 permanent state jobs were vacated between Jan. 8 and Aug. 20, reducing the state's permanent work force to 178,017.
The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers called yesterday for state help to avert a teachers' strike threatened for Sept. 9, the day after the fall school term begins.

John R. Inman, who retired three years ago as vice president of the Council on Religion and International Affairs after 27 years of activity in the cause of world peace, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital, in Cleveland. He was 63 years old and lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio, and formerly in Scarsdale, N.Y.
MOSCOW, Aug. 29 Soviet legal authorities have ordered tighter supervision of the grain harvest and warned that those guilty of theft and spoilage will be prosecuted.
Players who open substandard hands are likely to create swings, sometimes in their favor, sometimes not.
ST. PAUL. Minn., Aug. 29 The controversy between conservatives and moderates in the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod has brought changes in leadership in two more synod colleges.

It is probably a little late to make any difference in the American League's Eastern Division race, but the Yankees have regained the winning habit. Last night at Shea Stadium, it took 10 innings, but the home team beat the Kansas City Royals, 6-5.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) Andy North shot a record-tying 27 for nine holes and an eight-under-par 63 today to take the first-round lead in the B.C. open golf tournament.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the Over-theCounter market advanced for the second straight day yesterday. Investors seemed confident that the economy would show advances toward the end of the year, said one analyst.
Foreclosure proceedings have begun against the Chrysler Building, a city landmark since it was opened in 1930.

HASTINGS, N.Y. A detour taken 52 years ago to buy fresh-from-the-oven bread dramatically changed the course of Faith and Edward Deming Andrews's lives. For beyond the loaves in that immaculate basement "cook-room" at Hancock (N.H.) Shaker Village, then saw austere benches, spare, slat-back rockers, a lean trestle table and asymmetric cupboards, all of haunting grace and unlike anything they had ever seen before.

In appealing to its members to help clear away litter in front of their stores, the Fifth Avenue Association has spotlighted a priority that should not stop with tidying up the city's principal shopping areas. Volunteer action can be a help all over the city in keeping up standards of civic housekeeping while bringing down the costs of urban government.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 29 A number of former members of the so-called third force opposition in South Vietnam have quietly begun appearing in the governing bodies being set up by the Communist Government, according to intelligence reports, broadcasts and reports from travelers from Vietnam.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 29 (AP) The royal council of Laos has officially postponed general elections until April, a Vientiane newspaper reported today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 29 Three persons drowned today when a large raft carrying 29 persons on a test run through the treacherous whitewater rapids of the lower Niagara River was struck by a powerful wave and capsized, dumping its occupants into the swirling waters.

New York City has an accumulated deficit of $3.3-billion, Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, State Controller Arthur Levitt, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation agreed yesterday.

The Uniformed Firefighters Association reached a tentative contract settlement with the city yesterday, then voluntarily agreed to a wage freeze, shortly before Mayor Beame signed an executive order imposing the pay freeze on city employes as of Monday.

Moscow, Aug. 29 Five major exchanges of art exhibitions between the United States and the Soviet Union will take place between now and 1980 under an agreement signed today by Soviet cultural officials and Thomas P.F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said tonight that the presence of American technicians in the Sinai passes was "one of the central conditions" of Israel's willingness to agree to a new disengagement accord with Egypt. He called on Congress and the American public to support this overseas involvement.

A Public Service Commission investigation of why the Consolidated Edison Company's electric rates are the highest in the country has found that the most important reasons are the company's lack of cheap hydropower, its greater use of obsolete plants and the extraordinary hourly and seasonal peak demands made on its service along with sharp offpeak declines in usage.

Russell F.W. Smith, dean of New York University's School of Continuing Education for the last 10 years, died yesterday at N.Y.U.'s Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of complications growing out of a cerebral hemorrhage he suffered on Aug. 6 while vacationing in Vermont. He was 60 years old and lived in White Plains.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug, 29 (UPI) The Penn Central said today that it intended to raise commuter fares between Philadelphia and New York and New Jersey points by as much as 25 per cent on Oct. 1.
LISBON, Aug. 29 Two of Angola's three rival independence movements have reached an agreement on a cease-fire and an exchange of prisoners, official Portuguese sources announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The interest ceiling on Government-backed mortgage loans will be raised to 9 per cent Tuesday, Housing Secretary Carla Hills said today.
ROME, Aug. 29 The head of the Venice Geological Research Laboratory said today he believed that the city had stopped sinking into the sea and he did not expect it would sink any further.
Growing investor confidence that interest rates might have peaked helped the stock market advance yesterday in slightly higher trading.

Vitas Gerulaitis bent down to gather his tennis gear from the court after he had just become the first men's seeded player to lose in the United States Open at Forest Hills. When he straightened up he was confronted with a mural of disappointed and accusing faces stretched across one entire side of the court.

LISBON, Aug. 29 Gen. Vasco Goncalves, opposed for weeks by overwhelming military and political forces for trying to promote Communist rule in Portugal, was dismissed as Premier tonight by President Francisco da Costa Gomes.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 29 (Reuters) The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, today lost his first game since he won the title last April by default from Bobby Fischer.

Floyd Barger, who retired Aug. 1 as editor and a senior vice president of The Daily News, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I. Mr. Barger, who had been ill for several weeks, was 68 years old and lived in Garden City. L.I.

Barbara Ann Liebig, a music therapist at the Children's Day Treatment Center and School here, was married yesterday afternoon to William Jay Thomashower, a lawyer with the firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays Handler. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in the Beth-El Chapel of Temple Emanu-El.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has released to a professor of history at Smith College the first of its secret material on the espionage investigation of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, a 725-page portion of the bureau's 48,000-page file.

SEATTLE Since 1906, an enormous gas refining plant has occupied a prominent site at the edge of Lake Union in the center of this city, and for almost as many years, local residents have been complaining about the way it marred the landscape.

An acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday directed Bernard Bergman, and his son, Stanley, to appear before a stategrand jury in Trenton that is investigating Medicaid fraud and abuses in the nursing-home industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 President Ford proposed today a 5 per cent increase in pay for all Federal employes, including members of Congress.

The International Business Machines Corporation has filed a brief with the United States Supreme Court in opposition to an earlier petition by the Telex Corporation. Telex had requested a review of the Appeals Court decision, which held that I.B.M. had not violated the antitrust laws as charged in a 1972 suit filed by Telex.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 The Soviet press agency Tass denied today that the Soviet Union had transferred funds to the Portuguese Communist party by "laundering" them through a Soviet-Belgian shipping company in Antwerp.

Knut Hagrup, president of the International Air Transport Association, predicted yesterday a two-part increase in air fares that could total as much as 12 per cent by the end of next year. But he added that such an advance would be insufficient to pull the industry out of its immediate economic difficulties.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29 The President of Peru, who has headed a leftist military government for seven years, was overthrown today in an apparently bloodless military coup.

Milton Glaser is a witty fellow. This in itself would not qualify him for an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, but it adds a most welcome fizz and snap to the show of his graphic designs posters, record sleeves, stationery, book jackets and many other things besides that is on now at the Modern Museum and will be there through Sept. 14.

Eamon de Valera, a chief strategist and fighter in the cause of Irish independence, who became Prime Minister, President, and revered elder statesman of the Republic of Ireland, died early yesterday. He was 92 years old.

RICHMOND, Aug. 29 Five students and three selfsupporting "older guys" that is, from age 26 to 40 shared honors today in the fourth and fifth rounds of the 75th United States Amateur, a match-play golf championship being played on the picturesque James River Course of the Country Club of Virginia.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) John Walker of New Zealand, the world recordholder, won the mile in 3 minutes 53.62 seconds in an international track meet tonight at the Crystal Palace.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 Despite some sharp nudging by his supporters, former Gov. Ronald Reagan is still biding his time about making a final decision on whether he will challenge President Ford for the Republican nomination next year.

Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation have sunk to just about their lowest levels since public trading began July 21 in the original $1-billion issue. The agency was created with the aim of saving New York City from defaulting on its securities and lately, with the outlook still uncertain on putting together another patchwork plan of financing most prices have eased anew.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, conferred with President Ford today and reported afterward that Mr. Ford was willing to sign into law next month a revival of oil price controls of 30 to 45 days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Most industrial users of natural gas in the Northeast can sub stitute other fuels and can probably ride out this winter's expected gas shortage without major losses of production or jobs, according to a Government analysis.
Dr. Laszlo Ravasz, retired Bishop of the Reformed Church of Hungary, died Aug. 6 in Budapest, church officials here learned yesterday. He was 92 years old.
United Airlines announced yesterday that its directors, at a meeting on Thursday, had deferred indefinitely a decision on purchasing 50 Boeing 727300 three-engine jet planes, costing $600-million.

The long-delayed return of Prince Norodom Sihanouk to Cambodia, ending five years of exile, has been set for Sept. 9 or 10, Peking sources said yesterday. Going with him, they said, will be his wife, Princess Monique, and two of his sons; Penn Nouth, the titular Cambodian premier, and his wife, and "perhaps" nvo or three others of the Prince's retinue-inexile of some 50 members.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 President Ford proposed today a 5 per cent increase in pay for all Federal employes, including members of Congress.

Benny Scott, an associate professor of psychology at Mission College in Los Angeles, broke a color barrier in auto racing yesterday when the Brown and Williamson Tobacco Corporation announced it would sponsor the Black American Racers team in Formula 5000 race Sept. 28 at Long Beach, Calif.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 Six runs in the first inning, before he had to throw a pitch, were all Jon Matlack needed tonight to pitch his 16th victory of the season, a 6-1 decision for the New York Mets over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Just after 1 P.M. yesterday the Coast Guard sailing ship Eagle appeared in the Narrows, a lone stand of masts on the gray horizon.

Charles E. Honce, who rose from a $14 a week reporter in Keokuk, Iowa, to become an assistant general manager of The Associated Press, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 30 Beekman Place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission, seeking to "bring some order out of the chaos," issued guidelines today to force auto makers to tell the whole truth about their cars' fuel economy.

ATLANTA, Aug. 29 No one ever blamed the Falcons' front four for last season's 3-11 won-lost record. When a club puts an average of only 8 points a game on the scoreboard, even the best defense is hopeless to prevent a losing campaign.

MORRISTOWN, Aug. 29 About 25 women, members of two local chapters of the National Organization for Women, concluded a weeklong observance of the 55th anniversary of woman's suffrage tonight by staging a mock funeral cortege on the sidewalks this town's main street.

Besides all this, Tink has nothing in common with his older brother, a real jock; so he spends his hours alone with his dog, observing wildlife and collecting beach glass.

Why Congress Should Not Kill the DISC Exports have been the one significant area of growth in employment during the recession. Without rising exports, employment in the private sector would have declined by an additional 750,000 jobs. But it would have declined by more than 4.2 million if we had not had the increase in exports.

LONDON The death of former Emperor Haile Selassie has formally closed a chapter in Ethiopia's history, although the old regime had effectively died with his dethronement a year ago. Rabbi and Mrs. Philip Hiat of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merryl Jill Hiat, to James Solomon Tisch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Tisch of Rye, N.Y.

Latest in the paperback espionage sweepstakes series: MAX GALAN: HUNTER OF MEN by C.H. Guenter (Pinnacle, $1.25). This is the first in a projected series. The ingredients include the Mafia, a hit man, microfilm stolen from the C.I.A., a safecracking job on a safe that can't be cracked.

It is virtually impossible to discuss motor racing in a detached way, when you have recently lost someone who was very close to you. Americans are more affected by Mark Donohue's death than they would be if a driver from a foreign country were to die in a similar racing accident, even if he were equally loved and famous in his own home country. Nevertheless, let me try.

EAST HAMPTON Lynn Knoll loves to travel. This wanderlust and a desire to "put down roots in the community" she and her fabricdesigner husband, Boris Knoll, selected for a second home have resulted in The Beach Plum Tree, an unusual shop bursting with the crafts she has discovered on her journeys around the world and throughout the United States.

John M. Schiff's Gab Bag, who spent the first season of his eligible racing career just marking time, continued to demonstrate yesterday that his late start at the races was redounding to his advantage.

After centuries of neglect in mercantile America, the inner life is finally getting its due. Every popular magazine, every rock record, every commentary on the American scene contains reference to a hunger for change, away from the "emptiness and sterility" which are said to be the price of our material comfort, and toward a more emotionally meaningful, spiritual, fulfilling personal life.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP) An Episcopal priest again challenged church law and orders from his bishop by permitting women to celebrate communion today.

Unionized lay teachers at five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens are expected to vote tomorrow night on whether to strike Wednesday.
Viola Townsend Winmill, a noted foxhunt rider, coach driver and race horse owner, died Thursday in Warrenton, Va. She was 84 years old and formerly lived here and in Mill Neck, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 1 In an atmosphere of uncertainty and unease, Federal controls on all oil prices ended today, leaving the economy wholly without Federal price ceilings for the first time in four years.

MONTAUBAN, France, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Pierre Blaise, the young star of the film "Lacombe, Lucien," was killed in a car crash near here tonight, the police said. Two other persons also died with the 24year-old Mr. Blaise when the car in which they were riding ran off the road near this southWestern town.

PARIS, Aug. 31 Growers of walnuts in the Grenoble area staged protests throughout last night against an influx of cheaper California walnuts that have captured much of the European market from the celebrated Grenoble produce.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 31 (UPI) Logan County miners, leaders of an unauthorized coal strike that has idled more than 60,000 members of the United Mine Workers, voted today to continue their walkout in defiance of their union leaders and the courts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Alfred Hayes, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, urged today that the world move toward a system of "firmly managed floating" of currency-exchange rates to avoid the "violent fluctuations" that have occurred during the current experiment with floating.

MANILA, Aug. 31 (AP) A government prosecutor filed embezzlement charges today against the former presidential press censor, Primitivo Mijares, now in self-imposed exile in the United States. Mr. Mijares is a former National Press Club president and chairman of the defunct Media Advisory Council, which supervised the Philippine press until mid-1974.

RICHMOND, Aug. 31 Fred S. Ridley, a 23-year-old law student, defeated Keith Fergus, 2 up in 36 holes and won the 75th United States Amateur golf championship today. To do it he had to fend off two strong rallies and carry his opponent to the final green of the picturesque James River course of the Country Club of Virginia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 Ron O'Neal, Andy Williams and Howard Cosell signed autographs. Dick Gregory and Sandy Barron told jokes. Fred Williamson, a black actor, led his white date around crowded tables. Phil Donohue, a white television personality, guided a young black woman through the throng of more than 300.

City College's controversial Biomedical program has rejected for a second time the applications of three white men who are suing for admission on the ground that they were excluded last fall for racial reasons from the doctor-training program.

Jersey City authorities are investigating the death of two men described as derelicts in a fire in a vacant tenement early Saturday near the city's waterfront. A third man was reported to have been critically burned.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 A subsidiary, of International Telephone Telegraph responsible for operating and maintaining the entire American military communications system in Thailand, 'including top-secret monitoring stations, has been eased out of the country, its operations here terminating today.

LISBON, Aug. 31 The new Portuguese Government has inherited a series of measures intended to shore up a failing capitalist economy measures that Gen. Vasco Goncalves, widely accused of seeking a Communist state, pushed through just before his ouster as Premier Friday.

WASHINGTON This seems to be a bad year for an assault on the defense budget. Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has submitted a budget of $105 billion for fiscal year 1976, almost 18 per cent above last year's amount. Before the end of this decade, in the Pentagon's own figures, the defense budget will be $148 billion; by 1985, it will top $200 billion. Even in "inflated dollars," we had better take these projections seriously.

The American judicial system could learn from the British about legal ethics, self-discipline and the decorum that keeps a trial from turning into "something resembling a bar-room brawl," Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said yesterday in Provo, Utah.

Daniel Flynn, a former State Assemblyman, was killed Monday evening in a car collision on the Garden State Parkway in Clifton, N.J. Mr. Flynn was 68 years old and had homes at 5 Peter Cooper Road and in Spring Lake, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 One of the principal Government agencies charged with enforcing laws against employment discrimination has been accused of discrimination against its own minority workers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Forces of the leftwing Timorese Liberation Front seeking independence for Portuguese Timor were reported today to be fanning out from the capital, Dili, and threatening to cut off troops of a rival organization.

TRENTON, Sept. 5 Teacher unrest over wages and rights in New Jersey mounted today as four school districts reported job actions that closed schools and kept more than 14,000 children out of classes in the first week after the long summer recess.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission were reported yesterday to have begun routine investigations of insider trading in stock of the Copperweld Corporation. The Big Board confirmed that the inquiry had begun but the S.E.C., by custom, refused to comment.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5 (AP) A Federal judge signed a 90-day injunction today ordering longshoremen here to load ships with grain purchased by the Soviet Union and forbidding the longshoremen's union to try any evasive tactics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 The United States Postal Service has decided not to increase postage rates for letters to 13 cents from 10 cents until after Christmas, the agency reported today.

Suzanne Starkey Groome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Groome of Syosset, L.I., and Sarasota, Fla., was married last evening to Timothy Stephen Stier, son of Mrs. Albert Henry Stier of Columbia and Charleston, S.C., and the late Mr. Stier. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcom Bertram in the Community Church of Syosset, which is affiliated with the United Church of Christ.

Michael S. Striker, a leading patent lawyer, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 69 years old and had homes at 285 Central Park West, in New City, N.Y., and in Duncans, Jamaica, W.I.

Harry B. Helmsley, the realestate developer, said yesterday that he would present a revised set of plans to the city for his proposed hotel-office building to rise behind the landmark Villard Houses on Madison Avenue, calling for the preservation of the famed Gold Room there and expanding the hotel and office combination to include apartments as well.

The United States is on the brink of becoming a permanently divided society a society deeply split between the ever fewer who are employed and the ever more who, while willing and able to work, cannot find employment on a sustained basis.

Susan Warms Dryfoos, daughter of Marian S. Heiskell and the late Orvil E. MOSCOW, Sept. 5 While maintaining a conspicuous official silence on the conclusion of a new disengagement agreement between Egypt and Israel, the Soviet Union has made clear its unhappiness over the course of events in the Middle East.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Eight persons were killed in three separate incidents in political violence in Argentina today.
TRENTON, Sept. 5 According to his wife, Rudolph Fuessel Jr., a volunteer fireman, has grown so tired this week that since Wednesday he has been more or less walking in his sleep.

Querube Arias, daughter of Dr. Roberto E. Arias, the former Panamanian diplomat, was married here yesterday afternoon to Carlos Fernando Brillembourg, a Venezuelan architect. The Rev. Kenneth Jadoff performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.
Leif Ericson would have felt at home watching 90 young Scandinavian sailors gaze at the New York skyline yesterday.

Some 50,000 teachers walking picket lines in 11 states kept nearly a million children home from school again yesterday as courts in two states ordered teachers either to return to work or to resume bargaining with school officials.

"Bill, watch it," a stablehand shouted yesterday in Barn 34 at Belmont Park.

Paul H. Chook, who suddenly departed the W.R.
