Two crop forecasts released after trading Friday depressed prices of wheat, corn and soybeans yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. It was the first chance for the commodities to react to the reports.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8 The Westchester County Board of Legislators today overrode County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's veto last week of a consumer protection bill. The vote was 15 to 2.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of nuclear power plants for the production of electricity, announced yesterday that it would stop supplying uranium to about 20 electric utility customers by the end of 1978 because of the unprofitability of the business, and would begin an immediate program of allocating uranium it has in inventory or on order.

NEWARK, Sept. 8 Jersey City settled its civil suit against the North Jersey Incineration Company today for $500,000 in cash and the abrogation of a 17-year garbage-disposal contract allegedly awarded on the basis of fraud and political kickbacks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Two containers of a mass poison developed by the Central Intelligence Agency have been discovered hidden in a warehouse at Fort Detrick, Md., apparently in violation of a Presidential order, sources familiar with the matter reported today.

PERTH AMBOY, Sept. 8 Work officially began today on dredging operations near here that will create a new deep-water cargo shipping facility at the site of the former Raritan Arsenal on the Raritan Riverin Middlesex County.

TRENTON, Sept. 8 Schools and industries will be permitted to reopen here tomorrow, further indicating the steady if shaky recovery of thsi city and its suburbs from the water shortage that hit the area last week when the local water system broke down.

VISTA, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP) The niece of the president of the Curtis Publishing Company has been found beaten to death in a home here where she was vacationing. San Diego County sheriff's deputies reported.

The proposed offering of the common stock of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has been deferred pending clarification of problems in connection with shipments to the North Slope of Alaska, the company announced yesterday.

PREPARATION PERIODS: The Board of Education wants the teachers to reduce their "prep" or "free time" periods, figuring it could save $35-million to $40-million a year. The teachers use these periods to prepare lessons, mark papers or rest between classes. Instead, the board would have the teachers meet more classes during the week, enabling a reduction in class size.
Wesley Simpson, a former textile executive and designer of fashion fabrics and husband of Adele Simpson, the fashion designer, died yesterday at their home, 5A East 78th Street. He was 72 years old.

In a rush of poetic frenzy, Wayne Hanley of the Massachusetts Audubon Society writes in a recent newsletter that the "spermy whale may still gyre and gimble in the wabe," if enough jojoba oil can be produced.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 Secretary General Waldheim tried today to avoid a breakdown in the new round of peace negotiations here between Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 Sporadic street fighting continued this evening in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli, where at least 31 lives have been lost in six days of violence, according to unofficial figures.
PEKING, Tuesday, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk left here today for Cambodia after more than five years of exile in China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Two containers of a mass poison developed by the Central Intelligence Agency have been discovered hidden in a warehouse at Fort Detrick, Md., apparently in violation of a Presidential order, sources familiar with the matter reported today.
Ed Westfall will be back with the New York Islanders this season after spending the entire summer as an unsigned free agent, according to the National Hockey League's central registry office.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The functional literacy of 17-yearold high school students has increased slightly in recent years, the National Assessment of Education Progress reported today.

While believing that New York City has been mismanaged, 65 per cent of the American people feel that it must be kept from going bankrupt, the Harris poll reported yesterday. The sample also showed that 12 per cent did not believe in saving the city from bankruptcy, and 23 per cent had no opinion.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 8 Protestant political leaders voted overwhelmingly today against any sharing of administrative power with representatives of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 Independent barge owners in Belgium and the Netherlands won important concessions in freight rates and working conditions last week after staging spectacular and costly blockades of ports and waterways.

MONTESCUDAIO, Italy, Sept. 8 (AP) The American bred trotter, Wayne Eden, the first horse to be kidnapped in Italy, was released by his captors early today after three weeks. The horse was limping but in generally good condition, the police reported.

MEDFORD, Ore., Sept. 8 Water quality and leadership problems at Crater Lake National Park this summer have led to a re-evaluation of policies in the National Park Service, an official of the service says.
ATHENS, Sept. 7 Greece has announced a major effort to attract foreign capital and technology, particularly from the United States, as part of a new five-year plan for economic growth.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 8 (AP) A Finnish forest products company announced plans today for a $12-million sawmill and a multimillion-dollar pulpwood plant in south Mississippi.

Margaret Santry McEvoy, widow of Joseph P. McEvoy, who was a roving editor of Reader's Digest, died Sunday at her home, 231 East 48th Street. She was 72 years old.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Malaysia is speeding headlong down the road of development at a pace that her supporters say will in five years make her one of the most prosperous countries in Asia and that her critics say will blow her apart.

PARS, Sept. 8 (AP) Two gunmen escaped with $1.35million tonight after releasing unharmed seven hostages seized during a bank holdup and eluding the police in a high-speed chase.

The nation's fourth largest aluminum producer, Conalco, Inc., announced yesterday the election of E.G. Chaves as president and chief executive officer. On the morning of July 5, 1054, a minor star in the constellation Taurus appeared suddenly to explode into extraordinary brilliance. Ancient Chinese astronomers observed the event, which is now known to have been the supernova that created the Crab Nebula, and recorded that it was visible in daylight for 23 days before fading. It could be seen at night for another 633 days.

James A. McCullough, chief economist for the Wall Street firm of Scudder, Stevens Clark from 1952 until his retirement three years ago, died Sept. 2 in Homestead, Fla. He was 66 years old.

Charles Seligson, a leading specialist in bankruptcy law and creditor rights, died of cancer yesterday in the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

The Health Department has listed five more food establishments for having failed their second health-code inspection and warned that violations persisting at a third inspection could lead to closing orders.

After assessing the results of Tuesday's primary, Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, estimated yesterday that his chances of being re-elected to another twoyear term as county leader were 50-50.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Chilean Tennis Federation said today it would go ahead and play Sweden in the Davis Cup semifinals despite the withdrawal of its top player.

Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia will hold a hearing today on a petition of the Federal Government seeking to restrain the First National City Bank of New York from declaring the Penn Central Railroad in default on a $1.1million payment of principal and interest that was due on Aug. 15 on a second equipment loan.
A university professor's fear of testifying in a case connected to the Joseph Gallo murder led yesterday to dismissal of a perjury indictment against a man reputed to be linked to organized crime.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission is ending a long investigation of the financing of Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s unsuccessful Republican campaign for Governor in 1973, it was learned today.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 School attendance picked up here today, the third day of citywide public school integraton, but there was evidence of white flight from the school system as the result of the desegregation efforts.
Doubleday Co., Inc., the publishing house, said yesterday at its annual stockholders meeting that business in its first fiscal quarter ended July 31 was better than in the year-ago period.

The Citizens Committee to Save Jazz Radio, a recently formed group, said it filed a petition yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to block the sale of WRVR-FM by the Riverside Church to the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation.
Subway ridership in the first five days of the new 50-cent fare declined by 8.2 per cent from the same period last year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.
Charles Bolles Bolles-Rogers, assistant commissioner of the American Red Cross during World War II, died last Thursday at a retirement home in Sea Island, Ga. He was 91 years old.

Crude oil production in the United States fell to 8.26 million barrels a day last week, the lowest level since August, 1966, according to figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 Israeli planes struck at southern Lebanon this afternoon. Military headquarters here said the jets had attacked a guerrilla base beside a refute a camp three miles north of Tyre. The attack lasted 10 minutes and all the aircraft returned safely, it was reported.

NASHVILLE, Friday, Sept. 12 (AP) Convicts went on a rampage last night when the kitchen at the Tennessee State Prison ran out of pork chops and began substituting baloney for supper. One prisoner was shot and two other prisoners and two guards were injured.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 11 (UPI) A Federal judge rejected today the Government's attempt to jail two reluctant witnesses for their refusal to testify before a grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst case.

Mere outsiders can only guess at the intricate dealings that brought Prince Norodom Sihanouk back to his capital this week, after five-and-a-half years of exile. They are as mysterious as is his real status in the emerging power structure in Phnom Penh. The only point of clarity is that Prince Sihanouk is not a man to be ignored, whether by friend or foe, or anyone in between.

MARAWI, the Philippines, Sept. 4 Its bank has been ribbed by a gang of heavily armed soldiers, its radio station has been shot up, its president has been ousted for alleged corruption. The Philippine Government has poured millions of dollars into it in an effort to win the allegiance of Moslem dissidents, while Moslem rebels use it to recruit their guerrillas.

To Mies van der Rohe's famous dictum that less is more, the art of Richard Tuttle offers definitive refutation. For in Mr. Tuttle's work, less is unmistakably less. It is, indeed, remorselessly and irredeemably less. It establishes new standards of lessness, and fairly basks in the void of lessness. One is tempted to say that, so far as art is concerned, less has never been as less as this.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 12 (AP) One inmate is dead of stab wounds, and state officials said that 10 other inmates were shot by guards in a riot at the Tennessee State Prison. An additional 26 persons two of them guards were injured.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 Justice Department officials here are investigating "about a dozen" incidents of violence in connection with court-ordered busing for school desegregation here for possible Federal prosecution.

Governor Carey formally announced the appointment of Joseph P. Hoey yesterday as special deputy attorney general to investigate both the Suffolk County District Attorney and the Suffolk Police Commissioner.

BONN, Sept. 12 If their governments agree, military observers from the Soviet Union and other Communist countries of Europe will be able next month, for the first time, to watch a series of exercises by troops of the United States, Canada and West Germany.

ATHENS, Sept. 12 The commander of the prison camp in which political prisoners were tortured during the military dictatorship was sentenced today to 23 years in prison. His predecessor and successor as commandant received sentences of 20 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Herbert Stein, the immediate past chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the program for national economic planning that is being advocated by key Senators, professors and labor and business leaders simply would not work, even if it could be enacted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Attempts by Senate Democrats to stretch a proposed interim revival of oil price controls beyond Nov. 1 and restrict President Ford's powers during that period have irritated some Democrats in the House of Representatives, as well as Administration officials.

BALTIMORE The need for a new ethic of recreational sex is not a luxury or an option. It is an imperative from which there is no escape. Our old ethic is, like Venice, sinking imperceptibly into the sea. We have succeeded neither in shoring up the old customs and morality of sexual relationships nor in restructuring them to meet the new tide of history.

The financially troubled Singer Company announced yesterday that Donald P. Kircher, its 60-year-old president and chairman, has taken an indefinite leave of absence from the company because of ill health.

NEWARK, Sept. 12 (UPI) John Digilio, a reputed underworld boss, convicted on charges of masterminding a plot to steal files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on his suspected loan-sharking operation, was sentenced today to nine years in prison and fined $10,000.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 President Ford, defending his frequent plunges into crowds of well-wishers, declared here today that he had no intention of allowing the government of the people to be held hostage at the point of a gun.

The First National City Bank of New York, reacting to the sustained upward trend in in- terest rates in the credit markets, raised its prime lending rate yesterday to 8 per cent from 7 , the highest level since early March.

Robert F. Ardrey, senior executive director of the Children's Specialived Hospital in Mountainside, N.J., died Thursday at the Elizabeth (N.J.) Genleral Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 55 Duncan Hill Road, Westfield, N.J.
DALLAS, Sept. 12 Vice President Rockefeller, barnstorming in the South again, said today that he favored giving communities local option on busing to bring about racial integration of schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 At hearings before the National Labor Relations Board today, the Newspaper Guild argued that if reporters, editors and cartoonists were separated from other newspaper employes in labor negotiations it would "virtually destroy the collective bargaining relationship and practices in the news media."

The top-level trade delegation that arrived a week ago from China ended a four-day visit to New York yesterday with a group of bankers. The delegation is in the United States for the purpose of learning about the American economy and technology.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept 12 The majority of the amateur theatrical groups that dot New York's suburban communities are accustomed to performing familiar comedies or musicals before local audiences. Some aspire to dramatic merit and attract regional attention. Tonight, one group the Fort Hill Players of White Plains will move from the community to the international stage.

CAMAS, Wash. Within hours of landing here last spring among the first of l30,000 South Vietnamese refugees to seek new homes in the United States, Nguven Dinh Tri had found a job, earned his driver's license and purchased a used car.
Through these languid trading days on Wall Street, a campaign of last-ditch resistance is building up against the Congressionally mandated reform of the nation's stock exchanges.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 12 (Reuters) Nigeria's new military Government today dismissed 102 federal officials, including five permanent secretaries, in the largest single purge since the country's recent change of government.

Howard Cosell's "Saturday Night Live" weekly series doesn't begin on ABC until next Saturday at 8 P.M., but Cosell followers can see their curious hero tonight at 8 o'clock on "The Muhammad Ali Variety Special" The sportscaster briefly joins the boxing champion to resume one of the more successful acts in show business.

The number of public-employe strikes since the Taylor Law was passed by the Legislature in 1967 has averaged fewer than 20 a year amid thousands of negotiations in the eightyear period. But the statute's dispute procedures and penalties have failed to prevent major walkouts in some complex and hightly charged situations, such as the current teachers' strike here.
The Bureau of the Budget has identified, and is now using a computer to track down, $1.2billion in uncollected revenue owed the city by the Federal Government and the state over the last four years.

ROCKLAND, Me., Sept. 12 A. Alan Grossman, Knox County Judge of Probate since 1960, and the first chief justice of the Maine Probate Judges Assembly, died at his home here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12 This city's Democratic party organization suffered a stunning upset last night when Frank F. Logue, who was running on an "anti-machine" platform, defeated Mayor Bartholomew F. Guida for the mayoral nomination in the party's primary.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 12 (UPI) The new Bangladesh Government says the staggering economic and social situation of the country was the fault of the regime of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was assassinated in a coup on Aug. 15.
Federal officials have decided to cut off financing of the city's Addiction Services Agency, citing mismanagement and excessive administrative costs.
DALLAS, Sept. 12 (UPI) Mr. Reagan said today that he was not interested in the Vice- Presidency and would be a candidate for President or nothing in 1976.
The elimination of 102 daily train trips on IND and BMT subway lines, beginning Jan. 11, was announced by the Transit Authority yesterday.

The First National City Bank of New York, reacting to the sustained upward trend in interest rates in the credit markets, raised its prime lending rate yesterday to 8 per cent from 7 , the highest level since early March.

Morton-Norwich Products, Inc., has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $60-million sinking fund debentures due in 2000. Goldman, Sachs Co. will manage a nationwide group of underwriters who expect to offer the debentures in early October.
DILI, Portuguese Timor, Sept. 11 A burst of gunfire echoed and re-echoed today through the hot, humid air here as the leftwing Timorese Liberation Front held a victory celebration.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (AP) The legal fight of Bear Bryant, the Alabama football coach, over National Collegiate restrictions on the size of a traveling team landed in a Federal appeals court today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 12 (AP) Most of the remaining restrictions on demonstrations and rallies in Jefferson County were lifted today and 100 of the 400 state police called in to help control antibusing disturbances last weekend were sent home.

The sudden swing from near-agreement in the teachers' strike negotiations to the present outpouring of pessimism defies all logic and reason. When the Board of Education calls the outlook bleak and union president Albert Shanker says, "we're pretty far apart," it appears all too clear that the persistence of fiscal delusions carried over from the old days of backdoor settlements now constitutes the real roadblock to a settlement.

ROME, sept. 12 Carl Kalin, 73 years old, spry and an avid golfer, was in Rome today, sightseeing with his wife, Anne, walking the streets and still somewhat bewildered by what happened to him 12 years ago.
DELANO, Calif., Sept. 12 As the first week of elections for farm labor union representation neared a close today, the United Farm Workers had won 22 elections and the rival teamsters union 13.

Hoffa, will remain in the custody of the Government, a judge ruled today.

In the latest aspect of the government credit crisis, the state's Housing Finance Agency has turned to Governor Carey for emergency assistance to deal with its own mushrooming problems in the borrowing market.

A plot by organized crime groups to cash in on stolen United States Series E savings bonds has been smashed, according to Federal officials, with the arraignment in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of four persons on charges of conspiring to forge and cash $250,000 worth of stolen bonds.
PEKING, Sept. 12 Summer in downtown Peking is a testament to boredom. A policeman quietly trying to sort out a minor bicycle accident quickly draws a crowd of 25 to 50 people.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept 12 The majority of the amateur theatrical groups that dot New York's suburban communities are accustomed to performing familiar comedies or musicals before local audiences. Some aspire to dramatic merit and attract regional attention. Tonight, one group the Fort Hill Players of White Plains will move from the community to the international stage.

Joseph Rosensaft, a survivor of Nazi death camps and later a leader in efforts to keep alive the memory of the Holocaust, died of a heart attack Thursday while on a visit to London. He was 64 years old and had an apartment here.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 Two of four criminal charges have been dropped in the case against Frank DeMarco Jr., the lawyer accused of preparing false documents to give former President Nixon a tax advantage on a donation of his VicePresidential papers.
Federal officials have decided to cut off financing of the city's Addiction Services Agency, citing mismanagement and excessive administrative costs.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP) Joseph Kallinger's lawyers opened their case today, saying that Mr, Kallinger was innocent of an alleged fatherson robbery but, they added, even if he had committed the robbery, he would still be innocent on grounds of insanity.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 12 (UPI) The dollar advanced on European markets today, hitting 11-month highs in Frankfurt and Amsterdam. The price of gold dropped to its lowest price in almost a year on the London bullion market.

GLEN COVE, L.I, Sept. 12 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks successfully defended her women's Long Island match-play golf championship today at Nassau Country Club. She defeated Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the home club, 7 and 5, in the 36-hole title match.
Kenneth S. Axelson, a senior vice president and director of the J.C. Penney department-store chain, was appointed as the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance by Mayor Beame yesterday.

The Champlin Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corporation, announced yesterday that a definite agreement had been signed for the cash sale of its interest in British North Sea oil exploration. The purchaser of the interest, which is located in Block 211/18 in the British North Sea northeast of Scotland, is the Deutsche Erdolversorgunsgesellscharft G. m.b.H.-Deminix, a West German company.

After being pushed in a wheel chair to his first courtroom appearance since last April, Associate Justice William O. Douglas told newsmen in Yakima, Wash., that despite a crippling stroke, he intended to stay on the Supreme Court "as long as the work remains interesting and challenging."

Dr. Frithiof Borgeson, a member of the faculty of the New York University School of Education for 37 years, died Thursday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had lived in Harwich Pines, Mass., since his retirement in 1966.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 CBS, Inc., has introduced a new directional loudspeaker with baffles that enable sound to be aimed accurately toward the center of the room.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12 (AP) Finance Minister John J. Turner, long regarded as the heir to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's post, has left the Cabinet, in what could foreshadow a major reorganization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

C. Towner French, who served two terms, 1963 to 1965, as president of the Institute of Navigation, died Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 64 years old.

Strikes in the Canadian newsprint industry, which began on a limited scale in July, have now spread to the extent that almost a third of that country's capacity has been shut down. The Canadian industry exports about 90 per cent of its newsprint to newspapers in the United States.

Venezuela, which inspired the creation of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries 15 years ago, is devising plans to help poor nations finance OPEC's fourfold increase in oil prices since 1973.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 14 Cornelia Wallace has disclosed that she prayed "in tongues" with the Rev. Oral Roberts, while her husband, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was recovering from wounds inflicted in an assassination attempt, and that she then learned "the meaning of the baptism of the Holy Spirit."
The Traffic Department announced yesterday the suspension of some alternateside-of-the-street parking regulations for today, Yom Kippur.

H.E. Brandli, who retired in 1954 as president of the Cities Service Oil Company, marketing susbidiary of the Cities Service Company, died Saturday at his home, 25 East 83d Street. He was 90 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A quietly developed plan that would enable thousands of state-inspected slaughtering plants to begin shipping meat in interstate commerce, under consideration in the Department of Agriculture, has been attacked by a combination of Congressional, consumer and packing industry forces.

Deborah Burnham Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hinckley of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon, to David 'Theodore Berghorst, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oren Berghorst of Cadillac, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 The sleek John Hancock Building towers gracefully over the Boston skyline, a symbol of the city's economic power.
DILI, Portuguese Timor, Sept. 13 The civil war in Portuguese Timor has created a food shortage that could become a major problem.
PARIS, Sept. 15 France has invited major developed and developing countries to reconvene a preparatory meeting on energy and other problems of the world's rich and poor nations in Paris on Oct. 13.

The W.T. Grant Company, the store chain, which lost $111-million in the 26 weeks ended in July, reported yesterday that its 27 major banks had formally agreed to subordinate $300-million of loans to Grant's debts to venders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The White House succeeded in breaking a deadlock in the Pentagon on controversial aspects of a new Panama Canals treaty last summer, permitting the Ford Administration to resume stailed negotiations in Panama this month, top-level Washington officials said today.

NEWARK, Sept. 15 Teachers' strikes that delayed the return to classes of thousands of New Jersey students this month narrowed to two school systems, those in Hoboken and Englewood, as the 79 faculty members of Gloucester County College ended their walkout this morning.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 The Palestine Liberation Organization tonight dissociated itself from the hostage-taking in Madrid, but a radical Marxist group issued a statement endorsing it.

Prof. Ting-yee Kuo. founder of the Institute of Modern History of the Academia Sinica on Taiwan in 1955 and its director until 1972, died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 552 Riverside Drive.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Striking teachers prepared today to set up alternative schools in an attempt to get the city's 530,000 public school pupils back into the classrooms.

Frederick M. Winship, assistant managing editor of United Press International, will direct the news agency's worldwide newsfeature and enterprise service, it was announced yesterday by Paul. G. Eberhart, the agency's managing editor.
A cause that has managed to unite women from feminists to members of the Right to Life movement is the right to disability benefits for time lost due to pregnancy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has heard testimony that the Central Intelligence Agency transferred poison to an African outpost. In 1961 for use in killing Patrice Lumumba, the Congolese leader, but that the poison was never administered, sources familiar with the testimony said today.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) A gunman seeking to flee aboard an airliner that he had hijacked was shot and killed by a police marksman today after two hours of violence that left one of his four hostages critically wounded.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 15 (AP) Gov. Thomas P. Salmon of Vermont asked Gov. Elia T. Grasso of Connecticut today to hold a hearing before ordering the extradition of a Jericho, Vt., woman charged with conspiracy to kidnap her daughter.
WESTFIELD, Sept. 15 If you are one of the many Americans who can't tell a Nib from a Twizzler, don't fret. The condition is merely temporary, or so Y S Candies, Inc., earnestly hopes.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 Jaime Fillol will play for Chile against Sweden in the Davis Cup, after all.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, urged Congress today to ban the use of spray can gases, saying that it will take a decade to clear up the damage that such gases may already have done to the earth's ozone radiation shield.

Bridge enthusiasts who scour the emporiums of Fifth Avenue for books on their favorite game seldom realize that they are looking in the wrong place. By far the biggest collection of bridge books for sale in New York City is to be found in an obscure brownstone at 39 West 94th Street, the offices of The Bridge World Magazine (telephone, 866-5860).

The proposed settlement in the week-old teachers' strike is working its laborious way through the wrap-up process, with hopes high that classes will reopen tomorrow. Essential as is a swift end to the damaging interruption in the education of a million children, the peace terms reflect only dim awareness by either the United Federation of Teachers or the Board of Education of the desperateness of the city's financial crunch.
The Lay Faculty Association of New York, representin 328 teachers at 12 high schools, with 12,000 students, in the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) President Ford signed today an Executive order terminating the Presidential Clemency Board, created a year ago to help Vietnam war resisters clear their records and return to normal lives.

C.B.G.B., a tacky little club at 315 Bowery near Bleecker Street, has been presenting young local rock bands for several months. First there were a few tentative bookings, then a fullfledged "festival," and now things have been regularized with unknown bands on week nights and bands that have made something of a cult name for themselves on weekends.

My old stick-up man, John, stepped out of the shadows and pointed his gun. "As usual, sir, I'll start with your wallet," he said. I gave it to him, commenting that I was delighted to see he had still not found honest labor.

McAFEE, Sept. 15 Changing economic conditions and a management decision to alter the image of the former Playboy Club Hotel are bringing about a new look to the $33million resort at Great Gorge in this tiny Sussex County community.

Richard Hartshorne, retired senior judge of the Third United States District Court in Newark, died Sunday at a Bryn Mawr, Pa., nursing home. He was 87 years old and had moved with his family to Philadelphia less than a month ago after having resided in East Orange, N.J., for 58 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The United States has agreed with Israel as part of the recent Sinai accord to conduct a joint study of Israel's defense needs and to develop a contingency plan for military supply in case of a new Middle Eastern emergency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15, (Reuters) The Federal Reserve Board today outlined measures designed to give credit card holders greater legal protection including refusal to pay if they feel they have been sold "shoddy or defective merchandise."

A small but significant step has been taken by the State Office of Court Administration to control patronage one of the venerable hidden powers of political leaders that causes cynicism about the even-handedness of the judicial system in New York. Under a new set of guidelines, plums handed out to certain specialists practicing in the courts will be carefully recorded and supervised when compensation exceeds $100.

Steel production for the week ended Sept. 13 rose 4.6 per cent, the largest week-to-week increase this year and the fifth consecutive weekly gain, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Attorney General Bronson C. LaFollette of Wisconsin filed suit in Federal District Court here today against the Democratic National Committee challenging the 1976 delegate selection rules of the national Democratic party.

The Norma Gladys docked at Fulton Street and the East River yesterday, carrying with her a crew from Newfoundland and a story about the Grand Banks fishery. The story was that the fishery is being fished out.

LONDON, Sept. 15 Today marked the end of a novel experiment in Britain. A man who thought he could get along and prosper with British labor by running a company the American way conceded faliure, and decided to go into receivership.
The Reserve Oil Gas Company and Basin Petroleum Corporation announced jointly that they had signed a definitive merger agreement, which would ...

LONG BEACH. L.I., Sept. 15 Wearing a white bandage over his brow, Pete Stemkowski stood out like a sore eye today as the New York Rangers opened their National Hockey League training camp. A full complement of 34 players skated under the watchful eye of a new coach, Ron Stewart, at a new site, the Nassau County Arena.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 15 The key figure in New Hampshire's special Senate election tomorrow is a 45-yearold unemployed technical writer who stands about as much chance of winning as does the late Daniel Webster.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 15 William Craig, leader of a Protestant party, today withdrew his resignation as head of the 12 members of his party elected to a convention deliberating Ulster's constitutional future.

After more than 17 months without a first down in their labor dispute with the club owners, the National Football League players appear to be realizing that Ed Garvey is too stubborn to be a winning quarterback.

Canonization is a rare event in the life of the Roman Catholic Church. A saint has to be not only a good man or woman but a person of heroic virtues and unique sanctity. After years of study and analysis of the evidence of her life and work, the church has now inscribed the name of Elizabeth Ann Seton in its calendar of saints.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 Roscoe Tanner, the lightning southpaw server from Lookout Mountain, Tenn., was under inspection at the Pacific Southwest open tennis championships today. The new Davis Cup captain, Tony Trabert, was taking a look ...

SCHENECTADY. N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP) County officials should look to the Federal Government, and not the state, for more money to help pay for welfare programs, a top official of the State Social Services Department said today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 15 The Soviet Government reported today that it was prepared in principle to issue multiple-use exit and entry visas to American correspondents accredited in Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Dwight L. Chapin, onetime appointments secretary to President Nixon, asked the Supreme Court today to review his perjury conviction.

MY THO, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (Agence France-Presse) Since the war ended the Mekong Delta has apparently become a peaceful land, and My Tho, with its floating houses and promenades along the majestic Mekong River, is one of its most attractive cities.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 15 The mother-in-law of Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee, has charged in a $1-million suit that she was libeled when her former superior said on a television program that she had requested a 1 per cent salary kickback to the Republican party from a former county employe.
PARIS, Sept. 15 Conflicts between ethnic minorities and their governments have been flaring up again in Western Europe.

The American people believe by a 56 to 28 per cent majority that the nation will be in a recession this time next year, according to a Louis Harris survey released yesterday. The figures reflect a higher degree of pessimism than at any time since March.
"I've got a 10,000-acre oil field out there," said Arthur C. Elliot, salesman, speaking figuratively. "And nobody's drilling," added William J. Lucano, an associate, in the same vein.

Trading was slow in most commodity futures markets yesterday mostly because of the Jewish holiday observance. On the nation's largest exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat and soybeans drifted lower and corn held virtually steady.

Responding to American public opinion polls that protested large-scale assistance to Israel, a group of Jewish organizations has started a drive to win support for the United States Government's pledge to aid Israel.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 15 The wiretapping trial of two wealthy oil men, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, opens here tomorrow.

Thirteen influential faculty members at the University of Virginia are trying to have canceled the scheduled appearance on the Charlottesville campus of Nguyen Cao Ky, former Premier and Vice President of South Vietnam tomorrow night.

Jack Bell, a columnist for the Gannett News Service since his retirement in 1969 as chief political writer for the Associated Press, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after having suffered a massive stroke on Saturday. He was 71 years old.
The fast-growing charismatic movement is facing its first major difficulty as a result of a controversial teaching about church authority.

ROME, Sept. 15 (AP) Pope Paul VI urged United States churchmen today to make untiring efforts to preserve the Roman Catholic school system, begun in the early 19th century by St. Elizabeth Ann Seton, the first native-born American saint.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 15 (AP) The Grumman Aerospace Corporation acknowledged today that the cost of its F-14 Tomcat fighter had increased $2-million per plane this year, but attributed the increase to the Government's cut in the company's rate of production.

Margaret Thatcher, on her first visit here since becoming leader of the Conservative party in Britain, charged last night that 30 years of expansion of the welfare state had caused major damage by curbing British growth.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 President Anwar el-Sadat, in a defiant and angry speech, pledged tonight that no amount of pressure from the Soviet Union, the Palestinians or any other source would cause Egypt to deviate from the policy he had chosen for her.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Industrial production rose strongly in August, further evidence of recovery in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Unhealthy levels of the toxic chemical PCB have been found in fish in three more state waterways, prompting the State Environmental Conservation Department to begin planning a broadened campaign to detect, analyze and possibly combat the compound.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Sept. 16 For the fourth consecutive night, delegates were working to wind up the special session of the United Nations General Assembly by overcoming remaining disagreements on ways to bridge the gap between rich and poor nations.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 American new car sales were off 7.5 per cent in early September compared with the like period last year, but the annual selling rate was up from August due to early deliveries of some 1976 models by the General Motors Corporation dealers.

Prices drifted down on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the Amex market value index closing at 82.67, off 0.61. Volume moved up to 1,127,000 from 1,120,000 despite the Jewish holiday observance.

John J. Fitzgerald, a retired major general in the New York National Guard who commanded the artillery of the 42d Infantry Division, died Sunday at his home, 17 Oswego Avenue, Long Beach, L.I. He was 70 years old.
Standard Poor's, the investment rating service, warned yesterday that any further state emergency assistance to the city would jeopardize the state's credit rating and fiscal integrity.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15 (AP) A suit designed to spark the enactment of a constitutionat amendment that would ends school busing to achieve desegregation was filed in Federal court today by Gov. Julian Carroll.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 (AP) A New Delhi high court overturned the jailing of a prominent journalist today, ruling that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi must be prepared with specific charges to back up her use of the Internal Security Act to arrest critics of her Government.

BEIRUT, Sept. 15 The Economic Commission of the Ogranization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to convene tomorrow in Vienna with several important member states pushing for an increase in the price of oil.
HONG KONG, Sept. 15 The movie "Jaws" hasn't come here yet, and apparently most people still haven't heard of it, either.

Papua New Guinea, in joining the ranks of the world's independent states, is seeking to change its image as "the stone age island." Its size, about 180,000 square miles, and population, roughly three million, it is comparable to New Zealand. But with a wide range of tribal groups speaking a variety of languages, a sense of national identity and unity appears to be a major problem.
One of the engaging sidelights of the resort collections opening on Seventh Avenue this month is the prevalence of little handbags swinging on a chain from shoulder or waistline.
A computerized data bank will be set up by the National Wildlife Federation in its headquarters in Washington as a Bicentennial project to help to save the American bald eagle from extinction.
Working under the glare of intensive publicity and the scrutiny of an angry Mayor, the Sanitation Department yesterday bent to the task, ordered by Mr. Beame, of cleaning up the city by Saturday.

LONDON, Sept. 15 At 6 A.M. yesterday, a small union local in a Welsh steel town sent one of its members, a "waterman," into a huge new blast furnace that the stateowned British Steel Corporation says it needs to survive. He was told to check the cooling pipes, He refused.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 15 A key witness in the sodomy case against Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk County District Attorney, has sworn to investigators that Roger Barry Petersen, the 21-year-old unemployed handyman who made the accusation against the prosecutor, lied and that Mr. Petersen even passed a lie detector test and then boasted about it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission accused Safeway Stores Inc, the nation's largest supermarket chain, today of cheating consumers by advertising food at sale prices but selling it at regular prices. The loss to shoppers, one commission lawyer said, has been "substantial" over the years, although no complete dollar estimate has been made.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 15 Jack and Micki Scott, the sports activists, have in recent months raised the hopes of both the authorities and the family of Patricia Hearst that they might help to find the missing 21-year-old girl, or at least provide clues to her condition and feelings.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 15 A suit by five Roman Catholics, including two nuns, against the Most Rev. Daniel T. Cronin, Bishop of Fall River, has led to a controversy over whether the five plaintiffs have been excommunicated for their action against the Bishop.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today that it was selling the Hollywood-Burbank Airport, which it owns.

MADRID, Tuesday, Sept. 16 Four Palestinian guerrillas flew to Algiers today with three hostages from the Egyptian Embassy here after a day in which they forced their way into the embassy and threatened to blow it up unless Egypt scrapped her disengagement agreement with Israel.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation has been forced to become a full-time borrowing agency devoted to selling the city to local and national investors, without ever exercising the budgetary functions it was given when it was formed in June.

Last-minute snags delayed an expected agreement last night between the teachers' union and the Board of Education, but Albert Shanker, the union's president, said he was still hopeful that the problems could be resolved soon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 Secretary General Waldheim warned today that the Sinai agreement must not be allowed to create "dangerous" complacency and called far a Middle East settlement that would include "recognition of the rights of the Palestinian people."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Commerce Department announced today that it intended to impose an embargo on some imported tuna fish, a move that could cut off much of the tuna sold in the United States.

Connecticut's deer-hunting regulations have been substantially changed this year, but any attempt to tersely describe them leaves one crying for madder music and stronger wine, for they are an incredible blend of sound management procedures and political expediency.

As Yom Kippur the 24hour-period of fasting and prayer ended at sundown yesterday, rabbis in sermons called on the Kremlin to grant Soviet Jews religious freedom and their right to emigrate, and cited Israel's willingness to achieve a permanent peace in the Middle East.

The Norma Gladys docked at Fulton Street and the East River yesterday, carrying with her a crew from Newfoundland and a story about the Grand Banks fishery. The story was that the fishery is being fished out.
The Rev. Dr. O.P. Kretzmann, president emeritus of Valparaiso University in Indiana, died Sunday. He was 74 years old.

OROVILLE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) The Oroville area, shaken last month by an earthquake that measured 6.1 on the Richter scale, has sunk about six inches in relation to the Sierras, according to a Federal study.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 President Anwar el-Sadat, in a defiant and angry speech, pledged tonight that no amount of pressure from the Soviet Union, the Palestinians or any other source would cause Egypt to deviate from the policy he had chosen for her.

Larry Christiansen won the United States Junior Invitational Championship in Norristown, Pa., for the third time this year. The only consolation his fallen opponents have now is that he became 20 years old during the 1975 event and thus ineligible for the 11th competition in the series, planned for next June.

The Amstar Corporation raised the wholesale price of industrial sugar 20 cents a hundred pounds, effective today. This brings the price for a hundred pounds of extra-fine granulated to $23.55 and raises the price for two other industrial grades bulk granulated and liquid No. 2 to $22.95 a hundred pounds.
Liza Davis Pulitzer, daughter of Lilly Pulitzer, the designer, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., last evening to Robert Lee Terry Jr., a freelance cinematographer.

Eleventh-hour negotiations and mediation to avert a strike against 12 Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New York broke down last night, 12 hours before a strike deadline of 8 o'clock this morning.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 15 A new phase in efforts against pollution was marked today as some 800 scientists, engineers and public officials from 40 nations met for five days of discussions about monitoring of the environment.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 Societe Imetal, the French firm controlled by the Rothschild family that wants to purchase the stock of the Copperweld Corporation, began to fight back today against efforts by Copperweld to block the sale.
The nation's top thoroughbred of 1975 could be decided by the $350,000 National Championships on Nov. 1 at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif....

YONKERS, Sept. 15 Can a city and its governing council be held in contempt of court? Yonkers may find out next Monday if its Council continues to withhold permission for Sarah Lawrence College to build new dormitories.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Industrial production rose strongly in August, further evidence of recovery in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The New York Knicks have signed Larry Fogle, their second-round draft choice, to a multiyear contract.

PARIS, Sept. 15 France has invited major developed and developing countries to reconvene a preparatory meeting on energy and other problems of the world's rich and poor nations in Paris on Oct. 13.

The stories about the possible dangerous effects of aerosol on the atmosphere are having their impact on the marketplace. Manufacturers of products sold in aerosol cans are rushing out with new containers that do not use the suspect fluorocarbon propellant.

Dwight Evans drove in four runs with four hits and Fred Lynn and Jim Rice each drove in their 100th runs last night at Fenway Park in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 9-7 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

The Giants, the Jets and the 24 other teams of the National Football League trimmed their rosters yesterday to the required 43 players in advance of the scheduled start of the season on Sunday.

Interest rates continued to rise yesterday as the credit markets braced for the sale of $3-billion of two-year Treasury notes that are expected to carry rates of 8 per cent or more.
Pan American World Airways made a new effort yesterday to gain an entry into the 48-state domestic market by proposing a New York-San Francisco round-trip fare of $199.

CHEYNEY, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP) Six Cheyney State College students, all from nearby Philadelphia, were suspended today in connection with the hazing death of a Coatesville freshman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Iran disassociated itself today from oil cartel "extremists" and said it would support a modest oil price increase when the 14-member organization meets next week in Vienna.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Two academic celebrities, an academic-politician and a businessman-celebrity are forming a national organization called Non-New Yorkers to Save New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Sept. 18 She didn't look like the focus of a nationwide search. She didn't look like an heiress. She looked, instead, like someone who might stand unnoticed in an all-night cafeteria.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The House passed today a compromise bill that reduces the price of school lunches for low-middle-income children when free lunches are served to poverty-level students.

The city's 1.1 million pupils returned to school yesterday and, in many instances, found oversized classes, confused conditions and general discontent over the outcome of the week-long teachers' strike.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 18 Joseph P. Hoey, the special state prosecutor for Suffolk County, is investigating reports that there was a plot to blackmail Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, and that it was allegedly conceived by Roger Barry Petersen, who has accused Mr. O'Brien of sodomy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Critics used to complain about Presidents secluding themselves in the White House or at personal vacation enclaves. Not so with President Ford.

SUDR, Sept. 18 Israeli soldiers this week cleared antitank minefields from this area, which is to be the first to be evacuated under the new interim agreement with Egypt. And barbed-wire entanglements that had surrounded the minefields were gathered today and trucked to a new front.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 After deliberating less than one hour, a jury of six men and six women today convicted Joseph Kallinger of burglary and the binding and robbery of four women at a suburban home here last Dec. 3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 A House committee was told today that it will initially cost the United States $7-million to $10-million to establish the facilities for 200 civilian technicians and post them in the Sinai passes to monitor the latest Egyptian-Israeli agreement.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 The first phase in the courtordered re-examination of the Robert F. Kennedy assassination case was completed today after the chief ballistics expert in the case ended his testimony.
Unionized musicians struck Broadway in a contract dispute last night that shut down all of the nine musical productions of a young fall season billed as one of the biggest in years.

WASHINGTON From 1964 to 1974 we as a people underwent a gradual but truly profound change in our sense of national priorities. Domestic concerns pressed steadily to the forefront. Internationalist sentiment eased. Support for isolationist positions grew.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP) Steven Weed, 28 years old, who was engaged to marry Patricia Hearst, said today he was "relieved" at news of her safe capture. 'Obviously, I want to see her," he added.

LAS VEGAS, Nev.., Sept. 18 A plaster compound used in countless buildings put up from the nineteen-thirties to 1973 presents a continuing cancer hazard to occupants, an international scientific conference was told today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 The Jets' two-day-old Strike, designed to force an agreement between the players and management, as well as to show support for the New England Patriots, ended today, perhaps successfully.

In many ways, the Harrises, Emily and William, are the stereotype young revolutionaries of America's turbulent late nineteen-sixties and early seventies. They came from white, uppermiddle-class families, families with money and a more or less conservative outlook.

The United States Steel Corporation filed yesterday "countervailing duty complaints" with the Treasury Department seeking relief from alleged "unfair trade practices" by seven European Economic Community nations.
Three days of confirmation hearings last week on the controversial nomination of Joseph Coors to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting ended unresolved.

Linda Ronstadt's last album, "Heart Like a Wheel," was the record that made her a superstar. But No. 1 albums that result in two No. 1 singles are hard to follow. Miss Ronstadt has always made lovely records, but one had every right to wonder if her next record could be as extraordinarily satisfying and strikingly commercial as the last one.
The appointment of David E.C. Steel, deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., as chairman of the company was announced yesterday in London.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 18 Jordan rejected today conditions set by President Ford for the sale of Hawk antiaircraft missiles as "insulting to national dignity" and indicated she might buy Soviet surface-to-air missiles instead.

Charlie Rouse, the tenor saxophonist who followed along in the scintillating wake of Thelonious Monk's piano in Mr. Monk's quartet for many years, is leading a group of his own this week at the Five Spot, 2 St. Mark's Place.
On a foggy night 19 months ago, Patricia Campbell Hearst was dragged screaming from her Berkeley, Calif., apartment by a white woman and two black men who covered their escape with rifle fire.
The operator of the Westchester Nursing Home was indicted yesterday on charges of permitting filthy and hazardous conditions in the home, at 245 East Prospect Avenue, Mount Vernon.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 Home-mortgage rates are moving up again, threatening to cause more problems for the nation's housing industry just as it is inching out of its worst recession in more than a decade. Most of the country's largest savings and loan associations and many commercial banks have raised their basic home-mortgage rates by one-quarter to one-half of a percentage point during the last two weeks or so.

A double murder in an apparent burglary in well-to-do Forest Hills Gardens took the lives yesterday of the sister and brother-in-law of the owner of Lundy's, a long-established seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay.

After a lengthy search for an outside expert to serve as the new special deputy state controller for the city, Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday turned to his own staff and named Sidney Schwartz, currently the state's chief auditor in the city.
Three days of confirmation hearings last week on the controversial nomination of Joseph Coors to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting ended unresolved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The controversy over whether some spray can gases are imperiling the vital ozone layer over the earth has "significantly damaged" the aerosol industry even though the theory is unproved, an official of a major can maker said today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Sept. 18 A state Supreme Court justice told the striking teachers of the Half Hollow Hills school district today to return to their classrooms tomorrow morning "as evidence of good faith."
NEWARK, Sept. 18 (AP) The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today granted New Jersey Bell a rate increase to provide more than $59.9-million a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met today with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger to discuss a new treaty limiting nuclear arms and later said that "some differences" remained.

LONDON, Sept. 18 The Rank Organization, the British entertainment conglomerate whose movies begin with a man striking a gong, ended a week of turmoil in the executive suite today by dismissing its chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Federal Power Commission has said that it believes Charles H. Tenney 2d, chairman of the Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., in New York State, is overpaid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today the major industrial nations still face serious financial problems because of higher oil prices. He said they need an international financing fund that has been proposed.

Gen. James M. Gavin remembers parachuting into a turnip patch with a member of the Dutch Resistance at his side. Lieut. Comdr. Arnoldus Wolters remembers packing into the invasion glider for his return to the Netherlands a teddy bear for an infant daughter he had never seen. Mrs. Cornelius Ryan remembers the sight of her author-husband limping across the bridge at Arnhem that he had written about.
If the holders of debt securities of the seven bankrupt Northeastern railroads soon to be merged into Conrail, a Government-supported railway, are confused and depressed, it is understandable.
The weather is changing, marking a new season in New York in a time of change that heralds a beginning so much more dramatically than do the dreary days that tailgate Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Both corporate profits and the Gross National Product for the second quarter were revised upward today by the Commerce Department.
Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.
Many a bridge Walter Mitty sits at home dreaming of international success. If only I had the chance, he muses, I could play as well as any of them perhaps better.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 18 (UPI) Robert Mottershead, a 45-year-old Little Silver stockbroker, was judged innocent by reason of insanity in the shooting death of his two children, who were slain in their beds on Aug. 16, 1974.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 There may be at least two political warnings for President Ford in the unexpectedly large victory of Democrat John Durkin in the special New Hampshire Senate election. Both have more to do with Mr. Ford's own prospects than with the length of his political coattails.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP) More than 400 women and children marched to City Hall today to protest cuts in the city's day-care program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The controversy over whether some spray can gases are imperiling the vital ozone layer over the earth has "significantly damaged" the aerosol industry even though the theory is unproved, an official of a major can maker said today.
A jury in State Supreme Court here yesterday acquitted Dr. Daniel Manfredi, a surgeon, of charges of illegally prescribing amphetamines to an undercover agent posing as a patient.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18 The outcome of the special session dealing with the global economic and social north-south lopsidedness is widely viewed at United Nations headquarters as a reflection of the growing awareness in the third world that it needs the advanced nations especially the United States and will need them for quite some time.

A double murder in an apparent burglary in well-to-do Forest Hills Gardens took the lives yesterday of the sister and brother-in-law of the owner of Lundy's, a long-established seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay.

Arnoldus Woiters remembers packing into the invasion glider for his return to the Netherlands a teddy bear for an infant daughter he had never seen. Mrs. Cornelius Ryan remembers the sight of her author-husband limping across the bridge at Arnhem that he had written about.

Broadway on a night at the beginning of the most prosperous theater season in years: taxicabs pull up to the theater, people get out, look anticipatingly at the brightly lit marquee. "A Chorus Line," Chicago," "The Wiz." The sold-out sign is up at the box office. The lobby is filled, but the theater is empty. The musicians are on strike and the show does not go on.
Home runs by Mike Schmidt and Greg Luzinski and Steve Carlton's four-hit pitching carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night.

With the new season's general level of mediocrity, television executives have enough to worry about, but now they are nervously preparing to contend with "Space: 1999," a science-fiction series produced in Britain. "Space: 1999" is not a network show. It is being syndicated station by station, and it has already been sold to 155 stations, the vast majority of them network affiliates.

HAWTHORNE, Sept. 18 Striking teachers in the Hawthorne school district reached a tentative contract settlement late today and agreed to return to their classrooms tomorrow morning pending a ratification vote.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) Arab oil nations are beginning to shift their investments from Britain to the United States and Western Europe, the Bank of England reported today.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 Governor Byrne's $600-million transportation bond issue cleared the New Jersey Legislature today amid warnings that it was already fatally crippled by opposition of environmentalists and by New York City's fiscal crisis, and that there was not enough time to sell it to the voters in November.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Glomar Explorer which retrieved part of a sunken Soviet submarine, is free to go to sea again while the Federal and county governments wrangle over her tax status in a stalled court action.
Hot, scratchy, binding, drab. Robert Diamond, a director of television shows and father of an 8-year-old boy, remembers those suits of his childhood.
