LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 18 It's true the British once won at Fort Ligonier, named after one of their field marshals. But that was in 1758, and it was French and Indian forces they beat, not the Americans. And they had the help of a colonel named G. Washington.
MADRID, Sept. 18 (AP) Three men and two women who said they were pregnant were sentenced to death today for the shotgun slaying of a policeman last Aug. 16.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter marekt rose yesterday as traders took advantage of lower prices that resulted from several days of declines.

HOUSTON, Sept. 18 M.W. (Freddie) Speights was standing next to some burning garbage five years ago. He was 50 years old and depressed. His publishing business had just gone broke. Then, there in the ashes, he found the makings of a new life buttons.
The Sperry Rand Corporation said yesterday that it was seriously considering whether to buy the Xerox Corporation's computer customer base.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 18 (UPI) The dollar made fresh gains on most European money markets today, again reaching new highs for the year, while the price of gold sank to its lowest level in more than a year. The pound fell to another low against the dollar, but held modest gains against Continental currencies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Officials of the Federal Reserve Board have promised a group of women members of Congress to make some changes in the proposed regulations outlawing discrimination against women in the granting of credit.

The police have identified the two suspects in the kiling of two police officers on Tuesday night, but fear that releasing either their names or pictures would jeopardize any court case that might be brought against them.
The New York Rangers have a Problem that the New York Islanders could solve if the teams cared to merge, a fantasy that could occur only in the minds of hockey fans.

FISHING LINE The Seafood Playhouse, a restaurant at 209 West 48th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, is presenting these days what is said to be the first chorus line in a major Broadway nightclub since the closing of the Latin Quarter in 1969.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (UPI) Wendy Masako Yoshimura, arrested today with Patricia Hearat, is a Japanese-American artist who was born in a relocation camp. She disappeared in 1972 after being indicted in a plot to bomb a Navy Reserve Officers Training Corps building at the University of California.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 The Government of India today sharply rebuked President Ford for his criticism of the state of emergency under which thousands of political dissidents have been arrested in this country.
ROME, Sept. 18 (AP) Bishop Dolegiewicz of Canada won the shot-put with a distance of 63 feet 9 inches today in the opening of the World University Games for track and field.

NEWARK, Sept. 18, (AP) A 27-year-old Brick Township man held two years in Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital as insane since his acquittal in the fatal shooting of a Roman Catholic priest was looking for a job today and trying to readjust to the outside world.
Unionized musicians struck Broadway in a contract dispute last night that shut down all of the nine musical productions of a young fall season billed as one of the biggest in years.

The City Council, acting with unusual speed, elected David N. Dinkins as City Clerk yesterday and half an hour later Mayor Beame swore him into the $37,344-a-year position. The Mayor had recommended him for the post earlier this week.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 18 Unlike last year's football players' strike, no picket signs adorned the Giants' practice site today. There weren't even any pickets: That's because there weren't any strikers. There weren't any strikers because there wasn't any strike.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Senate voted today to limit pay increases for members of Congress and 3.5 million other Federal employes to the 5 per cent proposed by President Ford.

The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City has proposed some dramatic and controversial governmental reforms that would significantly alter the balance of power on questions of city policy among the Mayor, Board of Estimate, City Council, Controller and Council President.

WHITTIER, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI) The Greek-based Onassis shipping empire and the Uco Oil Company of Whittier, Calif., have formed a partnership to conduct petroleum refining and shipping activities, a Uco spokesman confirmed today.

After a lengthy search for an outside expert to serve as the new special deputy state controller for the city, Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday turned to his own staff and named Sidney Schwart, currently the state's chief auditor in the city.
TOKYO, Sept. 18 The dollar shot up against the Japanese yen under heavy buying on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, reaching 300 yen for the first time in eight months.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 18 (Reuters) Luis Cardinal Concha Cordoba, former primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia, died here today of heart failure following complications of a stomach ailment. He was 84 years old and had been retired for the last nine years. His death leaves the Sacred College of Cardinals with 123 members.

PARIS, Sept. 18 The French Government and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation are moving toward an agreement in which Westinghouse would reduce its 45 per cent interest in the Framatome Corporation, a key company in French nuclear technology, and the French atomic energy agency would acquire an important stake.

The sharp drop in gold futures continued yesterday, with the October contract on the Commodity Exchange dropping to a new low of $135 an ounce before closing at $136 1/10, off $6.40. In two days it has dropped almost $10 an ounce.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 Patricia Hearst, the wealthy kidnapping victim who proclaimed herself a revolutionary and was accused of being a bank robber, was captured here this afternoon by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LIVINGSTON, N.J. The National Burn Victim Foundation and St. Barnabas Hospital are making, a major effort to make operational the 12-bed burn treatment unit at St. Barnabos Medical Center here, the only such facility in the state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) President Ford's Clemency Board was stacked with antiwar liberals who distorted the intent of the program, urged prison inmates to apply and voted clemency in cases involving civilian felony convictions, including rape and murder, four board members say.

PARIS, Sept. 19 A group of Arab countries has pledged some $25-million to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization more than enough to replace the funds the United States is withholding because of UNESCO's anti-Israeli actions.

MANILA, Sept. 19 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today he had dismissed 2,000 Government and military officials as "traitors" to his New Society program and warned that the purge had only begun. Several department heads were dismissed on charges of corruption.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 19 (AP) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he sees the possibility of this white-ruled nation someday having a black prime minister and a multiracial cabinet.
Two accidents involving four buses closed one New Yorkbound tube at the height of the rush hour yesterday morning. Nineteen persons were slightly injured and traffic was delayed up to two hours.
STARKE, Fla., Sept. 19 After 12 years in jail for someone else's crime, Freddie Pitts and Wilbert Lee walked out of prison here today, into the bright autumn sunshine and new lives as free men.
Fairfield Porter, an artist whose realist style influenced many younger painters, died Thursday in Southampton, L.I., where he had lived since 1949. He was 68 years old.

A man who had refused to pay the 50-cent fare at a Brooklyn subway station was shot and killed last night when he allegedly lunged with a knife at a transit police officer who was pursuing him, the police reported.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 The Supreme Court, delivering at least a temporary setback to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, today postponed a decision on her appeal against her conviction in June of violating election laws.

A noise that sounded like the slamming of a door early Thursday morning on a quiet street in Forest Hills Gardens Queens, is now believed by the police to have been the sound of the shot that killed 67-year-old Elaine Lundy during the double murder that also took the life of her 80year-old brother-in-law.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which helped design the elaborate fiscal rescue mechanism for the city, is now considering whether it should come to the aid of the New York City Educational Construction Fund, an independent agency that faces possible default within a week.
Leaders of the City University believe that the muchpublicized debate with state offials over continuation of the university's no-tuition policy is essentially a "smokescreen" for

A group of 55 prominent New Yorkers formed the Citizens Committee for New York City yesterday and pledged to support efforts by public officials and private groups to reverse the city's financial downslide.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (UPI) The police raided two safety deposit boxes in a downtown bank today and recovered 35, rare Greek and Roman coins, part of a collection stolen from a museum at Harvard University two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept 19 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that it would be better to tackle unemployment by providing low-wage government jobs for anyone willing to take them than by further pumping up the economy through budget deficits and a rapid rise in money and credit.
May Davie, a civic and political leader here, died yesterday of heart failure at her home. She was in her 80's and lived at 71 East 71st Street and in Newport, R.I.

In the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon Marguerite Stewart Rule, a model, was married to Yerger Johnstone, a vice president with Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., investment bankers. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony.
HAWTHORNE, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP) A tentative settlement was reached this morning in the 11-day Englewood teachers' strike.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) Jack Alexander, former newspaperman and editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died Wednesday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 73 years old.
The Metropolitan Opera orchestra, whose members voted Thursday to authorize a strike, plans to report to work for the first scheduled rehearsals Monday.
Black paint was lossed by a vandal early yesterday on a statue of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton in lower Manhattan.

After a sharp decline since Monday, gold futures moved up a little yesterday, possibly due to bargain hunting by traders. The October delivery on the Commodity Exchange closed at $136 7/10 an ounce, up from $136 1/10.

MADRID, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The police said today that two Basque nationalist guerrillas were killed and at least 18 persons arrested in raids that led to gun battles in Madrid and Barcelona yesterday.

With solid support from black and Puerto Rican district leaders, Frank G. Rossetti, who has been Manhattan Democratic leader since 1967, was reelected by the organization's executive committee yesterday for another two-year term.
Jean-Luc Ponty, who will be at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, through tomorrow night, is a musician of overflowing gifts. The trouble is that he doesn't make very interesting music.

DELAWARE, Ohio. Sept. 19 (AP) Seatrain, lightly raced and lightly regarded, defeated the favorite, Nero, in the first division and then defeated Polaris Lobell in the race-off today to win the Little Brown Jug, the middle jewel of pacing's triple crown.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 19 William M. Ellinghaus, a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board established by the state to oversee New York City's finances, said today that "it is quite unlikely" that the city would be able to borrow money again on its own by December.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19 Yale University and the Town of Old Saybrook, Conn., kissed and made up here today, ending a 257-year-old tiff over a handful of overdue books and a few bruised knuckles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The staff of the Council on Wage and Price Stability says the American steel industry is one of limited competition and therefore can resist basic market forces that might otherwise force down prices.

With solid support from black and Puerto Rican district leaders, Frank G. Rossetti, who has been Manhattan Democratic leader since 1967, was reelected by the organization's executive committee yesterday for another two-year term.

Matt Helm is a private detective played by Tony Franciosa. His new series begins tonight at 10 on ABC. Bronk is a police detective played by Jack Palance. His new series begins tomorrow night at 10 on CBS. And the new television season proceeds apace along familiar ruts.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP) A 16-yearold boy who apparently won the Connecticut $10,000 instant lottery may end up with nothing at all.
MELVILLE, L.I., Sept. 19 The striking teachers call Gladys Singer "scab." They carry picket signs with her name on them. But Mrs. Singer continues to work as a substitute in her own school district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Jordanian officials informed the United States privately today that King Hussein had dropped his apparent objections and had agreed to accept all the conditions imposed by President Ford for the sale to Jordan of 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles.

James Andrew Kennedy, a founder and principal executive of Today's Consumer, Ltd., an economic consultant firm for commercial banks and sayings institutions at 109 East 29th Street, died of cancer Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived here.

A group of 55 prominent New Yorkers formed the Citizens Committee for New York City yesterday and pledged to support efforts by public officials and private groups to reverse the city's financial downslide.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 A "cold trail" that led to a set of fingerprints in a Pennsylvania farmhouse eventually wended its tortuous way to Patricia Hearst in a second-floor Mission District apartment here yesterday.

Much too quickly, Rennie Stennett of the Pittsburgh Pirates has dissolved into the small print of the box scores. His accomplishment of seven hits in seven times at bat in the Pirates' 22-0 conquest of the Chicago Cubs deserves to be chiseled in marble. It deserves to be hailed in song in Panama where he grew up. It deserves to be toasted in Three Rivers Stadium with champagne.
The short interest position as of Sept. 15, rose to 24,516,000 shares from 22,801,000 as of, Aug. 15, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 An attempt by the voters of Massena, N.Y., to take over an operate the local power company received a setback here today when a Public Service Commission examiner issued a complicated earnings estimate for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation facilities in the upstate town.
LISBON, Sept. 19 After a political crisis and a threat of civil war, Portugal has announced the formation of a government that reflects the results of last April's elections.

Encouraging news on the inflation front a sharp decline in the rate of growth in the consumer price index for August aided stock prices yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a sizable advance for the second consecutive day accompanied by increased volume.

PARIS, Sept. 19 A group of Arab countries has pledged some $25-million to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization more than enough to replace the funds the United States is witholding because of the agency's anti-Israeli actions.
Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., which already owns two-thirds of the Paris-based firm of Morgan Cie. International, said yesterday that it would acquire the remaining third...

Consumer prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose a bit in August as declines in the prices of some foods offset increases in the cost of apparel and of transportation, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

NEWARK, Sept. 19 Judge Melvin P. Antell today dissolved a seal on two documents that describe the business and political dealings of Anthony J. Grossi, president of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, with George Katz, a garbage contractor and long-time friend.

A state mediator has called a meeting for next week between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and lay teachers at 325 Catholic elementary and high schools in the city and upstate in an effort to avert a strike threatened for Monday.

Yesterday, the day after Mayor Beame told his cabinet not "to come up with wish lists" for capital projects, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation disclosed its proposed budget, with some requests its officials conceded could be described as "wishful thinking." Included in the corporation's proposed capital budget was $840,000 for the design of a 400-bed geriatric center on Staten Island that is estimated to cost $23.2-million, which has not been allocated.

HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 19 A three-member panel of Air Force officers took 4 hours 27 minutes today to conclude that T.Sgt. Leonard P. Matlovich, a homosexual, was unfit for military service. The panel recommended that he be severed from service with a general discharge.

Private economists yesterday welcomed the news that inflation slowed dramatically in August. But they, like the Ford Administration, expect consumer prices to move up faster again than the August rate during the remainder of this year.

An attempt by former President Richard M. Nixon to resign from the state bar has been rejected by a New York court because he has not admitted wrongdoing in connection with the Watergate scandal, sources familiar with the secret legal proceeding said yesterday.

OXFORD, Md. A pair of stately swans, escorted by a half-dozen brown mallards, paddle smoothly under the timbered ferry slip here, gliding forward like surfers on the tumbling wave of a fullastern propeller wash. Gunning the engine from the white wheelhouse, Capt. Gilbert C. Clark brings his 50year-old double-end ferry boat to a practiced, gentle bump against the creaking automobile ramp.
STARKE, Fla., Sept. 19 After 12 years in jail for someone else's crime, Freddie Pitts and Wilbert Lee walked out of prison here today, into the bright autumn sunshine and new lives as free men.

The Professional Staff Congress, the City University's faculty union, petitioned the State Public Employment Relations Board yesterday to mediate the impasse that has developed in its contract negotiations with the Board of Higher Education.

A controversial auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet of works by Long Island artists brought $108,675 Thursday evening for the benefit of Guild Hall, the arts center in East Hampton. Of the 90 paintings, drawings and sculptures by well-known and lesser-known artists, only slightly more than half were sold, with few going at their minimum estimates.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 19 William M. Ellinghaus, a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board established by the state to oversee New York City's finances, said today that "it is quite unlikely" that the city would be able to borrow money again on its own by December.

LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 19 The American team of golf professionals routed their British-Irish counterparts today in the opening round of the 21st Ryder Cup matches. The Americans won six of their eight matches, lost one and tied one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senator James L. Buckley and 11 other challengers of the new Federal campaign financing laws told the Supreme Court today that the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had "wholly failed" to examine the impact of the new laws and instead "uncritically deferred" to Congress when it upheld nearly all of the new legislation last Au- gust.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Sept. 20 Fighting continued in Beirut yesterday, with the southeastern suburbs of Ain el-Rummaneh and Chiyah resounding to sniper, rocket and mortar fire.
The New York Mets, who used to smile when Yogi Berra would say "You're not out of it till you're out of it," stopped smiling last night because they were finally out of it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Consumer Price Index rose by two-tenths of 1 per cent in August, the smallest rise in three years, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The resignation of Ray Garrett Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and of William J. Casey, a former chairman of the S.E.C. who is now the head of the ExportImport Bank, were announced today by the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 An Administration official said to day that between 85 and 90 per cent of the work had been completed for a new accord with the Soviet Union to limit strategic weapons, but that im- portant differences still held up an agreement.

The most unusual of this season's prime time television shows. "Saturday Night Live With Howard Cosell," has its premiere at 8 o'clock tonight on ABC-TV. Some may also regard it as the most bizarre of shows, since in many ways it is a variety show version of Monday night football, or what the television industry calls "a spin-off."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Jordanian officials informed the United States privately today that King Hussein had dropped his apparent objections and had agreed to accept all the conditions imposed by President Ford for the sale to Jordan of 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles.

TOMS RIVER, Sept. 19 (AP) John Kelly 3d, who spent two years in a mental institution after being acquitted by reason of insanity in the murder of a priest, was back in custody today after three days of freedom.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19-- When Randolph A. A pair of stately swans, escorted by a half-dozen brown mallards, paddle smoothly under the timbered ferry slip here, gliding forward like surfers on the tumbling wave of a fullastern propeller wash. A famous bridge writer is on record as saying that the most intractable problem in bridge is "the kibitzer evil." There are rules for kibitzers, just as there are for players, but they are frequently disregarded. The ideal kibitzer watches one hand only, never opens his mouth during the bidding and play, and says very little in between deals: He makes a postmortem comment only if asked to do so.

In this critical period when the university is laboring under draconian budget cuts and the city's capacity to support any of its past commitments is in question, no proposals that might ease the fiscal pinch can be ignored.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The 25th Amendment to the Constitution worked "exceedingly well" in the elevation of Gerald R. Ford to President and Nelson A. Rockefeller to Vice President and should not be revised, a Senate report concluded today.
WEST POINT, Sept. 21 Change marches slowly through West Point, but the pace is quickening.
Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein's simmering feud with Speaker Stanley Steingut has begun a new chapter that Steingut partisans contend should be entitled the Case of the Purloined Portfolio.

LAKEWOOD, Sept. 21--An Ocean County Park patrolman was injected with sodium pentathol, the so-called truth drug, to help the police find clues to the theft last month of a $25,000 Tiffany lamp from the Georgian Court College here.

LISBON, Sept. 19--Portugal is not Chile! they cry at every political demonstration and in private conversations. But the Portuguese nevertheless identify their revolution with Chile's lost cause. The late Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens has become a Portuguese national hero and his portrait is seen everywhere.

The cost of the passengerrail link from midtown to Kennedy International Airport is now estimated at $469-million 10 times the 1968 price tag and the project is therefore under "re-examination," according to William J. Ronan.

Tony Dorsett, Pittsburgh's excellent running back, learned Saturday that even though individuals win allAmerica honors each year, they can't do it without help. Virtually helpless in efforts to shake free against the Oklahoma defense, the allAmerica tailback picked up only 17 yards, by far the lowest one-game figure in his three varsity seasons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Government announced today that it was removing the 60-cent-a-barrel fee on imported petroleum products, largely to end uncertainties about the future of the fee that were threatening to create shortages of imported home heating oil and heavy industrial fuel this winter.

The most obvious difference between tournaments here and tournaments in Europe is that most parts of Europe offer cash prize. The American Contract Bridge League, throughout its history, has barred money rewards, and independent attempts to establish money tournaments have repeatedly failed.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 21 President Ford said today that the Government was accumulating vast amounts of information on American citizens, and declared, "We must protect every individual from excessive and unnecessary intrusions by a 'Big Brother' bureaucracy."

Roasted sweet peppers, known as pepperoni, are one of the joys of an Italian antipasto. Both red and green sweet peppers sometimes known as bell peppers, particularly in the South seem available in particular abundance this season, and Samuel Hirsh of Jackson Heights, Queens, writes that he would like information on roasting the peppers.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 To the despair of civil rights activists and public educators, many of the 3,000 or so private "academies" hastily set up to avoid desegregation in the South in recent years are gaining a semblance of permanence.

Detectives, many working on their own time, followed scores of leads throughout the city yesterday from callers who said they had seen a man who resembled Luis Serrano Yelez, identified by the police as the man who killed two officers last Tuesday night.
It looks as if the Newspaper Advertising Bureau is the first group to come up witha method of testing advertising effectivness through the far-reaching new Universal Product Code.
Acting Sanitation Commissioner Martin Lang said yesterday that one of the first moves in his new job would be to "strengthen" the disciplinary unit within the department.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 21 (AP) Bruce Poulton, chancel lor of the University of New Hampshire system, has issued in apology for the "improper use" oP student address labels by the Senate campaign of John A. Durkin, which Mr. Durkin won last Tuesday.
PEKING, Sept. 21 (Reuters) Former Prime Minister Edward Heath met today with Chairman Mao Tse-tung and reported later that Mr. Mao was wellinformed and in comparatively good health.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 21--A 12-year-old campaign to make the Congaree Swamp, a 70,000 acre bottomland forest in central South Carolina, into a national preserve was revived with gusto over the weekend.

Donna E. Mitchell, news manager for Patrick Carr Associates, a New York advertising agency, was married yesterday to Alfred C. Westermann of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. He is vice president and director of sales training for Petry Television, Inc., television representatives.
WEST POINT, Sept. 21 One of West Point's older established minority groups, the Jewish cadets, celebrated Succoth this year under a Succah constructed with the help of the Army Corps of Engineers.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 The Yankees put the pleasures and thrills of this season on the road behind them today, splitting a double-header with the Cleveland Indians and closing out their travel for 1975.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

Joyce Trisler's Danscompany, which gave a series of performances this weekend at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is a small, agreeably trained moderndance group that seems capable of giving modest but genuine pleasure, but lacks something in personal character.

LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 21 With just seven weeks left before the scheduled date of Angolan independence, the Portuguese are still searching for a nationalist coalition to which they can turn over the government as they withdraw from this vast, potentially rich land they have held for 491 years.

HOUSTON, Sept. 21 Wildcatter! The word itself helps perpetuate the image of the independent oilman: a two-fisted, hard drinking leather faced Texas Yahoo with a nose for crude oil, an eye for wild women and a wallet stuffed with hundred dollar bills.

A threat by members of the Federation of Catholic Teachers to strike against 325 schools in the Archdiocese of New York was called off yesterday when 350 members of the union. Local 2092 of the American Federation of Teachers, voted against a work stoppage according to Jack O'Neill, president of the union.

Marjorie Ellen Balgooyen, a soprano with a master's degree in music history from the University of Michigan, was married yesterday afternoon to M. Dickey Drysdale of Randolph, Vt. He is editor and publisher of The White River Valley Herald, a Randolph weekly.

The New Jersey court system will begin today to undertake a review of the complex legal questions surrounding a proposed withdrawal of life-sustaining medical procedures from a terminally ill patient.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 E. Howard Hunt Jr., who is serving a jail term in Florida for his, role in the Watergate burglary, has told "associates" that he was asked about five years ago by a "senior" official in 'the Nixon White House to assassinate the syndicated columnist Jack Anderson, according to a report today in The Washington Post.

The state ombudsman for elderly nursing-home patients has been appointed and plans as one of his first policies to answer the special hot line phone himself every Wednesday. The line is used to receive complaints or information concerning the elderly.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 Publicschool teachers here were preparing today to strike tomorrow in the face of a state court prohibition against a work stoppage. The teachers' decision created another problem for Boston's school desegregation efforts.

GRAPE DEAL The Brasserie, that subterranean 24hour French restaurant that hosts among others a variety of weary-eyed predawn allnight on-the-towners, is launching a three-week champagne harvest festival tonight.

For the first time, the Blue Cross Association and the National Association of Blue Shield Plans are going to promote themselves in a joint advertising effort That, of course, calls for a single advertising agency.

A bases-loaded double in the ninth inning by Denny Doyle drove in two runs yesterday and lifted Boston to a 6-5 comeback victory over the Tigers in Detroit, but the Red Sox suffered a crippling blow as they stayed 3 games ahead of the hardcharging Baltimore Orioles, who also won, in the Ameri- can League East race. They lost Jim Rice for the season.

There are fewer gray wooden police barricades around the perimeter of City Hall Park. Those that remain seem to be standing there out of habit, not because they are to be used to keep out angry teachers, laid-off policemen, dismissed hospital workers and fundless librarians.

The City Commissioner of Human Rights has concluded that the charter-revision proposals to be voted on in a Nov. 4 referendum will lead to increased neighborhood rivalry that "will almost surely" take racial and ethnic form, thereby endangering the city's often tenuous racial peace.
SHRAZ, Iran The establishment of an electronics industry center here in arid southern Iran will move step further next month with the opening of a testing laboratory for advanced military equipment.

Led by a group of red-hatted Cossacks on horseback, a "parada" of more than a thousand Ukrainian-Americans, including folk dancers and hands in native costume, marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday in the pouring rain to celebrate the American Bicentennial as well as the, 100th anniversary of Ukrainian settlement in the United States.
Winning the opening game of the National Football League schedule is an old tradition in Dallas--even when the opposition is provided by the Los Angeles Rams.
DALLAS, Sept. 21 The Texas School Book Depository, where Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President, Kennedy, is up for sale for $1million.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS. In the furor over the mythical evils of school busing and the purported inviolability of neighborhood schools, the nation has overlooked four essential points. School desegregation is a necessary, viable and important national goal. The Constitution requires it. Minority children will never achieve equal educational opportunity without it. And our children will never learn to live together if they do not begin to learn together now.

Senator Jacob K. Javits charged yesterday that President Ford had been "captured" by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's "wrong" attitude toward New York City's fiscal crisis, an attitude the Senator characterized as "sit tight and keep a stony face."
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 As hard as it was for Middle Western farmers to believe, the stockyard price of hogs has soared to $63.25 a hundred pounds, a record that is nearly double the price a year ago.

"I enjoy working in the theater," Stanley Koor says, "and it's one of the few sources of steady employment for musicians that is left in the city."

The singer Esther Phillips, borne up by her hit recording "What a Diff'rence a Day Makes," is one of the reigning stars of the discotheque scene -- certainly one of the major music trends of the year. Miss Phillips began her career in the mid-nineteen-fifties (as Little Esther) and has had successful phases over two decades.

Pamela Wattenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Wattenberg of New York, was married here yesterday to Carl J. Green, the Ford Foundation's representative in Tokyo and program officer for Japan and East Asia.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 Patricia Hearst and her parents are expected to testify Tuesday in Federal Court when a hearing resumes on her request to be released on bail, one of her attorneys said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Government announced today that it was removing the 60-cent-a-barrel fee on imported petroleum products, largely to end uncertainties about the future of the fee that were threatening to create shortages of imported home heating oil and heavy industrial fuel this winter.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP) JoAnn Washam, a longdriving, third-year pro from Fort Worth, won the $40,000 Portland golf tournament today at the Portland Golf Club. She finished one stroke ahead of Sandra Haynie and won the top prize of $5,700.
HAIFA, Sept. 21 (Reuters) The Israeli artist Moshe Mokady died here today, He was 73 years old.

Mayor Beame intervened in the musicians' strike yesterday, calling, union and theater leaders to Gracie Mansion last night to express his "deep concern." The strike, started last Thursday, has shut nine Broadway musicals.

The resignation of Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh under strong pressure from Mayor Beame is an encouraging attest to the Mayor's newfound determination to provide the kind of executive leadership needed if New York City is to rescue itself from fiscal and administrative disaster.

Lynn Frances Barry, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Wright Barry of Locust Valley, L.I., was marired yesterday afternoon in Glen Cove, L.I., to Kevin Clay Hyson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Hyson of Sun City, Ariz., formerly of Locust Valley.

LONDON, Sept. 21 British authorities are coming under increasing pressure to explain this country's role in the resettlement of more than 1,000 island residents to make way for an American naval base in the Indian Ocean.

LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 21 A member of the Hunt oil family says that its widely advertised H.L.H. food company lost $50-million to $60-million between 1960 and 1970 because of "stealing" by key company employes and that the Justice Department has refused for five years to investigate.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 21 Three botanists went into Death Valley this weekend to study an extraordinary form of life, a scrubby plant called tidestromia oblongifolia: The hotter and dryer and more inhospitable conditions are the bigger and faster tidestromia grows.

Samuel A. Adams is an intelligence analyst, a specialist on Vietnam, who spent ten years in the Central Intelligence Agency. He liked the work, as he says. But he quit the C.I.A. in 1973 in frustration at the way lies and politics corrupted its function.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 Security precautions were reinforced at United Nations headquarters today in preparation for the expected appearance tomorrow of Secretary of State Kissinger and of other visitors in coming weeks.

Although few have begun preparing for their 1975 Federal income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service has made advance proofs of the new forms available. A look at the form used for most personal returns Form 1040 and its accompanying schedules points up the impact of the Tax Reduction Act of 1975.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 21 Eight hundred striking teachers were scheduled to return to classes in the Half Hollow Hills school district tomorrow following ratification late tonight of a new three-year contract.

Citing 39 escapes and attempted escapes by inmates under his jurisdiction since the first of the year, Benjamin J. Malcolm, the city's Commissioner of Correction, said yesterday that he was considering a "department shake-up, ranging from transfer to suspension to possible dismissal."

BAASTAD, Sweden, Sept. 21 (AP) Sweden gained the Davis Cup final for the first time in history today when Birger Andersson, who became a full-time tennis pro only six months ago, clinched the three-of-five, series with Chile with a 6-3, 14-12, 6-1 triumph over Patricio Cornejo.

HONG KONG, Sept. 21 Refugees coming out of South Vietnam say that economic conditions in Saigon are becoming increasingly difficult and that there is some continuing armed resistance to the Communists and a "resistance" radio that broadcasts daily.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 21 The voters of this second largest California city, who are not only content but also determined to remain No. 2, gave a vote of confidence last week to San Diego's growth controls that are among the most rigid in the nation.

The marriage of Suzanne Jane Tillman to Richard William Darrow, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Hill Knowlton, Inc., international public relations and public affairs counseling concern, took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) Senator Harrison A. Williams, Jr. Democrat of New Jersey said today he would introduce legislation delaying for one year the abandonment of any rail lines.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UPI) The National Safety Council says the nation's death toll from all accidents decreased by nearly 11,000 last year compared with the 1973 toll and was the lowest death rate on record.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 Mayor Richard J. Daley is seeking to scrap Chicago's Civil Service Commission to provide himself and his department heads with what he recently described as "more flexible" control over more than 40,000 city jobs.

Ronni Gail Gordon, a business reporter with Dun Bradstreet, was married here yesterday morning to Alan Martin Eisenberg, an associate in the law firm of Hays, St. John, Abramson Heilbron. The ceremony was performed in the Geth-El Chanel of Temple Emanu-El by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

The African elephant, the largest land animal alive, is declining in numbers so rapidly that some wildlife experts fear that within a decade it may be on the verge of extermination in much, if not all, of Africa.

It's not surprising the Gregg Smith Singer's 197576 Bicentennial tour program of which the group offered a preview yesterday afternoon to a spottily attended Alice Tully Hall should be devoted to American music.

On Tuesday, the Senate Rules Committee approved President Ford's nomination of Daniel J. Boorstin as Librarian of Congress. The vote was unanimous, but the committee, in the words of a United Press International dispatch from Washington, "cautioned the Pulitzer Prizewinning historian on his future writing activities."

Mayor Beame yesterday announced the appointments of two executives with experience in accounting and public administration to serve as nonsalaried consultants to Kenneth Axelson, the new Deputy Mayor for Finance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The two most widely sold electric cars in the United States market the Elcar 2000 and the Citicar SV-48 are so unsafe that they should not be allowed on the highway, according to the Consumers Union.
Jack Cuddy, a former United Press and U.P.I, boxing writer, died yesterday at New York Hospital of a stroke. He was 77 years old.
The problem at Putumayo is what to examine first. The selection of South American handcrafts in Dan Storper's small shop at 142 Fast 73d Street is almost overwhelming in its variety.

Prudence Halle Bach, daughter of Julian Bach of New York and the late Mrs. Bach, was married yesterday to Anthony N. Madia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Madia of North Bergen, N.J. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The first statewide test of the new Federal campaign law in New Hampshire last week demonstrated dramatically the powerful political leverage that the reform statute has given to organized labor.

The last time Mayor Beame mentioned higher stocktransfer taxes as a means of reducing New York City's $3.3-billion deficit, he was snowed under like a rookie quarterback getting blitzed by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)--The first group of high school students to take final examinations since the Communists took over here had a choice yesterday of writing papers analyzing the thoughts of either Ho Chi Minh, the late North Vietnamese leader, or the current Premier, Pham Van Dong.

PARIS, Sept. 21 Exporting and consuming countries appear to be subtly changing strategy in the diplomacy of oil moving back from confrontation toward a more moderate position where the politics of cooperation may finally break through.

LONDON, Sept. 21 The British people have learned, to their shock, that Lord Reith, who as creator of the British Broadcasting Corporation shaped the presentation of news and views, "loathed the common people," lusted after power and venomously reviled the country's leaders.

MADRID, Sept. 21 Eleven death sentences against political terrorists in three weeks, the arrest of close to 200 persons, a crackdown on the press and sharpened hostility abroad to the Spanish Government have increased tension in Spain to the highest point since the assassination of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco in December, 1973.

Nancy Tatum, a Memphisborn soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut last fall in "Turandot," appeared for the first time yesterday afternoon at the New York City Opera, once more in the title role of Puccini's last, unfinished opera. She served as the focal point of a first-rate performance, the season's fourth of this dramatically ludicrous but often stirring opera.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. '2l (AP) Matthew Reed, his receivers covered, ran 32 yards to cap a late comeback and give the Birmingham Vulcans a 22-16 World Football League victory over Charlotte today.

The Frank Sinatra-Ella Fitzgerald-Count Basie concert grossed a reported $1.08-million for its two-week, 16performance stand, which ended Saturday night at the 1,900-seat Uris Theater on Broadway at 50th Street.

FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 21 The New England Patriots, who spent most of last week on strike, lost their opening game to the Houston Oilers, 7-0, today. Jordan said yesterday that he was "pretty damn mad" about the conclusion of a federally financed study that said Jersey City was the worst large American city in which to live. He noted that the study was based on data more than five years old that predated his administration, which began in 1971.

A sudden burst of optimism in the credit markets, Wall Street analysts say, has dispelled at least temporarily one lingering worry. Richard B. Jablow, a partner in the law firm of Butler, Jablow Geller here, who represented literary and musical clients, died Saturday of a heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 1 Lincoln Plaza.

The Conference Board reported over the weekend that its index of consumer confidence advanced to 77.3 per cent of the 1967 average during August, up 9 points from the June level. Kleppe, the millionaire former North Daokta Representative who is President Ford's latest nominee to be Secretary of the Interior, was assured at a Senate hearing today on his confirmation to the Cabinet post that, unlike his predecessor, he would be promptly approved.

Lynn, director of the Office of Management and Budget, gave Congress some new figures today that showed that already identifiable increases in Government spending this year amount to $15-billion more than the Administration estimated in May, but that only $5-billion of the total was a result of Congressional actions that ran counter to Administration policy.

Negotiations aimed at ending the strike of musicians at Broadway theaters resumed yesterday, but the Metropolitan Opera warned that it would not open its season next month without a contract or a nostrike pledge from the musicians union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Four members of Congress from primarily rural districts testified today against a proposal to allow the Postal Service to close more than 12,000 rural post offices.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 Mayor Kevin H. White won the top spot tonight in a preliminary city election that drew a light turnout in rainy weather.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 23 A Federal judge ruled today that Lynette Alice Fromme was mentally competent to stand trial on a charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford here on Sept. 5. The judge also granted Miss Fromme's request to represent herself.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 Mexico's Finance Minister, Jose Lopez Portillo, chosen yesterday to succeed President Luis Echeverria Alverez, said today that his main concerns were job opportunities and the distribution of wealth.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UPI) A Federal judge says the Pennsylvania State Police denied a promotion for a black trooper because of his race and ordered the state police to promote him and pay $10,000 in back pay.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Dr. Ludwig Von Sallmann, former chief of ophthalmology at the National Institutes of Health, died here today at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 33 years old.
ROME, Sept. 24 Two physicians in Avellino, near Naples, have been arrested in connection with the deaths of at least 17 newborn babies from salmonella poisoning in the last two weeks.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 24 An Episcopal delegation back from a trip to Rome reported today that the chief Vatican ecumenical officer, Jan Cardinal Willebrands, had said that acceptance of women into the priesthood within the Anglican communion would inject "a new element of tension" into Roman Catholic-Anglican consultations.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Negotiators for striking Boston teachers considered a new School Committee offer tonight as enrollment in the newly integrated schools plummeted.

PARIS, Sept. 24 Rene Thomas, the French racing driver who won the Indianapolis 500 in 1914, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The South Korean opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, believes his country will suffer "the fate, of another Vietnam" unless they present Seoul Government is changed, he wrote in a document released here today.
In brisker trading, prices moved ahead on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The index closed at 84.74, up 0.59, Volume rose to 1.61 million shares from Tuesday's 1.37 million.

Diana Nyad, who swims long distances better than any other woman in the world, tried to swim around Manhattan yesterday. At 1 P.M. she slid into the water off East 89th Street and headed north, but 6 hours 25 minutes later, feeling "cold, frozen and tired," she was hauled aboard a police launch and taken to a hospital. She had got as far as Wall Street.

Eighteen leading Wall Street brokerage houses, three major New York banks and a prominent mutual fund organization urged the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday not to change admittedly anticompetitive stock exchange rules that favor exchange members.

The New York Nets and Denver Nuggets of the American Basketball Association have applied for admission to the rival National Basketball Association. They are expected to announce their applications today, The Associated Press reported.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 24 The Hartford Stage Company has just opened its new season with a splendid and timely revival of Clifford Odets's finest play, "Awake and Sing!" The play stands up admirably it is now exactly 40 years old and the staging and the acting show the American resident theater at its very best.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The First National City Bank delivered to a House transportation subcommitte today a grim assessment of the future of the nation's railroads, forecasting a $21.1-billion cash gap over the next 10 years.

LONDON, Sept. 24, (AP) A three-month advance that raised the United States dollar's overseas value by more than 10 per cent leveled off today, offering at least temporary relief to European currencies and gold.
The Treasury auctioned $2-billion of new 29-month notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.10 per cent in a sale that attracted heavy public participation.

Rohr Industries said it was the low bidder on a $49.1 million order to build 779 city transit buses for the New Jersey Department of Transportation. Delivery is scheduled to begin early next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Millions of dollars are being poured covertly into Portugal and Angola by East and West, according to four official sources in Washington. The funneling of the funds is part of the continuing struggle for control of the Mediterranean and for influence and raw materials in Central Africa.

Dennis Koster, who abandoned, a career as a flamenco guitarist seven years ago to study the classic guitar, gave the first recital of his new career on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Still in his mid-20's, Mr. Koster needs further maturing, both musically and technically, but he played a difficult program with considerable success.

Luis Serrano Velez, who had been sought as the gunman in the killing of two police officers on the Lower East Side last week, was arrested here last night when he succumbed to a police ruse and ran out of a West 19th Street apartment into the arms of four waiting detectives.

Negotiators for both sides in the musicians' strike reassessed their respective positions yesterday as financial losses from the seven-day walkout mounted for producer's, nonsriking performers, theater district restaurants and other related businesses.

The opening marks the start of the parish's 50th year. It was in this parish that Mother Cabrini, the first American to be canonized, taught Sunday school.

The Bache Group, Inc., one of the nation's leading investment securities companies; reported yesterday a profit of $4.7-million or 67 cents a share, an revenues of $64.7million in the quarter ended July 31. In the year-earlier period, the company lost $1million on revenues of $40.4million.

Geiberger and Watson, the two leading money-winners in the 144-man field, will chase the $27,000 first prize.

COVENTRY, England By middle-class standards David Kershaw is doing well. He makes $13,500 a year, enough to put him among the top 10 per cent of Britain's wageearners. He has a good home, a challenging job and money in the bank.

An offering of 1,250,000 common shares of Christensen, Inc., at $16.50 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. The offering includes 600,000 shares being sold by the company and 650,000 being sold by certain selling shareholders.

A year-long investigation into payroll padding in the office of the City Clerk culminated yesterday in the indictments of Herman Katz, City Clerk for 16 years until he resigned last November, and Thomas A. Lenane, the former deputy clerk.
Higher prices for gold yesterday in Europe gave a lift to gold futures contracts here after a long decline, resulting in a drop of about $20 an ounce in the last eight trading sessions.

The Museum of Modern Art is plagued by leaks in the roof and walls of the East and Garden Wings, additions completed 11 years ago at a cost of $5.5-million. A leader of the Japan Socialist party, which after three decades in the Opposition now sees hope of gaining a role in the Government, declared here yesterday that the party was not "willing to play a subordinate role as an American mascot."

LISBON, Sept. 24 Vera Lagoa was not arrested today, as she had expected. But she is ready anyway, as is her friend, Fernanda Leitao.

HOBOKEN, Sept. 24. The Hoboken Teachers Association continued to strike today, defying a second court order, issued yesterday, to return to work and a contempt citation that had cost it a $5,000 fine.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 The four United States auto makers today reported mid-September sales that were only six-tenths of 1 per cent behind the same period a year ago. Analysts said that sales were the fifth highest for the period and that strong early demand for the 1976 models were a factor in the improvement.

Isidore G. Needleman, general counselor for the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the official Soviet Government commercial agency in this country, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in St. Michael's, Barbados, where he had been on legal business. He was 72 years old and lived at 444 Central Park West.
William T. Higgs, president of Higgs Marine Service in the Bronx, died Tuesday, apparent- ly of a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived adjacent to his company's marina and in Jupiter, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Panamanian Government has apologized to the United States for an incident yesterday in which demonstrators broke about 100 windows in the American Embassy in Panama City, the State De- partment reported today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 With their power play in midseason form, the New York Rangers opened their preseason schedule tonight by beating the Boston Bruins, 4-3, at Providence Civic Center.

Large numbers of uniformed policemen kept people back with the help of barriers. There were plainclothesmen in and watching the crowd, and Secret Service agents surrounded the President.

Jacob Anthony Probst, a lawyer who specialized in general corporate practice, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 East 66th Street and Westport, Conn.

The big fall weekend is here for Long Island fanciers, with a total of 4,249 dogs slated to compete in three events, all with increased entries.
MANILA, Sept. 24 Muhammad Ali, who is capable of announcing his retirement and comeback in the same sentence, came up today with a plan to leave boxing flat on its back for a year.
Governor Carey and Mayor Beame criticized Senator James L. Buckley yesterday for opposing direct Federal intervention in the city's fiscal crisis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 In the second victory in a week for antibusing forces, the Senate voted today to bar the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from ordering the busing of students beyond the school nearest their homes.
LOS ANGELES, Sept 24 (AP) Sara Jane Moore says she acted alone and was driven by personal rage and frustration when she fired a shot at President Ford in San Francisco on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Crime today accused the Treasury Department and its Bureau of Alcohol, to enforce gun control laws that Congress has already enacted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Postal service to rural America would deteriorate if Congress agrees to the closing of 12,000 small post offices, the president of the National Association of Postmasters said today.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 A ministerial conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved today toward what was expected to be a modest price increase for oil, but conflicts developed, chiefly between Saudi Arabia and militant members, over the size of the increase.
Paul J. Curran announced yesterday that he was resigning as the United States Attorney here because "it was time to return to private employment."
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 24 A 57-year-old nurse's aide was trapped in an elevator at Hempstead General Hospital for 22 hours before being discovered this morning.

Nixon and Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edward M. Kennedy and Frank Church.

LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 24 Kenneth Stanley Adams, owner of the Houston Oilers, a professional football team, testified today that he did not know it was illegal when he suggested to Nelson Bunker Hunt that he tap the telephones of Hunt Oil Company employes in an attempt to learn who had embezzled up to $50-million.

Some 10 to 15 per cent of the landlords of the 1,000 stores operated by the W.T. Grant Company have agreed to the retail chain's recent request for a 25 per cent reduction in rentals over the next two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 24 The chairman of the Congressional black caucus, Representative Charles B. Rangel, promised today to "organize all the support possible for the Ford Administration's attempt to repeal the Byrd Amendment during the current session of Congress."

LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) Clive Morton, a well-known character actor who had appeared in some 60 films, more than 100 television productions and many stage plays in a career that began in 1926, died today. He was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a basic change in the way that expenses for the care of children or other dependents can be used to reduce Federal income taxes.

In an effort to explain ball lightning, which many scientists consider the most perplexing of atmospheric phenomena, French researchers have conducted a modernized version of Benjamin Franklin's famous experiment with a kite.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Republicans, already out- numbered 2 to 1 in the House, could lose 25 more seats in next year's' elections, a party panel has warned Republican members.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 A plan to allow the construction of apartment buildings for the first time in this affluent residential suburb of single-family homes was resoundingly defeated here today.

Continental Mortgage Investors, one of the nation's big real estate investment trusts, said yesterday that it had accepted bids from a group of its senior debtors to purchase selected pieces of property from the trust's portfolio. The trust refused to name the banks involved.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 24 (UPI) Judge Jon O. Newman of United States District Court here has ordered the state of Connecticut to pay for abortions for three unidentified welfare recipients.

The Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship, one of the prestige events in the New York tournament program, ended Wednesday night in a victory for the favorites: Michael Becker, Matt Granovetter, Ron Rubin, Alan Sontag and Peter Weichsel, all of New York City and Jeff Rubens of Scarsdale, N.Y.
STORMVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25 Seventy-year-old Roy Schuster walked out of Green Haven prison at 4 o'clock this afternoon, a free man for the first time in 44 years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Ford is reconsidering tentative plans for extensive cross-country travel next month after two apparent attempts on his life, White House officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The House Ways and Means Committee, responding to complaints of taxpayers and civil liberties groups, took some steps today to limit the authority that the Internal Revenue Service has in dealing with taxpayers.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 An unofficial Israeli delegation of leftists is visiting the Soviet Union for 10 days to explore prospects for restoring diplomatic relations between Israel and the Soviet Union.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 25 The compromise worked out last week to break the crisis over Jordan's desire to purchase 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles illustrates the problems that arise from the United States policy of trying to influence both sides in the Arab-Israeli dispute and the delicacy of Jordan's position in trying to appear to her Arab neighbors as more than a client of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Representative Otis G. Pike said today that in his opinion the executive branch was in "contempt of Congress," and that he would ask the House of Representatives to take action next week.
VIENNA, Sept. 25 Oil-exporting nations are expected to go into a third, unscheduled day of talks tomorrow with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide.

ALBANY (AP) New York State vineyards are expected to yield 155,000 tons of grapes this year, down 12 per cent from last year's crop. However, that is still good enough to maintain the states' ranking as the nation's No. 2 grape producer, second only to California.

A jury began deliberating the fate of Patricia E. Swinton late yesterday in Federal District Court, where she is on trial on charges of conspiring to bomb Federal buildings in Manhattan in September and November, 1969. At 10:15 P.M. the jury ceased deliberations for the night.

The press is advising the skipper to be a little more careful, lest he gain a few votes and lose his life, and the President is advising the press to be a little less sensational lest it make heroes of assassins and encourage the violence it deplores.

SAN FRANCISCO "Who wants to be Chief Kook of Kookville anyway?" I asked irreverently a few years ago when it looked as if Nobody would become Mayor of San Francisco. Therefore, I was less exercised than most of the locals when a Presidential aide, one James Falk, described northern California as "the kook capital of the world" in the wake of attempts to assassinate President Ford in Sacramento and San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The House refused today to renew the ban on United States imports of Rhodesian chrome ore, ignoring warnings that continuing the trade would hurt United States relations with other southern African nations.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 25 Papers were filed today in the case of Karen Anne Quinlan that show she was adopted as an infant in June, 1955, by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Quinlan of Landing in Morris County, under the terms of a Pennsylvania court decree.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 A spokesman for the White House press office said today that just what form President Ford would use to thank those who helped him in the San Francisco shooting episode had not yet been decided.
Dr. Carl Fenichel, founder and director of the League School for Seriously Disturbed Chlidren in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 244 Henry Street, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.
A public offering of 125,000 common shares of Bangor Hydro Electric Company, at $11.75 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc.

ASMARA, Ethiopia, Sept. 24 (Reuters) A burly ex-sailor drained his morning cup of coffee in the Royal Bar here and shouldered his way through a string curtain screening the doorway into the bright sunshine of the street.

Emanuel R. Gold, the ranking Democratic member of the Republican-controlled State Senate Committee on Crime and Corrections, yesterday appointed Burton Schoenbach, a prisonreform advocate and long-time gadfly of state corrections officials, as staff director and special consultant to the Democratic committee members.

The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson accused the Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday of failing to act swiftly or strongly enough to force greater austerity and fiscal reform on the city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The House Civil Service Committee today defeated a resolution proposing an 8.66 Federal pay raise to replace President Ford's recommended 5 per cent pay increase ceiling.

PARIS, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Mario Soares, the Portuguese Socialist leader, today denied a press report that his party had received millions of dollars in aid channeled from the United States by the Central Intelligence Agency.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 Early one morning this month, 15,000 new junior and senior high school graduates gathered in a square in the industrial city of Wuhan for a ritual that has been a central fact of life for young people in China they were being sent off to be resettled in the countryside.

Paula Lynn Shleffar of New York was married last evening to Luis Armando Garnica, a Mexico City pianist and musical arranger who records for RCA with Los Internacionales, a rock group. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony in Temple Emanu-El.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 An undercover Federal firearms agent working with Sara Jane Moore accompanied her on a visit to a suspected illicit gun dealer the day before she allegedly attempted to kill President Ford in San Francisco, according to Government sources familiar with the case. The visit came one day after the police told Federal officials that Miss Moore had apparently threatened Mr.Ford's life.

Rain steady, heavy and unrelenting drenched the metropolitan region for the fourth straight day yesterday, turning low-lying roadways into ponds, flooding some highways and making life generally unpleasant for hundreds of thousands of residents.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 25 Responsible Israelis tonight discounted speculation that the meeting between the Israeli and Soviet Foreign Ministers in New York would lead to a resumption of diplomatic ties.

The State Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to withdraw tis recommendation that the City Controller be removed from the Board of Estimate and that the Mayor and Council President be coupled on a single ticket in quadrennial elections.
MADRID, Sept. 25 (Reuters) A Spanish official today rejected protests abroad against death sentences passed on 11 urban guerillas.

NEW DELHI, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP) The Indian government today ordered the correspondent here of The Los Angeles Times, Jacques Leslie, to leave the country within 24 hours after his paper had refused to withdraw him.
Reliable an ubiquitous sources in Detroit indicate that the beginnings of smiles are starting to appear on the peaked faces that run the auto industry.

In 1892, on the first floor of a storefront at 113 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village, the newly founded Missionaries of St. Charles opened a church and called it Our Lady of Pompei. Its mission was to help the hundreds of thousands ofItalian immigrants who poured out of Ellis Island on their long journey to a better life.

THE ORIENT EXPRESSION The Theater for Asian American Performing Artists is about six months old. It is the first group of its kind in the city producing theatrical works on its own, and it aims to provide Asian-American performers a place to work and to develop talents. It also seeks to train beginners. The group has performed at Lincoln Center and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

The upward pressure on interest rates appears to have abated, if only temporarily, and a period of short-term stability in bank lending rates seemed possible following yesterday's report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on the latest week's developments.

Nearly 500 mourners attended a wake for the New York Cultural Center last evening, marking the end of its 11-year life. The occasion was billed as a "museum cooling," though the free-flowing liquor and loud rock provided by a live combo gave it a desperately festive air.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 25 "Can you explain," the Swedish television interviewer asks a visiting American, "the new wave of violence in the United States?"

The men who hold sway over how much music will be heard in the coming weeks on Broadway and at the Metropolitan Opera are a labor leader who once played the drums and a labor lawyer who wishes he could play the piano.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP) An unemployed service station attendant has told agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he had been recruited to assassinate President Ford and Senator Edward M. Kennedy by a guerrilla group armed with rifles, grenades and rocket launchers, an F.B.I. agent said today.

The New York Nets and Denver Nuggets applied formally yesterday for admission to the National Basketball Association for the 197677 season, but they faced legal challenges from within the league they are seeking to leave and from the N.B.A. Players' Association.
The New York Stock Exchange, plagued by continued low trading volume, reported a seat sale yesterday at a 20year low of $65,000 down $60,000 from only a month ago.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 25 As he dressed for his first workout of the week, Joe Namath said today he had "no doubts" that he would play Sunday at Kansas City against the Chiefs.
Among the Charter reform proposals that will face the city's voters on Nov. 4 is one that would mandate changes in the way in which land use planning and development in the city takes place.
VIENNA, Sept. 25 Oil-exporting nations are expected to go into a third, unscheduled day of talks tomorrow with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide.

There is growing evidence that the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act of 1973 is often being used for purposes other than its intended one of providing job training and employment opportunities for the nation's disadvantaged.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) A commentary by Tass, the official press agency, said today that the collapse of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization was a result of disputes between the members, new "foreign political orientation of a number of member countries" and "positive changes in the world arena."

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Sept. 25 (AP) Chester Charles Davis, the nation's food administrator during the early years of World War II, died today at a convalescent center. His age was 87. He underwent brain surgery last April.

ROME, Sept. 25 For more than three months since the governing Christian Democrats were set back by the Communists in elections, they have been struggling to discover something new to say to the Italian voters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 Two days before Patricia Hearst signed an affidavit in which she said she wanted to be admitted to bail because she was eager to go home to her parents, she told a high school chum that she feared becoming "a prisoner in my parents' home," court documents here disclosed today.

MINEOLA, L.I, Sept. 25 A 49-year-old Malverne woman was indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury on 23 counts of allegedly stealing about $50,000 in Medicaid funds while operating a nursing home in East Rockaway.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 25 (AP) Two British climbers have made the first ascent of Mount Everest by the southwest face, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry announced today.

HOLLYWOOD There is a curious scenario of boom and bust unfolding at the same time in Hollywood these days; Box-office receipts at the country's movie theaters are zooming toward a record for paradoxically, Hollywood's the second year in a row, but, producers are turning out fewer and fewer films.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Ford and Congressional leaders of both parties agreed today to restore the system of price controls on oil that expired Sept. 1 and to extend that system through the middle of November.

Harrison J. Goldin, the City Controller, charged yesterday that the Board of Education had failed to apply for $2.5million in state aid for education of the handicapped from 1972 through 1974, but the board sharply challenged the allegations, noting it had already collected more than $1.9million for the city.

Al Jarreau, who is opening for Grover Washington Jr. at the Bottom Line through Sunday, is well worth a visit. At times he sounds like both Al Green and Harry Belafonte (and even looks rather like Mr. Belafonte). But when he opens up, his voice takes on a more soulish bite. And when he moves onto his special turf, he becomes a singer of quite extraordinary virtuosity.
The next step toward peace between the Arabs and the Israelis "will have to involve the Palestinians," according to Prince Saud ibn Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 Prompted by growing doubts about the effectiveness of New York City's school decontralization policy as it is currently structured, the State Board of Regents is expected to undertake an extensive examination of the five-year-old policy.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, Sept. 25 A five-mile-long, half-billion-dollar convoy of barges carrying essential cargo to develop Alaska's oil-rich North Slope, racing against time and the weather, turned back last night after a sudden change in the winds halted a dramatic dash around icelocked Point Barrow.

LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 25 Nelson Bunker Hunt, a son of the late billionaire H.L. Hunt, testified today that he would never have authorized wiretaps on his father's top aides if he had known it was illegal.

A local property owner called his lawyer a few weeks ago to voice concern about the possibility that New York City might default on its obligations to bondholders, something that is still regarded as a possibility despite massive efforts by state and local officials to ease the city's financial crisis.

The premise underlying this book is that its subject transcends its esthetics. We care so much about the composer Richard Rodgers, we think his life so significant, that anything he sets down in his autobiography, "Musical Stages," is bound to be worth reading. Which is a fair enough assumption, up to a point.
MIAMI, Sept. 25 (UP) Tropical storm Gladys grew to hurricane force today in the Atlantic Ocean while Faye approached hurricane intensity and churned toward Bermuda with 70-mile-an-hour winds.

It used to be known as the Great White Way, Times Square, Broadway, the theater district; now it has become pimp, prostitute, porno and peepshow country. It is home for the big hustle, the mugger, con artists and criminals. This is the new worm in the Big Apple that has changed the character of the streets, the facades and even the buildings on some blocks in midtown Manhattan's West Side.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25 The days of population and economic growth in Westchester County, long a magnet for city dwellers and businesses on the move, may be over.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The United States will propose next week that a world grain reserve of 30 million metric tons be set up and held by individual countries as a hedge against future shortages and famine, Government documents showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Senate voted tonight to soften an antibusing provision approved last week, but liberals were thwarted in their efforts to nullify restrictions preventing the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from ordering busing to achieve desegregation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) President Ford's Domestic Council drug review study group has recommended that a low priority be given to enforcement of marijuana laws.

MANILA, Sept. 25 Debate over the selection of the referee for the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier world heavyweight championship fight developed today after Eddie Futch, the challenger's manager, objected to Zack Clayton of Philadelphia as a candidate.

Clyde Beals, who had been an executive of the American Newspaper Guild and editor of The Guild Reporter from 1935 to 1940, died Sept. 12, apparently of a heart attack, at a nursing home in O'Fallon, Ill. He was 79 years old.
CAIRO, Sept. 25 (UPI) Ashok B. Bhadkamkar, Indian Ambassador to Egypt since 1972, died Wednesday night of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Dr. Joseph M.A.H. Luns, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, accused the Soviet Union today of failing to live up to the obligations of the document signed at the European security conference in Helsinki.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Thomas S. Kleppe, President Ford's nominee to be Secretary of the Interior, was criticized today for his four-and-a-half year record as head of the Federal Small Business Administration, but the criticism seemed unlikely to affect his nomination.
LISBON, Sept. 25 A large anti-Government demonstration was held in Lisbon tonight under the sponsorship of an extreme leftist group of soldiers.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 Domestic auto plants this week are scheduled to build 155,532 cars, off 4 per cent from 162,118 last week and 10 per cent below the 172,753 units built in the corresponding week a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Iran has told the United States she is considering sending about a dozen Americanbuilt supersonic jet fighters to Jordan, the State Department said today.

As part of the effort to save New York City from default, 12 leading corporations have agreed to buy more than $20million of bonds in a new offering of securities by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon Sept. 25 (UPI) Isolated shooting incidents and two bombings hardly dented the latest cease-fire between rival militias today as the nation's leaders met to chart a permanent peace between leftist and rightist factions.
The Boston Red Sox and Baltimore Orioles, who have been battling for American League Eastern Division honors most of the season, both lost out to the rain again last night.

Ramblin' Jack Elliott, the folk-singing cowboy from Brooklyn, may not be a hot new artist, and he certainly doesn't have flashy recordcompany promotion to support his club dates. But Mr. Elliott who is currently at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, through Sunday is such a winning artist that he manages to fill up clubs anyhow.

BERGEN-HOHNE, West Germany In early September a battalion of American paratroopers jumped into an area just south of the Moselle River near Trier to set up a bridgehead in a training exercise. A Belgium army officer jumped with them, and they carried Belgian radio equipment besides their own.
HAMAR, Norway, Sept. 25 (Reuter) Premier Trygve Bratteli told a meeting of his party's national council today that he would resign early in January.

WASHINGTON, Sept 25 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee voted today to cut defense spending requests by nearly $9-billion, including a $344.2-million reduction in funds for intelligence activities.

Robert L. Vesco, the financier, and a personal holding company, Vesco Co., Inc., have been ordered by a Federal judge to turn over to a courtappointed custodian all shares of the International Controls Corporation in their possession.

As part of the effort to save New York City from default, 12 leading corporations have agreed to buy more than $20million of bonds in a new offering of securities, by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
