Luis Serrano Velez, the 26year-old former convict who was arraigned yesterday for the murder of two police officers last week may also have been the gunman in a third homicide case here, the police said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 A study that questioned the management ability of the Long Island Lighting Company is not accurate because it is based on a faulty assumption and wrong measure of performance, the company has charged.
TRENTON, Sept. 25 An attempt by a women's group to prevent a proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the State Constitution from appearing on the November ballot failed today.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 Deep down in their hearts, the New York Rangers probably didn't expect to beat the Boston Bruins back to back. But when they took a 2-0 lead within the first 9 minutes tonight at Boston Garden, you could almost hear them humming to themselves: "Two in a row, two in a row..."

POINT BARROW, Alaska, Sept. 25 A five-mile-long, half-billion-dollar convoy of barges carrying essential cargo to develop Alaska's oil-rich North Slope, racing against time and the weather, turned back last night after a sudden change in the winds halted a dramatic dash around icelocked Point Barrow.
A sloppy track at Belmont Park for the sixth straight day found Joe King, the superintendent of the thoroughbred plant, taking the weather in stride.

Last week, a federally financed study depicted Jersey City as the worst large American city to live in. This week, a separate and independent report by a former New York City official evaluated Jersey City as a potentially good place to live.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP) Authorities confiscated more than $3-million in stolen airline tickets in an apartment here in what was described as the biggest haul of stolen airplane tickets in the history of United States aviation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Ford told Mayor Beame yesterday that New York State might want to consider a two-cents-on-the-dollar increase in the sales tax to 10 per cent for New York City residents to help ease New York's fiscal crisis.
WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP) An Attica prison inmate, accused of stabbing four guards and clubbing another last week, was indicted by a Wyoming County grand jury today.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 Bayonne's firemen, sanitation men and other municipal workers returned to work today after three unions reached a settlement in Superior Court here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Ford's new $100-billion energy program represents Nelson A. Rockefeller's major initiative within the Administration and makes it possible for him to say, after only nine months in office, that he has had a greater impact on policy than any Vice President before him.
LONDON, Sept. 26 W.H. Steavenson, the astronomer died in a hospital at Swindon, England, on Tuesday. He was 81 years old.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 The Government of India today expelled Jacques Leslie, the resident correspondent of The Los Angeles Times.

Negotiations to settle a dispute over a 25 per cent increase in apartment charges at Co-op City have collapsed, and state officials and leaders of the residents fighting the increase at the huge Bronx development blamed each other yesterday.

The Dean Witter Organization, Inc., parent holding company of Dean Witter Co., reported record revenues and net income yesterday for its 1975 fiscal year and indicated that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings had risen sharply.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The two alleged attempts to shoot President Ford have generated new demands from commentators, law-enforcement officers and private citizens for stiff Federal guncontrol legislation.

A Suffolk County housewife, who four years ago listened to a birth-control lecture while holding her 16-month-old daughter, was awarded damages yesterday by a Federal Court judge stemming from her arrest at the lecture on charges of impairing the morals of a minor.

In announcing his intention to have the State Board of Regents mandate a minimum for hours in the school day, State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyqutist is expressing warranted disapproval of the contractual agreement between the United Federation of Teachers and the New York City Board of Education to limit class size by curtailing classroom time.

The combination of spirituality with nonstop lovemaking is hard to beat. Put into action, it would make theologians of us all. Quintessentialized in art, it exerts a thralldom that is the more commanding for being comparatively recent in date. You don't have to have a long white beard to remember a time when Tantric art was a matter for specialists only and the kingdom of Nepal was virtually closed to travelers from the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 UPI President Ford has sent a letter to Oliver W. Sipple expressing his "heartfelt appreciation" for the former marine's help during an attack on the President in San Francisco Monday, the White House said today.
Frank R. Donovan, author of 32 books, many for children, died yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

The disclosure that Sara Jane Moore had a long record as an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other police agencies once again raises fundamental questions about the use of unstable persons as a link between the two worlds of law-enforcement and law-breaking.

FOURTH CITY Brooklyn, with a 1970 population of 2,601,852, bills itself as the nation's fourth largest city. Today, Brooklyn will be agog with appropriately big activities.

The New York Philharmonic and Pierre Boulez, back home at Avery Fisher Hall after their four-week European tour, opened the orchestra's 134th season on Thursday night with a program of classics old and not so old. Perhaps the musicians were feeling a post-tour letdown, or maybe one went expecting too much of this opening program; in any event, the night threw off only intermittent sparks.
ELIZABETH, Sept. 26 (UPI) The foreman of the Rahway Public Works Department admitted today that he had taken kickbacks for 11 years from a contractor who delivered road oil to the city.

Patricia E. Swinton was acquitted in Federal District Court here yesterday of having been part of a conspiracy to bomb several corporate and Government buildings in Manhattan in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 American wariness about a proposed summit meeting of the five leading industrial nations on economic matters has apparently diminished. A preliinary session of high officials to discuss such a meeting will probably take place in New York next weekend.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 (AP) Canada's fisheries dispute with the Soviet Union has been resolved and Canadian east coast ports now closed to the Soviet fishing fleet will be reopened Monday, Foreign Secretary Allan J. MacEachen said today.
Soviet scientists predicted for the first time when and where a new volcano would be born, according to the Soviet press agency Novosti.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 Bayonne's firemen, sanitationmen and other municipal workers returned to work today after three unions reached a settlement in Superior Court here.

The number of people counted as unemployed in the city fell, 2,100 in August, to 385,800, the State Labor Department reported yesterday, but department economists called the change "piddling, and far less than our seasonal expectations."

It is not surprising that small investors are unenthusiastic about New York City bonds. The bonds have always been relatively illiquid, and now that the city is threatened with insolvency, matters are even worse.

Francis A. Adams, a writer and publisher who served for many years as director general of the Minute Men of America, a patriotic organization founded in 1917 and active in the nineteen-thirties, forties and fifties, died Wednesday in Stuart, Fla., where he lived. He was 101 years old.

ELMIRA, Sept. 26--Several thousand residents of New York's Southern Tier were being removed today in preparation for a possible repetition of the disastrous 1972 floods as five days of incessant rainover four inches in the last 24 hours--drove rivers and streams to dangerously high levels.

The Knicks apparently stymied in their attempts to buy or trade for a name center or power forward, asked the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday for permission to try to negotiate a contract with Wilt Chamberlain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Ford's new $100 billion energy program represents Nelson A. Rockefeller's major initiative within the Administration and makes it possible for him to say, after only nine months in office, that he has had a greater impact on policy than any Vice President before him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Ford, seeking to avert a threatened citation for contempt of Congress, met today with House leaders to try to resolve a dispute over Congressional access to intelligence information.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Congress will begin hearings Monday on the National Football League labor controversy in an effort to see if an agreement on a new contract can be reached between the 26 owners and some 1,200 players.

The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it was contemplating another cut in its capital budget. The utility said it had two plans, one that would entail cutting $280-million and another a total of $380-million.

Dr. Nathan S. Grosof, emeritus attending surgeon at the Brookdale Hospital Center and associate surgeon at Lefferts Hospital, died yesterday at the center. He was 72 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) The Federal privacy laws will make it tougher for state and local tax collectors to catch draft evaders from the ranks of the 4.8 million military and Federal employes.

ROME, Sept. 26-- Many Western Europeans have reacted bitterly and sometimes violently with demonstrations against the death sentences imposed in Spain on convicted terrorists. The protests have been most intense in Italy and France.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 The oil exporters' cartel failed again to reach agreement tonight but appeared to be nearing a compromise on what qualified sources said would probably be a 10 per cent price increase followed by a price freeze.

The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced yesterday that it would join the Comsat General Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation in the development and operation of a domestic communications satellite system.
Moody's Investor Service, Inc., a leading rating service, announced yesterday it had withdrawn its rating on four New York State agency note issues due Oct. 15.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 Four continuous days of heavy rainfall caused flooding today along the banks of the Passaic River in Wayne, where the swollen river spilled over its banks in the Hoffmann Grove section of the township.

"Born Innocent," a made-forTV movie that raised a tempest of criticism when it was presented last fall, will have a repeat showing after the first of the year, but with careful editing of a scene that had agitated viewers and station managers around the country, Robert T. Howard, president of NBC-TV, disclosed this week.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP) Lester C. Emoff, a furniture store executive whose family paid $400,000 ransom, was found slain in a wooded area on the city's outskirts today, three days after his alleged abduction.

LISBON, Saturday, Sept. 27 Reuters) About 5,000 demonstrators sacked the Spanish Embassy and consulate here today to protest the execution of five convicted terrorists due to take place in Spain at dawn.

SAN FRANCISCO In 1959 the California Legislature authorized the creation of a "state development plan." This effort spanned the administrations of three governors, expended some $4million and came up with a report ten years later that recommended that there be further studies, leading presumably to the comprehensive plan that had been authorized in the first place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 The United States served notice in the Security Council today that would repeat its vetoes of the admission of North and South Vietnam to the United Nations because membership was being refused to South Korea.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 (UPI) Donald S. Macdonald, chiefly responsible for Canada's tough energy policy in the last three years, was named Finance Minister today to replace the retired John N. Turner, as Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reshuffled six Cabinet members and appointed two new ones.

LISBON, Sept. 26 Portugal's military leaders announced today the formation of an elite force to back the newly formed coalition Cabinet because of the gravity of the current political-military situation."

A Suffolk County housewife who four years ago listened to a birth-control lecture while holding her 16-month-old daughter, was awarded damages yesterday by a Federal Court judge stemming from her arrest at the lecture on charges of impairing the morals of a minor.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the total short interest figures it reported for July, August and September and for the WeilMcLane Company were overstated because of incorrect information submitted to it by one of its member organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 A former official of the Department of Agriculture told a Senate hearing today that the influence of large grain exporters upon his agency had been partly responsible for his retiring early from his position as a regional director of its grain division.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 26 (UPI) The dollar turned up again today, on most European money markets, buoyed by news of another United States balanceof-trade surplus. The price of gold also rose.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 The gun used by Sirhan B. Sirhan to shoot Senator Robert F. Kennedy more loan seven years ago was fired again today.

The Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a lower court's ruling upholding the legality of a law mandating the use of public pension funds to purchase Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

Dr. Samuel Breslow, a New Jersey physician who played a major role in invalidating the state's abortion law, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in University Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Perth Amboy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26-- The French Foreign Minister, Jean Sauvagnargues, told the General Assembly today that "France, and I think, Europe" were prepared to take an active part in over-all guarantees to strengthen a future peace settlement in the Middle East.

VIENNA, Sept. 26-- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact are months, and perhaps years, from agreement on any reductions of the 1.7, million ground troops massed in Central Europe, according to a score of officials on both sides.

The rains that flooded the New York area for the last five days resulted from an unusual combination of three factors a large mass of warm, moist air from Hurricane Eloise; a low-pressure area that carried it northward, and a stationary front that condensed the moisture, turning it into the 7.89 inches of precipitation that the city has endured this week until last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Colombia announced today she would relinquish United States economic assistance the first Latin-American country to do this starting next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Secret Service decided that Sara Jane Moore did not represent a serious threat to President Ford's life largely because the San Francisco Police Department had told it that she had served the department and two Federal agencies as an informer over the last 18 months, law enforcement sources said today.
Mayor Beame submitted legislation to the City Council yesterday to increase sharply the fines for violations of the city's air pollution control code.

The city's continuing deluge of rain washed out the scheduled twilight-night double-header last night between the Yankees and Baltimore Orioles at Shea Stadium and injected further crowding into baseball's only remaining pennant race.

Whatever the vagaries obscuring the rest of this country's energy policies, the experts concur on one urgent conclusion: In the absence of immediate corrective action, large areas of the nation will face economic distress, loss of jobs and production this winter from a shortage of natural gas.

Eugene Feldman, a printmaker and founder of the Falcon Press of Philadelphia, printers of fine books and art catalogues, died yesterday of a heart attack at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 53 years old and lived in Bela-Cynwyd, Pa.

NEWARK, Sept. 26 The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners rejected as unjustified today an application by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company for a $45.4-million interim rate increase effective Oct. 1.

WHEATON, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP) The president of a local Young Republicans chapter was charged with arranging to murder a young woman whose charm, he thought, distracted a friend from political work, the authorities said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26 This has been Beirut's longest siege. It has also been the most bewildering and enervating, since the connection between political issues and the street fighting has seemed so tenuous.

Richard D. Spence, vice president-operations of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company, yesterday was elected president of Conrail, the new Federally sponsored railroad company that will take over 15,000 miles of line now operated by the Penn Central and six other bankrupt carriers.

PARIS, Sept. 26 (Reuters) A French envoy returned from the desert of northern Chad today after handing over part of a ransom demand to rebels but without achieving the release of a captive archeologist, Francoise Claustre.

CAIRO, Sept. 26 Some leading Egyptian officials have begun to express great bitterness over the attitudes taken by the United States and Israel since the conclusion three weeks ago of the Sinai disengagement agreement.

MANILA, Saturday, Sept. 27-- After only 12 hours here Belinda Ali, the wife of the World heavyweight champion, left last night to return to the United States following a loud quarrel with her husband over Veronica Porche, whom Muhammad Ali has acknowledged to be his "girlfriend."

LAS VEGAS, Sept. 26 (AP) Wally Armstrong, who was just trying to make the cut, birdied five of his last six holes and scored a 65 today that lifted him into a six-way tie for the lead after two rounds of the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

The swollen Susquehanna River claimed the lives of the Binghampton, N.Y., fire chief and another fire officer as they searched for a drowned col- league yesterday, three days after surging waterways flood- ed much of New York State's midsection.

Chain store sales in August rose by 8.1 per cent over the level of August 1974, according to a compilation of Chain Store Age magazine. The August gain was the highest since last May and the second highest of the year. It compared with a gain of 7.7 per cent in July and 7.9 per cent in June.

Lay teachers at nine Roman Catholic high schools in the city and Westchester County went back to their classrooms without a contract yesterday after a two-week strike, but threatened to walk out again if an agreement with the New York Archdiocese was not reached soon.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 Amid heavy security measures, Emperor Hirohito left today on a jet airliner for his first state visit to the United States.
John M. Oliver, a teacher of French at the Horace Mann School from 1929 to 1968, died Sunday at his home, 600 West 239th Street, the Bronx. He was 77 years old.

In the wake of collapse of the Millbank-Frawley lowincome housing project in Harlem, there are a lot of tired fingers all over town. People uptown, in City Hall and in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development are all energetically pointing at one another in an effort to assess and avoid the blame for failure. And quite a failure it was.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 29, (AP) New guidelines by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for federally funded day care centers across the nation were blocked by a Federal court in an order made public today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 Julius (Moose) Solters an American League outfielder from 1934 to 1943, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital. He was 69 years old.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 29 Louis Untermeyer, whose faith has launched a thousand poets and whose taste has shaped a thousand textbooks, has just thought of another anthology that needed his talents.
KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 29 State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Liff died here last night, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 14 Deer Park Lane. He was 68 years old.
LISBON, Sept. 29 The balance has tilted again in the struggle for the eventual control and mold of Portugal. NonCommunist forces dominate the government and military leadership.

The Canadian Government, in another effort to improve the competitive position of Canadian magazines, plans new regulations that Secretary of State Hugh Faulkner said yesterday would compel Canadian editions of Reader's Digest and Time to differ in content by 60 to 80 per cent from United States editions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 The Credentials Committee today accredited the delegation of Israel, together with representatives of most other members of the 141-country General Assembly. Libya registered "strongest reservations" on the acceptance of Israel and hinted at possible "further steps."

Hugh Aitken's "Fables," a new chamber opera based on 10 of Jean de la Fontaine's versions of fables by Aesop and others, will be given a preview performance Oct. 23 at Shea Center for the Performing Arts at William Patterson College in Wayne, N.J....

WEST SIDE VERSE Poetry is alive and well in New York these days. Better yet, it's flourishing. Observers note that there are innumerable poetry workshops, a relatively large quantity of poetry is being published and readings abound.
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 30 (UPI) The New Hampshire Supreme Court upheld today limited state aid to parochial schools.

America might not have known it, but it faced a delicate crisis a short while back. Howard Cosell had hinted that unless he catapulted from the puerile precincts of sports, he might run for the U.S. Senate.

MANILA, Wednesday, Oct. 1 In the most brutal confrontation of their five-year rivalry, Muhammad Ali re- tained the world heavyweight boxing championship today when Joe Frazier's manager, Eddie Futch, surrendered from the corner moments before the bell was to ring for the 15th round.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 Republican leaders here said this evening that thus far they had sold only about half the $100-aplate tickets they hoped to sell for President Ford's fundraising appearance in Newark on Saturday.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30 (UPI) Samuel L. Latimer Jr., who rose from office boy to chief editor and publisher of The State, died yesterday at Veterans Hospital. He was 83 years old.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 30 As if it didn't know, the Jets' defense had to hear it from all sides today about how badly it has been playing. The trouble is, there appears to be no easy answer to help the unit straighten itself out.

In a corner of Middle Village in Queens near the tracks of the Long Island Railroad, there was a commercial laundry many years ago. Now the same building is a warehouse. Around the corner someone is making industrial springs in a former garage. Nearby, another small industrial building that used to be a machine shop is producing ribbons.

With a 63 per cent positive job-rating from the American people, Secretary of State Kissenger "now evokes more confidence from the public than any other member of the Ford Administration, including the President," the Harris Poll says.

The sharp Social Democratic setback in legislative elections in Bremen, the smallest of West Germany's eleven states, is a major political rebuff for the party's "Iron Chancellor," Helmut Schmidt, who faces national elections next year. It also has an important message for President Ford, whom Mr. Schmidt will be visiting in Washington this week.

Dr. James F. Cusick, professor emeritus of economics at Dartmouth College and a former Ford Foundation consultant on curriculum evaluation at other colleges, died Monday in Hanover, N.H. He was 77 years old.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 Police officers, equipped for the first time with electronic screening devices, scanned the crowds near President Ford tonight as security precautions during his carefully arranged visit here were increased.

Casey Stengel, who died Monday night in California at the age of 85, was mourned yesterday by a public that had marveled for more than 60 years at his antics and achievements as a baseball player, coach, manager and nonstop showman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Henry Kearns, when he was head of the Government's Export-Import Bank in 1972, promoted an apparently highly profitable sale of stock he had placed in a "blind trust" and received some of the proceeds of the sale, it was disclosed today.

A little over three weeks after Boris Spassky charged that Soviet officials had jeopardized his marriage plans, the former world chess champion and Marina Stcherbatcheff were married in a two-minute ceremony yesterday at the Moscow Wedding Palace. The 38-year-old...

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 (UPI) An unidentified suspect in an apparent attempt to murder a patient at the Veterans Administration Hospital scene of 11 mysterious respiratory deaths has been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, hospital officials said today. The officials said the suspect was not an employe.

The new Prosecutor of Passaic County, N.J., Burrell I. Humphreys, said yesterday that there had been "no misconduct" by his office or the Paterson Police Department in the triple-murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis.
William Ernest Donovan, former president and board chairman of L.P. Graner, Inc., consulting engineers, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home at 250 East 65th Street. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Top Secret Service agents told a Congressional hearing today that only a few hours before Sara Jane Moore allegedly tried to assassinate Presi- dent Ford she made five attempts to telephone the agents protecting him but was never able to reach them.
Yale University will announce today the establishment of a Graduate School of Organization and Management to train leaders for both business and government service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 With pomp, prayer and a President, the Federal Bureau of Investigation dedicated today its new, $126-million headquarters building, a buffcolored concrete fortress named for the bureau's late director, J. Edgar Hoover.

MADRID, Sept. 30--Premier Carlos Arias Navarro tonight angrily denounced international protests against Spain over the execution of five terrorists and called on the Spanish people to unite behind Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the Government.

MORRISTOWN, Sept. 30 Judge Jacques H. Gascoyne of Morris County Court fined the striking Parsippany-Troy Hills Education Association $100,000 today and threatened to jail its leaders if the strike did not end by tomorrow morning. The leaders pleaded guilty to criminal contempt charges as the strike continued for a 10th day in defiance of a court order.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30 Like the kings queens and other distinguished visitors who have come here to see the wonders of historic restoration at Colonial Wililamsburg, Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako of Japan will not walk their knees numb tomorrow, stand in a long perspiring line for a bowl of cream of peanut soup in an authentic tavern or be surprised by what it costs to tour the popular re-creation of Virginia's preRevolutionary capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the longstalled nomination of Earl J. Silbert, the original Watergate prosecutor, to be the United States attorney for the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Ford has ordered two Cabinet officers to review Federal allocations to New York City, at the behest of Senator James L. Buckley, New York Conservative-Republican, who complained to the President that the city was shortchanged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) The Senate Banking Committee voted today to allow savings and loan associations the right to offer checking accounts and credit card as part of a bill to reform the United States financial structure.

As a result of sizable cost overruns for the production of the dramatic series, "The Adams Chronicles," WNET/13 here has dropped two local public affairs series scheduled this fall and has cut back two others.

Pedro Cortina Mauri, the Spanish Foreign Minister, had what American officials termed "good talks" with Secretary of State Kissinger here today on an agreement to continue American military bases in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Sept 30 (UPI) Agricultural cooperatives appear to dominate the markets for milk, fruits and nuts and through Government regulations may have an impact on prices that runs counter to some consumer interests, a Federal Trade Commission report said today.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 30 (UPI) The dollar brought its lowest rates in more than a week on most European money markets today following predictions that the United States will have large budget deficits.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Ethiopia's military Government declared a state of-emergency today in Addis Ababa and the surrounding area in the face of a mounting challenge from workers and students.

Forty urban experts at colleges and universities in the metropolitan area said yesterday that the 10 proposed revisions of the City Charter would, if approved, "foster dismemberment of the city," place power in the hands of parochial party figures and generally weaken city government.

Stocks retreated along a wide front for the second consecutive day yesterday, reflecting continued investor uneasiness over the prospects of increased Federal borrowing and higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.35 points at 793.88.

ASAN, Guam, Sept. 30--The United States has decided to allow 1,600 Vietnamese refugees here to return to their homeland as they have requested despite the new Saigon Government's apparent reluctance to accept them.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Indonesian troops, in a strike across the border, wiped out a rebel base in Portuguese East Timor, informed sources said today.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30-Emperor Hirohito stepped off a Japan Air Lines jet plane at nearby Patrick Henry Airport this morning io begin a 15-day visit to the United States.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 30 The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company contended today that Hyman R. Shapiro, the builder, had defaulted on a $21.2-million mortgage the company held on the 30-story Colony apartment building in Fort Lee. The insurer got a court order directing Mr. Shapiro to show why the property should not be put under the control of a receiver.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Pepsico, Inc., for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 7, with profits up 21.1 per cent and 19.8 per cent for the respective periods.

LODI, Sept. 30 (UPI) Residents here, upset over a recent property-tax increase, voted today to oust Mayor John Bombace and two Councilmen and elected Christopher Paci as their new Mayor.

Sharp increases in the price of meat were offset last week by significant drops some, fruit and vegets prices and the cost of feed a family of four in New York City declined slightly by 0.1 per cent, the City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

The Philadelphia Orchestra began its concert at Carnegie Hall Monday night with Beethoven's "Leonore" Overture No. 3, but "Home, Sweet Home" might have been a good choice, too. Art is long and "relevance" is short, says Robert Brustein in "The Culture Watch." The word "revolution," when applied to theater, is usually no more meaningful than when it is used to describe detergents. The radical left resembles the bourgeoisie in trying to use the theater, one as a pacifier, the other as a bomb. The avant-garde is being corrupted by uninformed praise: it has so many new friends, it doesn't need enemies.

The W.T. Grant Company, one of America's largest retail chains, yesterday filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy, listing debts of more than,$1billion.

Stocks on the Americana Stock Exchange edged upward a little in slow trading yesterday, with the index closing at 82.37 for a gain of 0.12. In the over-thecounter market trading was also slow, with the NASDAQ industrials, closing slightly higher at 78.61, up 0.42.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The Federal Election Commission's proposal to regulate Congressional "office accounts" as a form of election-year political spending ran into a storm of criticism at a Senate hearing today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The House Intelligence Committee today shifted its battle for classified information to the State Department by voting to subpoena from Secretary of State Kissinger a memorandum that is reported to criticize the "mismanagement" of this country's diplomatic reaction to last year's invasion of Cyprus.

Moody's investors Service lowered its ratings of New York State and New York City securities yesterday-an action that worsened the financial difficulties of both governments and promised to raise their future borrowing costs.
ATLANTA, Oct. 2 The South's tallest building, the 723-foot Peachtree Center Plaza Hotel, was topped out here today, the most visible symbol yet of the vitality of the so-called New South.

Governor Carey was advised by a panel of banking experts yesterday that it would take an infusion of $142-million in state-funds to strengthen the Housing Finance Agency to the point where it might be able to regain investors' confidence and raise, on its own, the money it needs.

NEWARK, Oct. 2 The city plans to spend about $30,000 in overtime payments for some of the 450 policemen who will provide security for President Ford's visit here Saturday, and a wood and metal snow fence has been set up in Military Park to deny unauthorized persons access to the Robert Treat Hotel, where the President will attend a Republican fund-raising event.

For the first time in the 51-year history at the Boston Bruins, the club's official family will not include a member of the founding Adams family. Weston Adams Jr., who succeeded his father as club president two years ago when the Bruins were sold to the Storer Broadcasting Company, was replaced yesterday by Paul Mooney of Buffalo.

The City Council's Standards and Ethics Committee will consider today whether there was a conflict of interest in the use of official Council stationery by Matthew J. Troy. Jr., chairman of the Finance Com mittee, to advise "close friends" of his new insurance business.

TOA BAJA; P.R., Oct. 1When Carmen Paz was 40 days old, in 1955, her father packed the family's belongings and took his newborn daughter, his wife, and three older children from San Juan to New York Cily in search of a better life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2-Welcomed by President Ford amid all the pomp the White House can muster, Emperor Hirohito today voiced regret about World War II and said he hoped his visit would contribute to "everlasting friendship" between the people of Japan and the United States.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 2 Kumaraswami Kamaraj, the South Indian power broker who installed Prime Ministers Lal Bahadur Shastri and Indira Gandhi, died of a heart attack in Madras today. He was 72 years old.

There has been plenty of grim news to depress the market for bank stocks. The threat of default of New York City and a deteriorating, market for bonds of New York State haven't helped the banks, which hold massive quantities of tax-exempt bonds issued by both.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that "if the [New York City] financial crisis is not resolved it could injure the recovery process that is now under way in our national economy."

State Controller Arthur Levitt agreed yesterday to use $250million from two state employe pension systems to help tide the city over its cash shortages through this month and pledged to ask another state pension system, not under his control, to help the city next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The pressmen of The Washington Post have finally succeeded in doing to their own newspaper what former President Nixon and his Attorney, General John Mitchell tried and failed to do during the Watergate conflict: They have stopped the presses at The Post.

The people who live near it say that in another few days the Old Mine Road in northwestern New Jersey built about 1650 to carry copper from the Kittatinny Mountains to the Hudson will be at its must spectacular.

LENSES Camera fans can attend tonight's award presentations for outstanding work in the field at 8-o'clock, when the 1975, winners are honored by the Society of Photographers in Communications. The 30-year-old group of professionals is meeting in the McGraw-Hill auditorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas (at 50th Street). The tab for outsiders is $5; for reservations, call 6616450. Seating is limited.
The second round of aluminum price cutting in less than two weeks began yesterday with the announcement by Martin Marietta Aluminum, Inc., that it would remain competitive with consignment pric
A Federal judge has assailed a New York City ordinance that requires the display of the United States flag at assemblies and parades.

To get to Peters Valley the long way, which is to say the scenic way, take Interstate 80 to the Delaware. Water Gap and get off at the last exit in New Jersey (you might want to pick up a map at the information center on the other side of the highway), turning right, in the direction of Milbrook.
CLIFTON, Oct. 2 (AP) A Newark widower who operates a forklift for a living won $250,000 today in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The Central Intelligence Agency and Ithe Federal Bureau of Investigation used the Internal Revenue Service, apparently illegally, to harass groups they felt were politically threatening, according to evidence presented today at a Senate hearing.

SANTA MONICA, Calif. The French archeologist Francoise Claustre' stared into the camera, desolate. For 17 months she had been a hostage of rebel guerrillas in Chad. Whether she lived or died depended on whether the French Government acceded to their demands for $2 million worth of arms and aid.

Stephanie Maria Lee and Samford Lee Maier Jr. were married here yesterday evening in the Central Synagogue by Rabbi Lewis Bogage. The bridegroom is a member of the International Banking Group of the First National City Bank in San Juan, P.R., where the couple will live.
A severe shortage of fire wood exists in most poor countries of the world, where nine tenths of the people depend on wood as fuel for cooking and heating.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2 United States officials boycotted a social function given by President Idi Amin of Uganda today in a gesture of displeasure over some of his remarks at the United Nations General Assembly yesterday.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 The Chrysler Corporation announced today that the base price of its 1976 model cars would increase, by an average of $122, or 2.8 per cent, compared with 1975 models.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Two executives of a grain company were partners in a private agency, authorized by the Department of Agriculture to inspect and grade the company's grain, according to sources close to an investigation of alleged corruption in the grainexport trade.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company wrote off $35-million yesterday on a loan extended to the W. T. Grant Company as the effects of the bankruptcy filing by the giant retailer quickly reverberated throughout the banking, merchandise and real-estate industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) The National Football League owners challenged the players' union at a Congressional hearing today to negotiate every player's individual salary, from the lowest rookie to established stars.
Samuel Tress, who had been a men's wear retailer in this city for many years, died yesterday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 2 Eleven persons were killed today in a spate of renewed activity by bombers and gunmen in Northern Ireland.
On Sunday the Jets and the New England Patriots will play the first of 14 pro football games scheduled for Shea Stadium this season, and the Jets are favored to

The Virginia Electric and Power Company filed suit yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation over its contract that calls for Westinghouse to supply the utility with uranium to fuel its nuclear power plants.

Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, who is in the United States to describe his double-heart procedure to American cardiologists, said yesterday he was prepared to try the transplant technique again although two of the three patients who underwent it died within a few months of surgery.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2 (AP) Front-office personnel held the line today against a rush by disgruntled New Orleans Saints' fans, seeking refunds on tickets for the remaining six home games of the football season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee completed action today on a bill that would restructure the nation's banking institutions.

This city has a lot wrong with it, but pretentiousness is not one of its faults. Its ceremonials are homely ones: Macy's parade and painting the stripe on Fifth Avenue green are about as close as it comes to panoply. Grander efforts look a little silly and often come unstuck.

URUMCHI, China, Sept. 27 This is the time of the 26th anniversary of the People's Republic of China, but for the eight million people of Sinkiang it is also the 20th anniversary of its founding as an autonomous region where 12 minority peoples and ethnic Chinese live together.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (UPI) Willie Stargell, the slugging first baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates, is unhappy with having to wait almost a week for the baseball playoffs to start. "Who decides this kind of schedule, anyway?" he said today. "Do they ever ask the players how they feel about it?"

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct 2 Harold Wilson has emerged from the annual Labor party conference with his power intact and his policies unchanged. He received much criticism, and the stormy behavior of many of the 3,000 delegates who assembled here this week left little doubt that Britain's governing party remained di . . vided and emotionally insecure.

The next Watergate Special Presecutor, succeeding Henry S. Ruth, will be Charles Frederick Carson Ruff, a 36-year-old Justice Department lawyer and a former member of the Special Prosecutor's staff. Now the chief inspector at the Drug Enforcement Administration, Mr. Ruff successfully tried the Government's case in 1972 against W.A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, for illegal campaign contributions.

Off-duty black policemen have started appearing regularly at the Rosedale, Queens, home of a black couple that was fire-bombed last New Year's Day, in an effort to discourage what they say is continual verbal and physical harassment.

A definitive agreement has been signed covering the purchase by the Amoco Production Company of the Wyoming oil and gas producing properties of Pasco, Inc., for about $225million, it was announced yesterday. Pasco is 55.5 per centowned by Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., and Amoco is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

"Monty Python's Flying Circus" has done well enough on public television to make the commercial-TV committees itchy. Pythonesque humor tends to get broadcasters nervous. It's so unpredictable, and all that. Even on its British home ground, the Monty Python company regularly sets off slight quavers of disgust within the staid corridors of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 2 Leaders of the striking Hoboken Teachers Association were ordered today by Judge Thomas O'Brien to appear in Superior Court here tomorrow morning to explain why the union had not paid $35,000 in fines levied against it for violating a backto-work order.
The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has announced that the effects of new amendments to the State Employment Agency Act had been erroneously reported in a press release.
A Federal judge has assailed a New York City ordinance that requires the display of the United States flag at assemblles and parades.

The nation's retail chains geneerally reported yesterday that their September sales rose by less than the 10 per cent annual rate of inflation in consumer goods, indicating a drop in unit sales. The gains ranged from 3 to 25 per cent above the year-earlier level.

The Treasury confirmed yesterday previous reports that George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of the Treasury, would represent the United States at a secret fivenation meeting in New York this Sunday and Monday to explore the prospects for an economic summit meeting of the heads of state of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said yesterday that he was rather disturbed about United States economic policies, which he described as "too restrictive," despite a degree of optimism about the possibilities for moving out of the current recession.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, Democrat, introduced today a bill that would establish income ceilings on eligibility for food stamps and overhaul the administration of the $6-billion a year program.

The Allis Chalmers Coropration said yesterday it had won a $2.4-million claim against Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., but lost a $10-million claim against the company, both involving charges of insider trading in Allis stock.

Two weeks after the end of the citywide teachers' strike end after a settlement that was supposed to provide limits on oversized classes, shorter school days for pupils and the rehiring of 2,400 laid-off teachers conditions in many schools are reported to be confused, uncertain and in open violation of some contract provisions.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's public offering of 12 million shares of common stock priced Wednesday at $46 a share was overscribed yesterday, Morgan Stanley Co., the leading underwriter, reported.
MADRID, Oct. 2 Shouts of "Death to the Communists! No more clemency!" and of demands that the army seize power disrupted the funeral of three slain policemen here today.

Digging deep to make news, NeimanMarcus, the Dallas-based department store, is dredging up the ghost of preChristmas past as the expensive and imaginative gift suggeston that is an annual feature of its Yule catalogue.
CAMDEN, Oct. 2, (UPI) Gerald Gibson, accused of murdering an off-duty narcotics officer during a neighborhood feud, was held in the Camden County Jail today in lieu of a $200,000 bond.
The W.T. Grant Company, one of America's largest retail chains, yesterday filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy, listing debts of more than $1billion.

DETROIT, OCt. 2 The Informant who is providing in formation to two Senate investigators in an effort to find the body of James R. Hoffa got in touch with them this afternoon, saying that the effort was continuing and asking for a 24-hour extension.
ASAN, Guam, Oct. 2?Tran Thanh Tong summed up simply his reasons for wanting to go back to Vietnam: I think Vietnam is my-fatherland, and in Vietnam is my family."
It is standard operating procedure at D'Arcy-MacManus Masius to assemble its top brass in platoon strength when announcing major management changes.

"Isn't it spectacular?" said a beaming Franklin A. Thomas, president of the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation, as he welcomed guests yesterday to the opening ceremonies of the corporation's new $6-million commercial center.

The agreement between the White House and the House Select Committee on Intelligence barring unilateral release of classified information indicates, that the nation's vital intelligence operations can be protected while Congress effectively investigates abuses, violations of the law and the efficiency of intelligence procedures.

WASHINGTON The case usually made for the Sinai agreement is that it is one step in a step-by-step process that will lead to peace. As a result of conversations in August with President Anwar el-Sadat, King Hussein, Premier Yitzhak Rabin and other Arab and Israeli leaders, I fear that Congressional approval of the Sinai package in its present form could push the prospect for peace further than ever from our grasp.
An irony is being savored by the city's union leaders in the suggestion now being made that their pension funds buy anywhere from $2-billion to $4-billion worth of Municipal Assistance Corpo

Wherever he goes these days whether in Yugoslavia or in Illinois the President of the United States does not seem able to resist sniping at the City of New York. Perhaps he thinks his cheap shots at this premier American city make for good politics at home and abroad. In reality, they only betray his own incredible insensitivity to a potentially disastrous situation that could affect every city in this country.
If a single catchword has emerged from among the complex proposals to revise the New York City Charter, that word is "coterminality."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 The Administration won an important victory today in its running energy-policy battle with Cogress when Senate Democrats failed to kill legislation that would partly end Federal controls on wellhead prices of natural gas.

Edwin A. Wagner, an advertising salesman with Story Kelly-Smith, Inc., newspaper representatives, died yesterday of asphyxiation following a fire at his home, 87-26 Marengo Street in Hollis, Queens. His age was 48. He had apparently been smoking in bed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2-The House Ways and Means Committee approved changes today in what is known as the DISC programs of tax incentives for American exporters. The changes would cut by approximately one-third the tax savings to corporations.
By Broadway definition a "walker" is a musician getting paid for not doing anything.

L. Roy Blumenthal, board chairman of Roy Blumenthal International Associates, Inc., who had been public relations counsel on American affairs to West Germany since 1951 and West Berlin since l96l, died Tuesday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 126 East 19th Street.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) The General Motors Corporation defended today its decision to resume business in Chile, saying it did not believe its presence would strengthen the military government there.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 2 The paramount chief of the Transkei tribal area said today that South Africa would grant his reservation independence on Oct. 26 of next year.
GENEVA, Oct. 2 Robert W Sarnoff, chairman of the RCA Corporation, proposed today linking the capitals of all na tions with a global hot line using communications satellites.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 2?A Passaic County Freeholder charged with accepting a bribe from Albert scaletti, a former Mayor of Riverdale, told Mr. Scaletti in a taped conversation played here that he was not aware of "an understanding," apparently referring to a bribe scheme.

A new, nationally oriented report on funding for the arts urges an appropriation of at least $225-million for the National Endowment on the Arts next year, more than three times its current $75-million budget.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 2 The lawyer for the family of Karen Anne Quinlan said today the state would be guilty of "cruel and unusual punishment" if it did not permit removal of a respirator that has been sustaining her life for more than five months.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service says that Charles G. Rebozo, close friend and confidant of former President Richard M. Nixon, owes more than $100,000 in back income taxes, the Knight Newspapers said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Federal, Bureau of Investigation opened approximately 1,000 letters between 1959 and 1966 as part of a mail surveillance program conducted in New York City, a top official of the bureau said yesterday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Oct. 2 Usually there is not as much pressure on a second-round draft pick to be exceptional unless he's on a football team that had no first-round pick. Just ask Al Simpson, the New York Giants rookie offensive tackle out of Colorado State.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 2-The Government's Wholesale Price Index for September signaled continuing inflation today, as both agricultural and nonagricultural prices rose substantially.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2At the height of the battle between Representative Otis G.Pike, Democrat of Riverhead, L.I., and the White House over the publication of

The stock market halted a three-day decline yesterday as bargain hunters cautiously moved off the sidelines. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, off a total of 34.44 points through Wednesday, closed with a gain of 10.39 points to 794.55.

All but the poorest families would be faced with increased costs of sending their children to the City University if undergraduates at the university paid as much as those at the State University do, according to the chairman of the Board of Higher Education.
LISBON, Oct. 2 charges and countercharges increased here today in the wake of warnings by the Socialist party last night that the extreme left was about to stage a coup.
New York's biggest and most successful duplicate bridge club will divide itself like an amoeba into two parts today.

PARIS, Oct. 2 Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald L. Parsky said today the full extent of a 10 per cent increase in prices decreed by the oil exporters cartel last weekend will not be taken by all member states because of the present weakness in demand.
LANDER, Wyo. "Have you ever hunted sage hens?" asked Jack Brodie, a Lander rancher, as we sipped our brandies stand-up style in the dim, noisy, crowded confines of the Pronghorn Lodge Bar.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 3 The long spiritual exile of Thomas Wolfe, the bitter, impassioned young genius who felt he could not go home again after his first novel was published, ended today as the city of Asheville folded her arms around her native son 37 years after his death.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 Turkey's Foreign Minister praised the United States Congress today for easing the Turkish arms embargo but said American installations here would not be allowed to function grain immediately.

Like the referee in a boxing match, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey will have maximum exposure and minimum bruising today at one of the major New York Democratic party events of the year. It will be a rare political happening the joint appearance of seven Dem- ocratic contenders for the Presidency.
Potatoes jumped ahead in futures trading yesterday to match their previous record high level before moving down somewhat in late trading.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Senate gave final approval today to a measure partly lifting the embargo against the shipment of American arms to Turkey.

Dr. Henry Allen Moe, principal administrator of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation from its founding in 1925 to his retirement in 1963, died Wednesday at the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was 81 years old and had homes in Riverdale, the Bronx, and Sherman, Conn.
Milton Weill, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York from 1951 to 1954, died Thursday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP) K.D. Owen's Noble Rogue, after a dismal first heat, put together two victories today and won the $100,000 Kentucky Futurity, the third jewel of trotting's triple crown for 3-year-olds.

Governor Carey is considering a plan to tap 200 special funds scattered within the vast state bureaucracy for up to $1.5-billion as a ready cash replacement for the money it can no longer borrow in the private credit market.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 The story that Patricia Hearst was broken down by mistreatment at the hands of her kidnappers, recounted in an affidavit that she signed, came first from an anonymous source and not from Miss Hearst, accord- ing to one of her lawyers.

NEWARK, Oct. 3 A Superior Court judge refused today to dismiss an unusual suit that charges a school system with failing to educate properly a pupil suffering from dyslexia, a disorder that causes the brain to distort visual images.

HONG KONG, Oct. 3 Several weeks ago the Chinese press began an unexpected and seemingly baffling denunciation of one of the great classics of Chinese literature, "The Water Margin," a picaresque saga of banditry and rebellion set in the 12th-century Sung Dynasty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended its drawn-out dispute with Secretary of State Kissinger today by overriding his formal objections and declassifying four documents, already printed by the press, dealing with American assurances to Israel and Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The United States has formally presented a plan to liberalize the International Monetary Fund's compensatory financing facility by increasing the amounts member countries can borrow, informed sources said today.
HOUSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Four oil companies were ordererd by a Federal judge yes terday to pay more than $30million in contested oil import fees imposed by the Federal Energy Administration.

NAPA, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) Don January, making a tour comeback at age 45, exploited near-perfect playing conditions today for an eight-under-par 64 that put him into the second-round lead of the $175,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 About 20 Federal district, judges from around the country are scheduled to meet here this weekend in closed sessions to discuss school desegregation cases and how to handle them. At least three of those scheduled to attend are among the judges now involved in desegregation litigation.

PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska The brutal Arctic winter is fast approaching on Alaska's North Slope, and across rivers and over the tundra, through mountain passes, valleys and forests, the once controversial trans-Alaska pipeline is slowly nearing the halfway mark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 President Ford, accusing Congress of broadening school lunch subsidies for "nonneedy" pupils, vetoed today a $2.7-billion extension of Federal child nutrition programs.
A new and unusual zoning ordinance designed to shut down so-called massage parlors will be proposed for Times Square, Mayor Beame said yesterday.

Dave Lawson kicked only one extra-point when he played high school football in Shawnee Mission, Kan. The defensive lineman never tried a field goal in high school and got the chance for the conversion only because the regular place-kicking specialist was hurt that day.

Stock prices registered a broad advance yesterday in moderately active trading. The upturn, which topped gains scored on Thursday, was attributed to hopes that the Federal Reserve Board might be easing its monetary policy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-The nation's job situation improved slightly in September, the Labor Department reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 Delegates to the convention here of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations called today for a 35-hour work week and an increase in the minimum wage to $3 an hour.

Construction on 20 buildings throughout the city was halted yesterday by a teamsters' strike after a breakdown of negotiations with building contractors and suppliers concerning overtime and various other issues.

Tiffany's may have its "diamonds by the yard," but Alexander's is into "gem- stones by the pound."

The year's biggest thoroughbred payoff ($11,338 for $2) at Belmont Park on Sept. 18 was brought into focus again yesterday when the New York State Racing and Wagering Board reported a positive finding in urine and blood samples taken from the winner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The House passed today a compromise $49.3-billion money bill for the Department of Housing and Urban Development and other related activities such as disaster relief and the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) Bill Veeck, who owned the Chicago White Sox when they won the American League pennant in 1959 and sold the team two years later, has joined a group that has made a tentative agreement to buy the White Sox, the club announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Justice Department today charged a prominent California tax lawyer, a bank in the Netherlands Antilles and two other individuals with having conspired to defraud the Government of nearly $1.5-million in Federal taxes allegedly owed but not paid by the lawyer's clients, who the department said included a number of prominent California doctors and lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 To combat fraud in the federally insured student loan program, which he called "one of the most gigantic ripoffs in the country," Representative Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois, today introduced legislation that would invoke criminal penalties against profit-making schools and financial institutions cheating the Government or students.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 3 (UPI) Derek Sanderson scored three goals tonight as the New York Rangers recorded a 7-3 victory over the Providence Reds in an exhibition game at the Providence Civic Center.

The Chicago Tribune has finally abandoned its long, lonely struggle to simplify English spelling and, so, another good cause bites the dust. Like so many food causes that fail, it was undertaken with the innocent notion that an evil easily identified is an evil easily corrected.
Student resentment against oversized classes and reductions in school services triggered demonstrations yesterday at five Brooklyn high schools, keeping at last 6,500 students out of classes.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 3 (AP) France has agreed to build a $300-million nitrogen fertilizer plant that officials said would save Syria $400million now spent yearly to import fertilizer.

Bob Howsam, the architect of four Western Division titles and two National League championships, signed a new five-year contract yesterday as president and chief executive of the Cincinnati Reds. Howsam joined the Cincinnati organization in 1967 and had been named to his present position in March of 1974.
The American Stock Exchange index rose sharply yesterday, closing at 83.21, up 0.84. Volume was up slightly to 1,510,000 shares, from 1,307,000 the day before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Congress voted today to prohibit the Evironmental Protection Agency from taxing, limiting or banning automobile parking in urban areas.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) Niki Lauda of Austria found the extra speed he had been seeking today, driving his "training" Ferrari to a quick time in the first of two days of qualifying for the United States Grand Prix here Sunday.

Joe Frazier, a one-time major league pinch-hitter who spent 17 years playing baseball in the minor leagues and 10 more years managing teams there, vaulted into the front trenches yesterday when he was named manager of the New York Mets.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Washington Post recovered today from the sabotage of its pressroom and published a 24page edition after missing pub- lication only one day.
MADRID, Oct. 3 The Spanish Government declared today that the killing of three more policemen this week strengthened its determination to use the full weight of the law to stamp out terrorism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told President Ford today of Bonn's problems with inward-looking United States monetary policies today.

The notes for Thursday night's New York Philharmonic program made a valid point about the close historical connection between Beethoven and Wagner. But then the concert itself came along and badly bruised one's belief in that connection. Given no more evidence, that is, than back-to-back performances of Wagner's "Liebesmahl der Apostel" and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, who would care to recognize any similarities?

MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Oct. 3 Who are in the semifinals of the $50,000 Mission Viejo women's tennis classic? Cynthia Doerner and Dianne Fromholtz, a couple of little-known Australians, were the first to gain the bracket.

Charles H. Tenney 2d announced yesterday his intention of resigning as chairman, chief executive and a director of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., at the annual meeting next April. James F. Smith, vice president, treasurer and a director, also resigned from the upstate utility.

Mickey Sanchez, the Manhattan Chess Club's 8-year-old prodigy from Maplewood, N.J., met defeat yesterday in his international match with an accomplished adult member of a Swiss team playing from Geneva, but he earned an admiring salute from his opponent.

The Midwest, the nation's industrial heartland "is in trouble," Ralph R. Widner, president of the Academy for Contemporary Problems, said yesterday at a seminar of the Ohio Foundations Conference in Cleveland.

As he ended a state visit here this week, President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen of Colombia explained his Government's decision unusual for a Latin American nation to forego further United States aid and restrict new foreign investments sharply. He also said that "Colombianizing" of existing foreign operations would continue.

Alexandra Willim Sanford, financial vice president of the New York Junior League, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Rowland Compton, a broker with Blyth Eastman Dillon here. The Rev. LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The five-day siege of an Italian restaurant here ended today with the hostages safe, three gunmen under arrest and Scotland Yard expressing satisfaction with its handling of the case.

Business executives who use bribery as a commercial tool in foreign countries almost never pass money directly. They use middlemen, who appear on their rosters as "agents" or "consultants." Middlemen come recommended to the American company by local lawyers and bankers and even U.S. Government officials. Usually natives of the country in which they operate, they are sufficiently trusted by local Government officials to handle the ticklish matter of payoffs in comfort and secrecy.

"The biographies of slaves," wrote the abolitionist Thomas Wentworth Higginson in his 1861 account of Nat Turner's revolt, "can hardly be individualized; they belong to the class .... It is a life of fear, excitement, tension, compact joys, boredom, quiet satisfactions, and hard work. Geese honk high, in October, and ducks take off from the river or the pond in a shower of diamond drops, southward bound. After September's tropical storms have passed and the skies have cleared again, October can be bright as a bittersweet berry. It has the day-tang of walnut hulls and sumac berries and windfalls souring in the orchard. It has the night calls of barred owls and restless foxes.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 4-- Cornell used pass interceptions to score one touchdown and set up another today in a 21-6 victory over Bucknell. An interception and 15-yard runback by Don Papich, a linebacker, set up the first score, which came on a 1yard plunge by Don Fanelli, a fullback, Dave Johnson, a halfback, ran 59 yards with an interception of a pass by Kerry Snow for the visitor's third score.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 (Agence France-Presse)-- South Vietnam's revolutionary authorities are stepping up their efforts to encourage a return to farming with a plan to send 1.5 million people in Saigon back to the land over the next 15 months.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4--The Illinois Supreme Court has invalidated the state's death penalty law that was passed in 1973 to cover certain types of murder. The decision this week by the state court in Springfield voided the law on a procedural ground, ruling that it violated the state constitution. The court did not rule on the constitutionality of capital punishment.
